PROCTEXT.PARA: The PRESIDENT (Senator the Hon. Kerry Sibraa) took the chair at 10 a.m., and read prayers.

TALK.START.PARA: —Petitions have been lodged for presentation as follows:

PETITION.TITLE: Judeo-Christian Values
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:

That we are concerned that the Judeo-Christian moral values which have been fundamental in our laws and education systems since the foundation of the country are now being undermined in the current practice of law making, and we are concerned that the values of the secular-humanistic philosophy have taken their place therefore jeopardizing the moral climate of our society and contributing towards immorality and violence in our society.
Your petitioners therefore ask the Senate for the restoration of Judeo-Christian laws and moral values.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Legislation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled.
The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:

1. That it be recognised the proposed Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission Bill is a public, legal acknowledgment that Australians who are non-aboriginal do not have sovereignty in their own country.

2. That the Australian people are opposed to the idea of a treaty, compact or makarrata between the Australian people who are non-aboriginal and those who are aboriginal, and the Government has no mandate or authority to pursue it.
3. That the proposed legislation and treaty
will damage Australia's position under international law and in any conflict,
will cause distrust and conflict between our aboriginal population (1%) and the non-aboriginal population (99%),
will extend aboriginal land rights, contrary to the wishes of the Australian people,
will not be acceptable to the aboriginal people themselves,
will solve none of the problems of aboriginal people who need housing, health services, education and employment.

That therefore, the Senate reject absolutely the announced proposals for an Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission Bill, and the negotiation of a treaty, compact or makarrata between the Commonwealth and aboriginal people.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation: Funding
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled:
The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth that we are:
1. Opposed to the Government's decision to cut funding to the Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation in real terms for the sixth year in succession;
2. Greatly concerned with the ramifications of these funding cuts in terms of reductions in staff numbers and research capacity;

3. Greatly concerned with the ramifications of these cuts on rural research in Queensland and on the long term economic well being of the rural sector, which makes a significant contribution to Australia's export income.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Human Rights: Slovenian Civilians
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and the members of the Senate in Parliament,

We the undersigned petition you to express to the Yugoslav Government the concern of the Australian people and Parliament at the contravention of human rights of four Slovenian civilians. Zavrl, Borstner, Jansa and Tasic were court-martialled by the Yugoslav army in Ljubljana, Slovenia on 27 July 1988. The court-martial was conducted during a time of peace and in a foreign language. The defendants were not permitted their own representatives. The representatives were bodily removed from the proceedings.
Your petitioners, in duty bound, will ever pray.

DEBATE.TITLE: AUSTRALIAN BUREAU OF STATISTICS AMENDMENT BILL 1988

PROCTEXT.PARA: Motion (by Senator Sheil) agreed to:

That the following Bill be introduced: A Bill for an Act to amend the Australian Bureau of Statistics Act 1975 to provide for parliamentary supervision of the collection of information for statistical purposes.
Motion (by Senator Sheil) agreed to:
That the Bill may proceed without formalities and be now read a first time.
Bill read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sheil Sen G.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.
I seek leave to have the second reading speech incorporated in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The speech read as follows-

Following the question on my Bill for an Act to provide for voluntary answers to statistical surveys for all surveys save the census itself passing in the negative on a tied vote in the Senate, I now present a new Bill for an Act to amend the ABS Act 1975 to provide for parliamentary supervision of the collection of information for statistical purposes.
The purpose of this Bill is to allow for parliamentary scrutiny and, if necessary, rejection of statistical proposals within five sitting days of its tabling in both Houses of the Parliament.

Under present arrangements if the Government Statistician wishes to make a compulsory survey then he is required to table his proposals in both Houses of Parliament. There is currently no provision to reject or vary the proposals. This fact makes me wonder why the Statistician did not table the present household expenditure survey which is a compulsory one and thus differs in a most significant way from previous surveys which were voluntary.
I can only surmise that the reason was to keep the increased size, inquisitiveness and expansion of the survey from the view of the Parliament.
The current household expenditure survey has caused great contention, concern and harassment in the community despite denials by the Statistician.

The Statistician is asking people to disclose intimate details of their household income and expenditure of a most personal nature. Information that could not possibly be of value for determining the CPI, average weekly earnings and pension increases. Information such as the size and nature of bank loans, the collateral offered for them, access to people's bank managers, and other such information up to and including production of their income tax returns.
So much for having a privacy Bill to protect your tax file in one area when in another area the Statistician can ask you for your tax return.

The Government Statistician has become far too aggressive and assertive and has savaged the parliamentary process and the Clerk of the Senate. For his own reasons and against competent advice from his officers he decided not to table the proposals for the household expenditure survey and yet wanted to compel answers from people on the grounds that the survey was no different from previous ones. This is patently ridiculous and has been admitted by officers of the Bureau in the Estimates committees because other surveys were voluntary and if this one is compulsory that is a significant difference.
This Bill will allow for parliamentary scrutiny of survey proposals and their acceptance or rejection. Acceptance will give proposals the authority of parliamentary scrutiny.
Debate (on motion by Senator Jones) adjourned.

DEBATE.TITLE: TAXATION LAWS AMENDMENT BILL (No. 5) 1988INCOME TAX RATES AMENDMENT BILL 1988SALES TAX (EXEMPTIONS AND CLASSIFICATIONS) AMENDMENT BILL (No. 2) 1988

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 5 December, on motion by Senator Richardson:
That the Bills be now read a second time.
upon which Senator Messner has moved by way of amendment in respect of the Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 5) 1988:
At end of motion, add: ``, but the Senate notes that:
(a) this is the highest taxing government in the post-war history of Australia;
(b) through the insidious effects of `bracket creep' an estimated $7 billion has been ripped off Australian taxpayers since 1985-86;

(c) despite the additional revenue gained through `bracket creep', the Government continues to attempt to raise more tax revenue by imposing new taxation on the gold mining industry despite a firm and unequivocal commitment by the Prime Minister prior to the last election not to do so; and
(d) the Keating/Hawke Government should be condemned for its indefensible action in breaking its pledge not to impose a tax on the gold mining industry''.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Parer Sen W.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —Today we are debating Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 5) 1988 which will make a number of amendments to the Income Tax Assessment Act 1936. I wish to concentrate my remarks on one section of the Bill in particular-that is, the section that repeals the exemption from company taxation of income from goldmining, effective from 1 January 1991; a change announced by the Treasurer (Mr Keating) in the May economic statement.

SPEECH.PARA: Yesterday in this debate Senator Haines, the Leader of the Australian Democrats, equated our decision to oppose this gold tax with our decision not to oppose the graduate tax and she claimed that she could not see the sense in opposing one and not the other. Let me give the Democrats and Senator Haines the reason for that decision. In my State of Queensland, and I know also in New South Wales, we have suffered from discrimination in the form of a lack of tertiary places, to the extent that 4,000 to 6,000 young people in Queensland will not have the opportunity to go into tertiary education that they would have had if they lived in any other State in Australia. This Government announced that it would increase the number of tertiary places in Queensland by some 4,000 or 5,000 next year and, at the same time, impose the graduate tax.

As Senator Haines quite correctly said, we in the Liberal and National parties will not oppose that tax but we have promised to repeal it in government. Why will we not oppose it? We will not oppose it because the first thing the Minister for Employment, Education and Training, Mr Dawkins, would say if we opposed that tax in cooperation with the Democrats would be, `Those places will not be available next year'. Even though we do not approve of and do not support the graduate tax we certainly could not run the risk of depriving between 4,000 and 6,000 young people in my State next year of being able to take the opportunity to attend a tertiary institution.

On many occasions Senator Haines also expressed great concern about the level of debt and the high debt to equity ratios in our major companies. I ask the Democrats to reconsider their decision on the gold tax. The Democrats come in here and say that they will now support the Government on the gold tax. It should be pointed out that the goldmining industry is one of the few industries in this country where the method of financing companies is almost entirely equity. The Democrats and Senator Haines cannot have it both ways. They complain about negative gearing, about the level of debt and about large corporations borrowing money and thus reducing their level of tax, yet at the same time they come in here and complain that the debt equity ratio is too high; yet we have an industry where it is almost entirely equity.

The announcement in May 1988 that a gold tax would be introduced in 1991 is probably one of the most stupid things this Government has ever done. Apart from killing the goose that is laying the golden egg it will have a negative effect on mining in the future. I will come to that later. The Government obviously got so carried away with its taxation frenzy that it does not seem to realise it will probably collect less tax over a period as a result of this measure.

The gold industry has enjoyed a decade of most spectacular growth, rising to become this country's third largest export earner. It is worth recounting the history of the gold industry. People will recollect that what kicked this country off in the 1850s were the gold rushes. Everyone will have seen the various television series on the gold rushes, with the many groups of people who came from around the world to places such as Ballarat, Bendigo and Kalgoorlie. In 1850 the gold rush brought people to Australia. Gold really formed the basis of this country. It went into a slump, picked up again in 1900 and then went into a further slump. Since 1924 the gold industry, the gold companies, have been exempt from company tax.

There are many reasons for the continued slump. Honourable senators will probably be aware that, until the early 1970s, if my memory is correct, the gold price was fixed at $US35 an ounce. It was when that price lifted that new incentive came into the industry. The Government has enjoyed a commensurate rise in revenue from taxes on both capital gains and share trading profits on dividends from the gold industry. This is a new tax. Any claims made that the gold- mining industry is not taxed are false. The Government gets tax revenue from all dividends that go to shareholders because the dividends are unfranked. It also gets revenue from all shares sold after September 1985 by way of the capital gains tax.

Gold analysts believe that this growth phase would have lasted until the end of the century if the gold industry had been left unimpeded and untaxed at the company level. But I repeat that the industry is taxed because shareholders who get dividends, which inevitably they must, pay tax on them. In most cases they are probably taxed at the highest marginal rate. If not, they are certainly taxed at around 40 per cent because the majority of Australians today pay a marginal tax rate of 40 per cent. However, Australia's highest taxing government could not resist the temptation to slug an industry with yet another tax, and we will have a gold tax from 1991. Despite claims by this Government to the contrary, the proposed introduction of a gold tax will affect industry expansion and damage investor confidence.

Independent studies have been commissioned by the gold industry to try to gauge the effect of the gold tax on the share market and on the Government's overall revenue from industry. When other speakers mentioned the two groups who have done the evaluations, Ernst and Whinney and Arthur Andersen and Co., the remark we got from Senator Walsh was `hired guns'. That was a despicable remark to make about two very prestigious companies in this country. Predictions differ from study to study, but gold analysts agree that the tax will have a negative impact on the gold index. Share prices will almost certainly fall with the introduction of the tax. The upshot is that, while the Government will collect some $300m a year from taxing gold profits, its total tax take from gold will be less with a gold tax because its revenue from tax on capital gains and share trading profits will be reduced.

The study by Ernst and Whinney found that for every dollar gained by the Government from taxing goldmining profits, potentially in excess of $2 could be lost by way of direct taxes. The Arthur Andersen study calculated that approximately 30 per cent more tax would be collected under the present system, primarily through tax on capital growth of the industry as gold production grows, than from a corporate tax system.

Here we have an industry which is making an incredible contribution to our balance of payments, poor though that may be. Without it, God knows where we would be. This Government wants to take what is essentially a very progressive type of tax system and make it into a lousy system. It is the Government's short-sighted tax grab to get the money up front. This is the same system it used on superannuation. Everyone knows that when it is taken up front there is less at the other end. It is a confidence trick perpetrated on people in superannuation funds. I just draw the parallel. The Government's short-sighted tax grab to yet again get the money up front ignores the considerable evidence that it will get less revenue from the gold tax than it will under the present tax regime.

The real act of folly was the Government's advance notice of the gold tax. This is probably the most stupid thing I have seen for many years. By giving a few years notice, the Government is defeating one of the key purposes of its gold tax-to stop the loss of around $100m in revenue each year through repatriated dividends. Thanks to the advance notice, companies which had previously reinvested their gold profits in Australia, thus increasing the wealth of this country and thus increasing employment, are now sending those profits off-shore to take advantage of lower taxes in their own countries. This loophole in the present tax regime could have been effectively closed by imposing a withholding tax on foreign companies at the same rate as if the dividends were paid in Australia. Senator Walsh estimates that foreign treasuries pick up $100m. The Government could simply have done it by introducing a withholding tax at the same rate as if dividends were paid in Australia. The Treasurer fancies himself as a fiscal genius. Surely this would not have been too hard even for him to comprehend.

Another negative effect of giving advance notice of the tax is that all goldmining companies are now, where possible, high grading. That means that they are mining their most economic areas and maximising the profits before the tax is introduced. I point out that this is being done throughout the country for open cut mines. It is not as easy for underground mines, but it is being done. Once one starts to high grade and takes the most economic reserves, one then sterilises a large number of Australia's reserves until the day comes when the price of gold goes up quite substantially, perhaps doubles. The tax has provided miners with an artificial incentive to exploit the richer ore before the tax is introduced.

TALK.START.PARA: —So all the jobs in the industry are under threat.

—As Senator Messner says, all new mines are certainly under threat. This is sterilising resources of low grade gold deposits which will only become economic once we get a substantial increase in the price of gold. According to the Government in its May economic statement, the reason for introducing the gold tax was that there was no economic justification for continuing the concession while other industries were fully taxed. They were the words used. What the Government was saying was that it wanted the company-based taxation system to apply as it applies to other industries, ignoring the fact that tax is already applied. It is a very positive sort of tax which has produced great results for this country. The Government's inference that the gold industry does not pay its way is false. The industry is taxed but it is taxed in a positive way. Profits from goldmining companies are taxed in the hands of shareholders when dividends are distributed, because the dividends from goldmining companies are unfranked dividends.

SPEECH.PARA: As I mentioned earlier, the Government also collects revenue from tax on capital gains and share trading profit. Profits that are retained for reinvestment into the industry to fund further exploration and mine development are not taxed at that stage. The gold mines currently reinvest most of their profits in further production, thus increasing our wealth and our exports. Hence, the massive increase in the level of exports of gold in this country. The beauty of the goldmining industry's present tax regime is that it encourages savings and investment. This, together with gold prices, has been the prime reason for the spectacular growth of the industry over the past decade.

Gold is now Australia's fastest growing export earner. In 1985-86-not so long ago-gold was ranked tenth on the major export list, but in the space of two short years it has risen to be the third largest export industry. In 1987-88 goldmining is expected to earn this country in excess of $2.5 billion a year-$2,500m a year-in export income. This is precisely the kind of investment and saving the Government should be encouraging if Australia is to trade its way out of its foreign debt and balance of payments problems. As we all know from the figures we received last month, our net foreign debt increased by $1.6 billion, or at the rate of $65m a day. Neighbouring countries in Asia, such as South Korea, are reducing their debt by in excess of $1 billion a month. Australia is a nation of spenders rather than savers because the Government's measures are a disincentive to save. We need incentives in order to save. Our savings ratio is not only low by world standards, but also has fallen dramatically in the past 10 years. In 1975 it stood at 15 per cent; today it is around 10 per cent. Total investment was 27 per cent of gross domestic product in the 1960s; in the 1970s it was 25 per cent. In 1986-87 it was around 22 per cent of gross domestic product.

Investment is the engine of economic growth of any country, thus it is the generator of employment. Without that investment we do not have employment; without employment we do not have wealth creation; without wealth creation we cannot provide the necessary services to people who are disadvantaged in the community. It defies commonsense for this Government to dismantle the goldmining industry's present tax regime which encourages the very savings and investment that are so necessary in this country. Instead of shackling the gold industry with a punitive corporate tax rate, the Government should be extending that industry's present positive tax system to other key industries. But the Government's perverse idea of equity and fairness is to ensure that the goldmining industry is equally crippled by punitive taxes as are many of our other industries. Why take a successful industry out of a good system of tax and throw it into a lousy system?

Various lobby groups often make the claim that their particular industry or commodity is unique and therefore warrants special consideration or exemption. This is a valid claim to make about gold which is one of the world's rare elements. It is at its strongest price-wise when other commodities are depressed. It is a good insurance against hard times, especially given Australia's heavy reliance on commodities. It can double or treble production without depressing world gold prices and is a store of wealth. It is a medium of financial exchange. It is an industry we should be doing everything in our power to encourage. No wonder over the years governments have developed quite a justifiable reputation of taxing efficient wealth creating industries and subsidising, through taxpayers' money, inefficient industries. For goodness sake, why do we not leave the efficient industries alone so they can create wealth and jobs?

The Government stated in the May economic statement that it did not expect the exemption to impact significantly on the scale of the industry as exploration costs would be deductible. This, of course, is nonsense. The gold tax will effectively cut up-front profit margins by half and it is the first rule of the mining industry, or any industry, that when profit margins drop, exploration or research and development is the first area to get the chop.

TALK.START.PARA: —That has already happened.

—I thank the honourable senator. The gold industry has already been hard hit. Drilling contractors are suffering a dramatic cutback in exploration projects since the tax was announced in the May mini-Budget, and some have already gone broke.

SPEECH.PARA: When referring to the remarks made by Senator Haines I mentioned that the gold industry has relied almost entirely on equity, on shareholders' funds, to develop and progress and on the re-investment of profits. Existing mines will continue until costs exceed revenue and then they will go out. What will happen now is that fewer mines will be developed. What the existing industry will do-I am not being critical when I say this as it is a sensible decision-is go into debt, because up until now there has been no benefit to companies from tax deductability of interest, depreciation and so on. They did not get a deduction because they did not pay company tax. It is inevitable that all the costs that apply to other industries will now apply to goldmining, so we will see large debt-equity ratios-the very thing that not only Senator Haines but also Senator Walsh complain about. Senator Walsh would like to see more equity.

The amended depreciation provisions for mining plant and equipment will add another element of risk and uncertainty to the gold industry. In an age of dwindling natural resources, this tax will lead to an inefficient use of our gold resources. Many goldmining companies will be forced to lift the cut-off grade of the ore being mined to accommodate the tax, making low-grade deposits uneconomic. What a waste of Australia's resources. Resources are good only if they can be exploited economically. If they cannot, they are not worth any more than the dirt that lies over the top of them. It is estimated that as much as one-quarter of Western Australia's low-grade gold bearing ore could stay in the ground as a result of the tax. What a waste of resources, at a time when we have enormous balance of payments problems, when our current foreign debt gross is $120 billion and rising, and when our net debt is $93 billion.

Tailing retreatment and heap leaching operations will also be threatened. For example, Western Mining Corporation Ltd's three million tonne stockpile of low-grade dirt will have to be treated before 1991 because it will become uneconomic and useless after the tax is introduced. The situation is being aggravated by the high grading that I mentioned earlier. Can honourable senators imagine the Minister for Finance telling financial institutions what the exchange rate will be in 1991 and the effect that that would have? What the Government has done is say that in 1991 there will be a punitive tax and so the industry reacts accordingly with high grading.

The gold tax will jeopardise not only the goldmining industry but also its associated service industries and communities which rely on the industry. This was made very clear to the Government when the Labor member for Kalgoorlie, Mr Campbell, crossed the floor in the other place. He comes from Kalgoorlie and has seen what the gold industry has done to revitalise that area. Particularly hard hit will be Western Australia, where over 70 per cent of Australia's gold is produced. Even the Labor Premier of Western Australia-I do not know how serious he was; possibly he was protecting his political hide-described the gold tax as `a clear breach of faith' with the Western Australian Government and the community. What he meant by that was that, yet again, the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) had broken another promise. Before the last election the Prime Minister of this country went over there and said, `There will not be a gold tax in the next term of government'. He is saying that he has sort of honoured his promise because, although he has introduced the legislation now, it will not come into effect until 1991.

A recent survey commissioned by Australian mining exporting companies found that 73 per cent of Western Australians opposed the tax. One cannot blame them. Their livelihoods depend on the industry and may now be at risk. Certainly, future growth will be at risk. The electorate will show the Hawke Government what it thinks of the gold tax at the next election. It is yet another tax; yet another broken promise; and it shows, yet again, that neither this Government nor its Prime Minister can be trusted.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Panizza Sen J.H.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 5) contains measures which include a corporate tax on gold and arrangements for employee share acquisition schemes and transitional imputation. I am going to direct my comments towards the corporate tax on gold. This is probably the most important taxation Bill that has come before this place since 1924, which was the year that Australia saw fit, for grave economic reasons of the time, to remove the corporate tax on gold to boost gold exploration and production. This was done to attract investment from overseas, to attract migration after World War I and to boost export income to enable Australia to overcome the debts it had acquired during World War I. The results at the time were tremendous, with a return to the gold rush days enjoyed in the latter part of the nineteenth century and the immediate years which led up to World War II.

SPEECH.PARA: The gold rush towns of Coolgardie, Kalgoorlie, Southern Cross, Leonora, Laverton, Malcolm, Cue, Daydawn, Wiluna, Meekatharra, Kukynie, Mount Magnet, Lancefield and Norseman, as well as their counterparts in the eastern States, boomed and blossomed, making Australia part of the roaring twenties which we have heard so much about, This preceded the Wall Street crash of 1929 and the Depression of the thirties. With the advent of that disastrous depression, mining was the one and only industry which did not feel the pinch of the downturn. Whilst cities had queues for work, the dole or whatever, with professionals out of work and doing menial jobs-when they could get those menial jobs-the goldfields were bursting at the seams. I remember my father telling me that in mining towns-Broken Hill, incidentally, was not a goldmining town-in Kalgoorlie and my own home town of Southern Cross, Western Australia, which is 100 years old this year and was the first developed goldfield of Western Australia - -

TALK.START.PARA: —Send them our best wishes.

—Thank you, Senator Messner. These mining towns did not know what depression meant because of the boom in gold production. Those towns were the last bastions of non-depression. Goldmining prospered till World War II, when most mines closed because of the lack of manpower.

SPEECH.PARA: The end of World War II saw a minor revival, even though some of the marginal producers did not reopen. Activity remained in the main centres, like Kalgoorlie, till the early 1970s when production-except at Mount Charlotte, which was the only mine working in the eastern goldfields-ceased altogether. Fortunately, the nickel boom of that time saved the goldfields. Intensive exploration led to the eventual development of the nickel mines such as Kambalda and Scotia and the most famous, Windarra, at Poseidon. A lot of the gold that was discovered was later brought on tap in the present gold boom. One of those discoveries was a big find at Kambalda.

Goldmining remained dormant till around 1983, when we saw the current revival. It was a timely revival, because at that time we had the worst levels of unemployment since the Depression-a disastrous situation. Also at that time there was a downturn in the rural sector and without the revival of mining Australia would have been in a far worse situation. I have said time and time again in this place that those two great industries achieve 85 per cent of Australia's export income. It has been the usual pattern, over the last 100 years, that when the mining sector is down the agricultural sector is up. But at present, Australia needs both sectors to be up at the same time in order to get over this Government's disastrous balance of trade problem. Fortunately, since 1982 the agricultural sector has also risen. Hopefully, those two sectors can pull Australia out of the mire which it has been in and is still in.

There were two good reasons for this great revival in the goldmining industry. One was the price of gold and the other was the lure of freedom from corporate tax, causing money to pour in from overseas. Very little of this money ever goes back. I know from reading that of every thousand goldmining floats in Australia only one venture ever produces gold. Presumably, most of these eventually pay a dividend. But we should look at the expenditure that goes into employment, machinery, materials, lease money paid to the mining departments around Australia, rates to local government and so forth. How does one justify a differential tax system for a particular industry purely on economic criteria? I believe that one should look at the contribution it makes to export income and the contribution it makes to employment. I will deal with them separately.

Export income has never been needed as much as it is now. We have a record current account deficit at a level never seen before in Australia, even when primary producers have been earning near record income from wheat, wool, beef, sugar and coal in the past two years. Despite these record export earnings, more and more income is needed to try to address the current account deficit. Gold is certainly doing its bit towards the situation. I have a list of export figures for gold showing that in 1982 Australia was produ-cing 13,076 kilograms per year and earning $135m. In 1987 we produced 86,402 kilograms worth $1.6 billion, and in the first two quarters of 1988 Australia has already earned $882m. Bearing in mind that the summer is yet to come, with the better weather conditions, so open cuts can be worked with fewer problems-more gold is produced in Australia in summer than in winter-the figure of $2 billion will soon be achieved. That is on the export side.

I move now to the other main aspect, employment. The employment figures show that in 1982-83 goldmining employed 3,140 men and women around Australia. In 1983-84 the figure jumped to 4,058; in 1984-85 it moved to 4,184; in 1985-86, 5,177; and in 1986-87, 6,582. At the same time wages and salaries rose from $69.6m to $196.1m. Of course, it does not stop at that point. The multiplying factor provides jobs far beyond that number. They are real jobs, not one's created by government spending. Figures from the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade show that the multiplying factor in the goldmining industry lies at 2.9, which means that approximately 19,000 other jobs flow directly from goldmining, with a related wages bill. These extra 19,000 jobs may be far removed from the goldfields, being provided by manufacturers and suppliers of goods in the cities. I also have a sheet here which shows those figures and which I will seek leave to incorporate later.

Last evening in this place I listened to Senator Haines speaking. She maintained that rather than give preferential treatment to the goldmining industry, there should be more done towards encouraging small business. I know no better way to encourage small business than to have a buoyant large business whereby the benefits flow from it. If there is money in the towns, if the companies spend money and the employees spend money, that is where the small businesses really do well and they do not need any other incentive. In my home town in about 1982 the rural sector was starting to decline and goldmining was in the doldrums; small businesses that had remained in the same family for the last 50 or 60 years were virtually at the end of their tether. I have been speaking to them and with the upturn in the goldmining industry they are certainly not complaining now and they can see a great future ahead of them.

One aspect that is forgotten in this debate is that the price of gold was fixed by the International Monetary Fund until 1974, at, I believe, $38 an ounce. The Government Mint was the sole buyer and it was illegal for any person, other than a producer, to hold gold. All this time a price 10 times higher could have been obtained overseas and a black market existed for anyone willing to try to get that gold out of Australia. I can remember an incident at Fremantle, where a car was being loaded on to a passenger liner, where for some unknown reason the crane drivers could not balance the car. They had the standard sling which balances a car by having a platform under each axle. Every time they tried to lift it, it was off balance. After a while the car was put aside and the next morning we all read in the press how that car had a lot of gold stacked in the sump. Obviously some people went to the trouble of taking the sump off, putting the gold in and putting the sump back on; but they were caught. Those are the measures that people who possessed gold took to get it out of the country.

Presumably the Government, through the Mint, was buying from the producers and selling at world prices and pocketing the difference. This is commonly forgotten. The gold companies could have reaped billions during those times and could have expanded much further. As I said, in my chronology of events we are at the latest boom and so the Government is looking at yet another new tax to add to its increasing list of new taxes to pay for its expanding spending mode, a spending mode that it got out of control. The Government will not tighten its own belt when it expects others to tighten theirs.

If honourable senators do not know the effects that the latest upsurge in goldmining is having on the economy, they should visit, or better still it should be compulsory for every senator and member to visit, the mining areas of Western Australia. I know that half a dozen of my colleagues who disbelieved the effects, visited those areas two months ago and came back with a vastly different opinion. These mines are situated in Australia's harshest environment, bordering some of Australia's desert regions-places like Laverton, Wiluna, Meekatharra and Telfer. Incidentally, my theory on the Telfer mine, which is the only real gold producing mine in the Pilbara area, distanced from a lot of other areas, is that it is Lasseter's lost reef. In summer those places reach 48 degrees and often stay over 40 degrees at night, with minimal winter rains.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to hear that theory.

—I will discuss that with Senator Harradine at some other time. That has been my theory for a few years now, and I have spent some time looking for Lasseter's Reef, without success of course. Miners and their families put up with harsh conditions in order to man the mines. As a result, they do much for our export income. If anyone from the comfortable cities of Sydney, Melbourne or Adelaide-Senator Haines's home city-made a visit to those areas and saw for themselves the harsh and inhospitable conditions that people are forced to contend with, they would soon change their minds and realise that this industry does deserve preferential treatment. How many in this place would live and work in those areas? I have already given the figures relating to the economy since the upturn, and at this stage I seek leave to incorporate them in Hansard.

TALK.START.PARA: —Last evening I heard Senator Haines say that more tax should be imposed on this industry so that benefits could flow to ordinary families. I presume the honourable senator meant ordinary families in her own city of Adelaide. She would be quite prepared to let the families in these harsh areas be placed in jeopardy from loss of employment and facilities so that ordinary families in Adelaide could be more comfortable.

SPEECH.PARA: Let me deal now with the myth that gold producers do not pay tax. This is far from the truth. Royalties are paid to the Government on a per ounce basis. In 1987 alone this amounted to $9.5m. A further $9.2m was paid to private landholders, et cetera. As I have said, $9.5m went to governments around Australia. I seek leave to incorporate that document in Hansard.

TALK.START.PARA: —Contrary to popular belief, or as the Government would have everybody believe, dividends in the hands of Australian shareholders will be taxed at the taxpayer's marginal rate, whatever that may be. This was borne out by Senator Parer. As he said, this could quite easily be 49c in the dollar. This is because the dividends coming from goldmining companies are unfranked, as they do not pay corporate tax. Further, unfranked dividends going to foreign countries will be subject to two-way agreements between Australia and the other country. Most agreements provide for a withholding tax of 15 per cent. Alongside that, there is no deductability of exploration or production costs. Tax is also paid on the by-products of goldmining such as silver and lead. As I have already mentioned, other minerals are found in exploration which could then be mined.

SPEECH.PARA: How much is this hungry Government missing out on the collection of tax? Everyone pays the withholding tax. Under these agreements there is a 15 per cent withholding tax on dividends going overseas. Conversely, tax is paid by others overseas. So if there is an equal amount going in or coming out-I presume that there is more going in than coming out-30 per cent will be reached in no time. So how much are we missing out on? It is certainly not as much as the Minister for Finance (Senator Walsh) keeps telling us in this chamber. He would have us believe that foreign treasuries are the only ones that will lose by having a corporate tax on gold. This is not correct. I am sure that most senators in this chamber are of the belief that all dividends going overseas are completely free of tax. That is not correct. I suppose one could say, as was mentioned earlier by Senator Parer, that the solution would be to raise the withholding tax rate to the new corporate tax rate of 39c or even to 49c, being the top marginal tax rate. But what would happen to the agreements? To do this would mean changing those existing agreements. Honourable senators should remember that the agreements are a two-way effort. If we increased withholding tax on dividends going overseas then other countries logically would do the same to us. This would mean that the Australian Treasury would miss out. Senator Walsh has conveniently forgotten to tell us of this aspect.

I now refer to a letter that most honourable senators and members in this place would have received from Sir Arvi Parbo on the gold tax matter. I presume everyone would say that he has an axe to grind on this matter. His letter certainly does make sense. Incidentally, for those who think that Sir Arvi Parbo was always Sir Arvi and spent all his life in his fiftieth floor office in Melbourne, that is not correct. I knew him as a very ordinary man working as a shift boss underground in my home town of Southern Cross. He is certainly to be congratulated on where he has got to in this world, especially starting from such a place. It is a long way from Southern Cross to Chairman of BHP. His letter states:
The integration method as now applied to gold mining has the advantage that undistributed company profits are not taxed in the first instance.
Such profits are invariably applied towards further development and investment, and more funds are therefore available from internal company resources-
that is, without borrowing-

for these vital purposes. Encouragement of more investment in productive activities is, as we all know, absolutely essential for the future of Australia. The undistributed profits will not go untaxed, because additional dividends and capital gains resulting from reinvestment are taxed in shareholders' hands when received.
How true that is. I would also like to quote from the Senate Hansard of 9 September 1925 on the goldmining industry. Senator Lynch from Western Australia stated:
the gold-mining industry is one whose home is essentially in the back-blocks. It belongs to all the States, even though Western Australia is the main producer.

There is no State of the Commonwealth that is not a contributor to the gold production of the Commonwealth. It is true that the contribution of Western Australia is in the neighbourhood of 70 per cent., which may change, but those of us who are large-minded enough to let our eyes wander beyond the boundaries of our States realize that if good can be done to any one State, especially in a pioneering industry, the benefit it creates is not confined within the boundaries of that State, but necessarily overflows into the neighbouring States with a consequent advantage to the whole of the Commonwealth.

Those words are still true today. The Government intends to raise $300m out of this taxing measure when it comes into action. But if we look at the second reading speech of the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories (Senator Richardson) we see that in the first instance the savings figure is $870m. I presume that is a typographical error-I hope it is-but it does show how much the relevant department has done its homework. As well, I am not sure that savings in later years will be in the order of $300m when we take into account the tax already being paid, and bearing in mind the other comments I have made.

In conclusion, I reiterate that this is the most important mining industry Bill that has come before this Parliament since 1924. It is so important because it attempts to reintroduce a tax on the industry. As the Senate well knows, the coalition is opposing the measure. Our reason for opposing it goes far beyond next year's election in Western Australia. I am not silly enough to claim that our stance may not have an effect on that election, but our reasons do go far beyond it. When the election results in Western Australia have been forgotten, the effects of this legislation will remain. It is an important measure that will last for the next 100 years. I must put on the record my appreciation for at least one member of the Australian Labor Party who, in the other House, had the guts to cross the floor in support of the area he represents.

TALK.START.PARA: —That was just pragmatic, though.

—At least he had the courage to stand up and do it. I presume he is respected for that in his electorate. With the help of the Australian Democrats this legislation may go through, but the Labor Government will still pay for it by losing the seat of Kalgoorlie in the next Federal election, and probably Kalgoorlie and Murchison-Eyre in the State election coming up. However, it is not as though we need the impact of this measure to win that election; I think we are well on the way to winning it now.

SPEECH.PARA: I support the amendment moved by the Opposition to the second reading motion for these Bills, which states:
. . . the Senate notes that:
(a) this is the highest taxing government in the post-war history of Australia;
(b) through the insidious effects of `bracket creep' an estimated $7 billion has been ripped off Australian taxpayers since 1985-86;

(c) despite the additional revenue gained through `bracket creep', the Government continues to attempt to raise more tax revenue by imposing new taxation on the gold mining industry despite a firm and unequivocal commitment by the Prime Minister prior to the last election not to do so; and
(d) the Keating/Hawke Government should be condemned for its indefensible action in breaking its pledge not to impose a tax on the gold mining industry''.
In conclusion, I maintain that if this Bill is passed and comes into effect in 1991 all those responsible will live to regret their decision.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: —Because of the time constraints imposed upon us this week and next my remarks will be very brief. The Senate is debating cognately the Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 5) 1988, the Income Tax Rates Amendment Bill 1988 and the Sales Tax (Exemptions and Classifications) Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1988. Senator Panizza has just read out to the Senate the amendment moved by Senator Messner on behalf of the Opposition. It is not often that I totally agree with the Opposition, but I do so on this particular occasion. However, I do not think the Opposition has gone far enough. Paragraph (b) of the amendment suggests that as a result of the insidious effects of bracket creep an estimated $7 billion has been ripped off Australian taxpayers since 1985-86. That is not the only thing that has led to the loss of living standards experienced by taxpayers, particularly those with dependent children.

SPEECH.PARA: In fairness to the Opposition, I note that yesterday this was raised as a matter of public importance, and justifiably so. This proposed legislation is going to bite. It is biting right now. It is hurting the people of Australia, those workers and taxpayers with dependants who are paying their way in this community. More and more of those people are being forced to the wall by this Government's taxation policies and by its failure to recognise the importance of raising children in this country. This situation makes me furious. This has been boiling up within me over the last year or two because of the ignorance and arrogance of this Government; because of its pitiful ignorance of what its policies mean for an ordinary person with a dependent spouse and children to raise a family. It is all very well for those Ministers who have no dependants or who are on a fat salary. Indeed, under the Hawke Government the recommendations of the Remuneration Tribunal will enable Ministers to cop salary increases.

TALK.START.PARA: —I doubt it.

—The House doubts it. The Tribunal's recommendations for salary increases were based on the assumption that Ministers and the Government were doing their job. But Ministers and this Government have failed in their fundamental task of treating Australian families fairly, and particularly those with dependent children. Added to what is contained in the Opposition's amendment-I suppose it assumes that this argument was dealt with yesterday-I point out that a family with dependent children and with an income just above the family assistance supplement level does not receive a very large income. We know that taxpayers earning $25,000, with the appropriate number of dependent children for comparison purposes, have suffered a loss since 1984 of 12 per cent in disposable income alone, and we can add to that the further depressed living standards they are suffering because of the amounts they now have to pay to meet their mortgage obligations and because of the increase in direct taxation that is being imposed on them.

SPEECH.PARA: The Bills we are considering further extend sales tax to certain food items-items which are very popular amongst children. Unless the Government takes stock of what it is doing to the family, it will definitely suffer a defeat at the next election, and it deserves to suffer that defeat if it does not take stock of the damage it is doing to the economic and social stability of Australian families.

Because of the limitation of time, I turn to the Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 5) 1988. I want to deal with that Bill very briefly by translating it into a practical example of the effect of this Government's actions. I want to deal with the effect that this action could well have on an industry in Beaconsfield in northern Tasmania, where there is quite high unemployment.

Beautiful Beaconsfield, as it is justifiably called, is a very desirable place to live and it is very different from the areas of most goldmines in Western Australia, which are situated in most inhospitable areas. But not so Beaconsfield. There is an extremely high unemployment rate in Beaconsfield and an attempt is being made by Beaconsfield Goldmines Ltd, a company which was formed solely for the purpose of raising funds to develop an old Tasmanian mine. We are not talking about billionaires here; we are talking about a company which has about 2,300 small shareholders in Tasmania alone. People are prepared to risk their capital to see whether this mine could be opened. The mine was quite profitable but it was closed early this century. Although the pumps were probably the most efficient pumps in the world at that time they were not able to keep the water out of the mine, so it became flooded.

Money is being spent on re-establishing the collar at the old shaft and an attempt will be made to dewater the shaft. I went down there yesterday and had a look at it. A very good job is being done. There are steel girders and cement all the way down the shaft to the 74-metre mark. The people doing this work have cleaned out the mine down to the 74-metre mark and they have to get through the cave in down to the 92-metre mark before there is a clear go to the 1,500-metre mark. I say `a clear go to the 1,500-metre mark' because while it appears to be clear of rubble, and cave in soil from the 92-metre to the 1,500-metre level, the shaft is still full of water. The company is spending $2,000 a day just to pump the water out. The engineers and geologists on the site are proposing to adopt a new method of damming the water by boring holes into the ground and using a grouting method to keep back the water from the actual mine. It is a very interesting process and they have high hopes.

There is wealth in that ground not only for that area of Tasmania but also for the whole of Australia, but the Government is changing the ground rules. These people committed funds on the basis that a tax would not be imposed on the company. I am not going over old ground; it has already been said that the goldmining industry is not free from tax; far from it. I am just talking about a very small operation which would be of great benefit not only for that area but for the whole of Australia. I say that it will benefit that area because at present only 20 or 30 jobs are involved as people are trying to clear out the shaft, but those jobs are still important in the Beaconsfield area at present. But when construction takes place 140 jobs, or thereabouts, will be involved and, when the mine is in full time production there will be about 100 full time jobs, which will be very significant for the Beaconsfield area.

TALK.START.PARA: —What does that do to small business?

—The Government, through this measure, is damping incentive for small business and quashing any hope that the people may have had of some return for their investment. About $10m has been sunk down that mine over recent years. When the company comes to the second stage of dewatering the shaft and confirming the estimates of the ore body, that will cost, say, another $20m and it will require a further commitment which the company has not yet received from the shareholders; it will ask for some more. I ask honourable senators to put themselves in the shoes of a small shareholder. Would they be game to put in the extra $2,000, $5,000 or $10,000 when the ground rules have been changed? I think it is important for the public to be reminded that the ground rules have been changed; that there has been a breaking of a clear pledge by this Government which it gave prior to the last election.

SPEECH.PARA: I have in my hand a copy of an advertisement in the Australian newspaper of 10 July 1987-a letter from the Prime Minister, Mr Bob Hawke, to the Executive Director of the Australian Goldmining Industry Council-which states:
Dear Mr Bell-
that is the Executive Director's name-

I understand that there appears to be an element of uncertainty among members of the Australian Goldmining Industry Council about the Government's intention concerning the tax exemption for goldmining income, despite my public statements on the matter.
Here it is-the Prime Minister, speaking prior to the last election-
You have my undertaking we will not introduce a gold tax during the next three year term of the Labor Government.

Anybody reading that advertisement would have immediately assumed that it meant that no gold tax would be introduced into the Parliament. The Government is getting around it by saying that it will not come into effect until 1 January 1991. That is a subterfuge; that is a ruse. It dashes the hopes of the people who have expended their money in this area. I appeal to this Government: I am giving a practical example of small shareholders who are likely to have lost their money down that shaft. They committed that money when the rules were quite firm and fixed, after the Government had made its decision and given its electoral promise and undertaking. I will use the words of the Prime Minister:
You have my undertaking we will not introduce a gold tax during the next three year term of the Labor Government.

TALK.START.PARA: —He didn't say that he wouldn't legislate for one.

—No. Now we have one. I remind the Senate of the effect that has on confidence amongst small investors. Do honourable senators recall what the Australian Democrats promised us? Do they remember Don Chipp's promise? `We will keep the bastards honest': that is what he said. In this legislation, an undertaking, an election promise, properly and generally understood by the whole community, is being broken. Are the Democrats going to keep the Government honest? The words used were not my words. They were the words of Don Chipp. Of course, I would not use such words about the Government; I have more respect. But those were the words of Don Chipp. Will the Democrats keep the Government honest? No; they impute motives to people for opposing the Government's taxation measures. Senator Haines said that the Liberal Party of Australia had sold out for a few lousy ounces of gold. She said:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . the simple fact is that . . . the Liberal Party has, with the Western Australian election coming up, been bought not for 30 pieces of silver but for a few lousy ounces of gold.

That was very smart. The Liberals can speak for themselves. I do not want to speak for them, and they do not want me to speak for them. But I think that is an insult to small shareholders, many of whom are workers of the small goldmine in Beaconsfield. I will vote against this measure because I believe that the Government has failed to uphold its quite definite election promise.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Knowles Sen S.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —We are debating the Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 5) 1988. I, like many of my colleagues, wish to address one particular point in the Bill that very much affects the well-being of my State of Western Australia. This final piece of taxation legislation for 1988 has one highly significant feature for my State and for Australia's future export earnings. The Bill will impose a corporate tax on gold in 1991, as the Treasurer (Mr Keating) foreshadowed last May. We have just heard Senator Harradine quite correctly talking about disposable promises of the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke). It is very much for that reason, but also for our fundamental philosophic reasons, that we in the Opposition are opposing such a measure.

SPEECH.PARA: How convenient it is that this measure is being pushed through Parliament before a detailed study commissioned by the Association of Mining and Exploration Companies Inc. in Western Australia can be completed and made available for public debate. What has the Government to fear in waiting for that study to be completed and debated? Why is there a need to rush this measure through the Parliament now when the Government proposes that it come into effect in 1991?

We are debating a Bill the undoubted effect of which will be to damage Australia's third greatest export industry after coal and wool, and at a time when one of our greatest continuing economic problems is the current account deficit, which is $12 billion in 1987-88. This means that Australia's ratio of foreign debt as a proportion of gross domestic product (GDP) is now 42 per cent. That is a rather sick figure when it is compared with figures of 27 per cent for Great Britain, 12 per cent for the United States of America and 7 per cent for Japan. This Hawke Labor Government has all but abandoned its Budget prediction that the 1988-89 deficit will be $9.5 billion. The first four months of 1988-89 have already produced an accumulated deficit of $5.5 billion-larger by $800m than for the same period last year.

The gold industry is one of the major economic success stories of the decade, with strong investment growth and export performance. It is a great tragedy that this Government has seen fit to try to ruin such a viable industry. This is an industry which in 1978 produced 17 tonnes of gold, which this year will have produced 140 tonnes of gold and which next year will produce 170 tonnes. The value of gold production has risen from less than $300m a decade ago to $2.25 billion in 1988. That is some increase.

What disturbs me about this proposal is that we will see the industry decline. One can forget that the gold industry is instrumental to the survival of a number of remote communities in Western Australia that produces 71 per cent of Australia's gold. I, however, choose not to forget that. Not only are those people my constituents, but also they provide great economic viability for this entire country, not just for my State of Western Australia. The bottom line surely is that $2.25 billion of export earnings are essential to Australia as a nation. Second to this, but of real importance, is the fact that not only is the gold industry responsible for 4,200 direct jobs in production and exploration but also its multiplier effect on employment in associated labour intensive industries has created some 41,000 jobs, all of which return income tax revenue to the Government. Company tax is paid by those firms which supply the gold industry.

So it is an absolute and utter fallacy for this Government to say that the gold industry is tax exempt. The gold industry is paying tax at every other level. Surely we as a nation should be looking more to reducing taxes instead of imposing them. Each additional $1m invested in goldmining results in an increase of $1.7m in national income, and each additional $1m in gold exports increases Australia's GDP by $1.9m, with a $3.3m rise in gross output.

Senator Walsh and other members of this Labor Government seize upon the mantle of economic rationalism as a justification for the corporate taxation of gold production, yet, to my mind, the essential task of a responsible government committed to economically rational goals is to maximise Australia's export income and maintain its revenue base without the creation of new taxes. It is not, therefore, prudent fiscal management for a government, using the excuse of consistency in taxation-that false excuse of consistency-to sacrifice $2 in direct revenue for each $1 gained through the new corporate tax on gold.

An examination of 51 major goldmining and exploration companies by Ernst and Whinney has indicated that, had a corporate tax on goldmining profits been in place from 1 March this year, the Government would have gained $363m in current and future revenue. However, by not imposing such a tax, the Government would gain current and future revenue to the tune of $807m. That is quite a difference, but it seems to matter not to this Labor Government. Quite apart from the 51 major companies that the gold index used for this exercise, the impact of the tax on 400 other companies would have an additional adverse effect on Government revenue. All too often this Government has sought to justify its decision by disinformation. Senator Walsh, of course, is a very clever master of that. He has adopted the tactic of labelling Western Australian gold producers as tax cheats and spivs, and he does not bother to check his facts. So far he has falsely accused one individual of having served a prison sentence. That does not matter to him. He does not care what he says to or about people. He has also claimed that 35 per cent of gold production is under foreign ownership. I suggest that Senator Walsh update his figures a bit because his figures on foreign ownership are in fact two years out of date. Only 18 per cent of the industry is foreign owned.

What is very distressing about this is that Senator Walsh happens to be a Western Australian senator which I think he conveniently forgot a long time ago, as did the Minister for Resources (Senator Cook) who has tried to float a line that because new mines are starting production this year, it somehow indicates that the proposed corporate tax will do the gold industry no harm. Parading such an argument adds insult to injury, particularly when it comes from a Western Australian senator. Senator Cook's list of 30 supposedly new mines names two mines in the wrong States. For the benefit of Senator Cook and his learning process Union Reefs and Doughboy Creek are not in Western Australia. One is in the Northern Territory and the other in Queensland. Neither is producing. And he claims to be a senator from Western Australia.

TALK.START.PARA: —Not to mention the Minister for Resources.

—Quite right, Senator Boswell, not to mention the Minister for Resources. They are two handles to his name that one would think would qualify him to talk with some knowledge on the subject. Another supposedly new mine at Mount Gibson is simply a deeper lode of an existing operation and another at Mullagine is a two-man tailings plant.

SPEECH.PARA: More significantly, Senator Cook did not mention that other mines on his list such as Forrest Belle near Menzies have only small desposits that will be mined out in a matter of months. The basic fallacy of Senator Cook's argument is that the short term production increases that will undoubtedly occur do not signal any kind of long term or medium term prosperity for the industry. It is in fact part of a process created by this Government that is wasting the future prospects of the gold industry. We, as a nation, cannot afford to see all of those opportunities being thrown out the window. It is elementary economic sense for gold producers to maximise, and in many cases, finalise production ahead of 1991. Obviously, the Government could not give a continental about that prospect because by then it will not be in government. It has a problem but it does not care; it just wants all of this in place.

It is also equally interesting-my colleague Senator Panizza mentioned this a little while ago-that the honourable member for Kalgoorlie, Mr Graeme Campbell, pragmatically crossed the floor when the vote on this Bill was taken in the House of Representatives. There was nothing clever or brave in his actions. He simply saw where he could get his votes and where he could lose them at the next election. He chose to go against Caucus and cross the floor. Normally that type of action means expulsion for a member of the Labor Party. But, oh no, not this time, all he got was a hit across the back of the hand with a feather. He was prevented from going to Caucus for three months, most of which time the Parliament is not sitting and Caucus will not be meeting. So what was brave about Mr Campbell's position? Absolutely nothing at all.

I also add that there are five honourable senators in this place from the Labor Party who supposedly represent Western Australia-Senators Walsh, Cook, McKiernan, Beahan and Giles. I have not heard one iota from any one of them who might even be thinking of voting to oppose this piece of legislation. Oh no! That would be taking it one step too far. Then of course we have Senator Jenkins of the Australian Democrats from Western Australia. What is her position? She does not care too much about the industry in Western Australia. She does not care too much about her constituents who will be very adversely affected by this decision.

Then of course we have Senator Vallentine-the senator for staying away from Parliament. It will be interesting to see where Senator Vallentine is when the vote is taken on this because she is generally not here. If she is in the building she only comes in to be seen and then goes out again. She has no interest in this. She has no interest in the economic viability of this whole proposition and no interest in the constituents that it affects. We have seven senators out of 12 who will vote in favor of this dreadful course of action to be taken in 1991. Only the five Liberal senators from Western Australia will be opposing this.

In its tortuous method of paying lip service to yet another disposable election promise, this Labor Government has created a huge disincentive for development after 1991 so that it can claim, as Senator Harradine pointed out earlier, that it did not introduce a gold tax in the lifetime of the Thirty-fifth Parliament; it merely legislated for one. I was in Kalgoorlie during the last election campaign on the day the Prime Minister announced that there would be no gold tax. I think Senator Panizza was with me on that particular day. The people of Kalgoorlie were ecstatic but I must admit that they were also very wary, but obviously not wary enough to vote against what was blatantly untrue and what we now see as completely untrue. It was purely and simply a decision that the Prime Minister made on that day when he happened to be swanning around Perth at some stage. He decided that he would announce that there would be no gold tax. What has that meant? It means absolutely nothing.

The increased production of which Senator Cook boasts will concentrate increasingly on the highest grades of ore so that low grade deposits will become totally uneconomic after 1991, not only through the imposition of corporate tax but also because lodes of high grade ore will have been mined. The availability of higher grade deposits has, in the past, made economic the development of lower grades. But that will all be wiped out. The Western Mining Corporation's three million tonne stockpile of low grade ore accumulating at 100,000 tonnes per month will be worthless unless it is processed before 1991. It has been estimated that in Western Australia some 30 million tonnes of low grade ore that a corporate tax will render uneconomic could yield more than one million ounces of gold. Once again, the Government does not seem to care that there is a future in that low grade ore. It simply does not want to know about it because this is a disincentive that will be in place at a time when all the high grade mining has been completed.

I defy this Government or any honourable senator voting for this tax to deny that it will shorten the lives of mines and discourage the development of deep mines that require a longer lead time than open cut operations. Equally, it defies credibility to argue that many of the mines currently in production or about to commence production would have come on stream if a corporate tax had been operating in recent years. It is most unlikely that gold production in the eastern States would have been commercially feasible except with the present incentive based tax regime. Those two words-incentive based-are very important because that is what we have seen in this industry for a long time. That incentive will now be removed as of 1991. We will see the demise of the gold industry just as we have seen it grow in recent years.

The classic example of the real state of the goldmining industry was the opening last month in Kalgoorlie of the Wombola goldmine. This deposit of low grade ore is being fast tracked by Croesus Mining using profits of $7m obtained from its predecessor, the Hannans South Pit. Wombola is being started up only because a corporate tax does not yet apply. From 1991 the whole world will be different because such a mine will not be an economic possibility. The company can only hope to discover a reserve with sufficient potential to withstand the taxation impost. Within two years this company has expanded from 320 to 5,035 shareholders. No doubt Senator Walsh would call them spivs too. He likes name-calling. As I said, he does not care much about what he calls people-whether it is accurate or not. The Wombola mine is typical of enterprise in the goldmining industry and it underscores the fact that mines will not operate unless they can make a profit. The profit margins of smaller companies will be wiped out by this tax change.

As I mentioned earlier, a study is under way to determine the actual and projected effects of the 1991 tax on gold production and its associated industries in Western Australia. While this may not be completed before the new year, there is already mounting evidence of the adverse effects of the new tax. It may be a very wise question to ask, but what has the Government got to fear in waiting for that report on the industry? Why is it rushing into it? Why does it not want to know the facts behind the industry as they are today and not what the Government knew them to be quite some time ago? It is simply a case of putting the blinkers on and hoping for the best. Already members of the Association of Mining and Exploration Companies have reported that seven gold deposits in Western Australia are on ice because corporate taxation would wipe out profit from the development of a marginal deposit. Obviously, capital raising after 1991 will be drastically curtailed. Up to the pre-sent some 90 per cent of mineral search in Australia has been for new gold deposits. Small wonder, therefore, that the exploration industry is already severely affected by the 1991 tax. At a conservative estimate there has been a 50 per cent fall-off in exploration over the past year. That is according to the Kalgoorlie Chairman of the Drilling Industry Association, Dr Brian Mann. Once again, Senator Walsh and Senator Cook would dispute that. They would say that that is something Senator Knowles has plucked out of the air, but it happens to be fact, a fact that this Government should not and could not deny, but of course it will.

A casual visitor to Kalgoorlie today will certainly notice the number of drilling rigs lying idle. That is another source of concern. Although there has been an increase in exploration in the immediate proximity of proven ore bodies, pure exploration has been savagely curtailed. Exploration budgets for 1988-89 have in many cases been spent before the end of October, a classic indication that the 1991 tax has already destroyed the long term prospects of the industry. It does not say much for the current health of the drilling industry that an operator recently informed a mining tenement owner near Geraldton that he would happily leave the rig there ready for subsequent work two or three months away. Last year it would have been unheard of for equipment to lie idle in this manner and for such a long time. But that is the effect this proposal is having on the industry now. Again, it is significant to learn that the air charter industry in Kalgoorlie reports an 80 per cent decline in the business of servicing exploration companies. All these indicators prove one thing, namely, that the industry already is going down even though it is fighting the tax and is extremely busy trying to get the high grade ore out. We have to ensure that we know and understand the ramifications of this proposition.

The Opposition is not, as the Government would have us believe, pleading a special tax privilege for the gold industry. We are not just making a decision on the run; we have always been committed to opposing a gold tax. It is not a decision that was made in the last few weeks or since May when the Treasurer announced this gold tax for 1991. We have always been opposed to it. It concerns me sometimes that even parts of the industry do not understand that we have always been opposed to it. There is no future in trying to penalise an industry in such a fashion.

Since 1924 the industry has been exempt from only corporate taxation in recognition of the fact that goldmining relies on its profits to pay its expenses in a relatively short term, given the generally short lives of individual mines. That pinpoints one of the major differences. These mines are very different from many other mines. They are not the same and they should not be treated in the same fashion. As the dividends from goldmining companies cannot be franked, they are fully taxable in the hands of shareholders, who are also liable for capital gains tax when the shares are sold. Once again, it is a fallacy for this Government to say that the industry and all those associated with it are exempt from tax. They simply are not. It is probably too much to expect from this Labor Government that it consider extending tax incentives to other forms of mineral production, rather than seeking to end a supposed anomaly. Why cannot tax incentives be extended to other industries?

TALK.START.PARA: —They tax kids' ice-creams. They will not give any concessions.

—Quite right. The Government will tax anything-anything that moves and in fact a lot of things that do not. Altogether in 1986-87, the three levels of government between them took 58 per cent of the operating profit of the mining industry. Again, that is not something we have manufactured. It is not a figure that is just plucked out of the air. It is a figure that has been certified by the Chief Executive of the Chamber of Mines in Western Australia, Mr Peter Ellery. The industry was left with a 6.5 per cent return on its investment. Yet this Government says it needs to be taxed more. It already has three levels of government chomping away at its heels. Why does it need more? This is the broad picture that this Labor Government chooses to ignore. It simply does not want to know about it. I appeal to the Australian Democrats-I suppose that is a bit futile-and to Labor senators particularly from Western Australia, to have regard for the undoubted consequences of this tax on employment in regional centres and remote communities, and, of course, on Australia's export income after 1991.

SPEECH.PARA: Opposition senators interjecting-

TALK.START.PARA: —I support gold companies paying their fair share of tax.

—I just heard Senator McKiernan say that he supports this tax on gold. Senator McKiernan is from Western Australia and he is meant to be representing the whole of Western Australia, yet he is in favour of this proposal. I honestly cannot understand that Senator McKiernan would be wanting to see such a viable and important industry to Western Australia and to Australia be penalised in such a fashion. I appeal to the Democrats and to the Western Australian Labor senators to do what the honourable member for Kalgoorlie did. If they think that that was not a pragmatic exercise, and if they think that Mr Campbell did that because that is what he really felt and not just to win a few votes, why do they not follow his lead? It is absolutely amazing.
—What has the Western Australian State Government done?

—Yes. The Labor State Government is opposed to the introduction of a gold tax, yet the Labor senators are giving their own State Government the flick. And so they should because everyone else will in a couple of months. But they do not have the courage to do what Mr Campbell did. That accounts for five votes out of it. Then we have Senator Jenkins which is another vote out of it. Then we have Senator Vallentine who is probably shooing ships away on some wharf at the moment. That is the only thing she is good at doing. Heaven knows what Senator Dunn will do. The first week she was in the place she took off all around Australia shooing ships away as well. It is such a tragedy that people in the Senate who supposedly represent the State of Western Australia care not about the future of that State. I reiterate: it is not just a parochial argument that I am putting forward here in the Senate today. While I feel very strongly about this on behalf of Western Australia I feel equally strongly about the future of Australia and the viability of this industry in Australia.
