SPEECH.PARA: It is a gross misuse of the principle of equity and rationalism to foreshadow a tax that, through both the manner of its introduction and its eventual effect, will drastically curtail an efficient and successful export industry. We need all the export industries we can possibly get at the moment without chopping their legs off. That is what this tax will do: it will chop the legs off the industry and its employees right across the nation.

TALK.START.PARA: —How many Labor senators have spoken?

—Senator Boswell has raised a very interesting question. I have last night's speakers list beside me, and today's, and I cannot find one. I am glad Senator Boswell raised that very interesting question. Let the devotees of a gold tax wait until the next election and convince the Australian electorate that this tax will somehow enhance our national well-being. It will not enhance our national well-being. It cannot do so. That is why I make a final plea to Labor senators from Western Australia, and to Senator Jenkins and Senator Vallentine-wherever she happens to be listening on the air waves-to vote against this dreadful taxation that will harm an industry. We in the Opposition will fight it tooth and nail and we will fight it right to the wire.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McKiernan Sen J.P.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise very briefly to answer the challenge laid down by my Opposition colleagues about the silence from Western Australian senators on this single aspect of a number of Bills before the chamber. It will not take me very long to put my cards on the table and to inform the Senate and, therefore, the public of Western Australia and indeed Australia of where I, as a senator representing Western Australia, stand on this issue of the wrongly named-it has been quoted wrongly throughout this debate-gold tax. It is not a gold tax. It is bringing the goldmining industry into line with every other industry in this country. It is bringing the goldmining industry into line with what other miners have to pay.

SPEECH.PARA: I have no problem in standing up in the Senate, representing the people of Western Australia, and making it clear that I support what the Government is doing in this legislation. On a number of occasions over the years I have supported the view that the goldmining industry ought to pay its fair share of taxes, in the same way as bauxite miners and iron ore miners do. It ought to pay its fair share of taxes in the same way as those who work for the goldmining industry do. No exemptions are granted to the workers in the goldmining industry, nor should there be to the profit takers from that industry. The challenge has been put out and it has been answered. It has taken me just over two minutes to do so. I regret delaying the Senate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brownhill Sen D.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —Dear oh dear, it is not often that one can stand up and speak after a senator from Western Australia who has sold one of his major industries in Western Australia down the drain. It does him no credit to do so. I have always had a bit of time for Senator McKiernan because, as the Government's Deputy Whip, he is sometimes helpful to all members of the Parliament. It really makes me wonder, having heard his speech and heard him sell his own State down the mine. He is one of 12 senators from Western Australia. He has been elected to represent his State, which is producing that wonderful export income. I just cannot understand it. The main crunch of the Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 5) is that, in accordance with the 1988 May economic statement, it will remove the current exemption from taxation of income from goldmining. This will be subject to certain phasing in arrangements. The Bill specifies that from 1 January 1989 the current conditions of exemption will be terminated. Shame on Senator McKiernan for being a part of that.

SPEECH.PARA: After recent visits to goldmining areas in New South Wales and Western Australia-both small and large mines-I am well aware of the impact the imposition of such a tax would have on a most buoyant industry. It is not just the mining companies themselves that will suffer. All the associated industries-some 1,500 of them-in cities such as Sydney, Brisbane and Melbourne and, I might add, in very marginal Labor seats-will also suffer. Let us wait and see what happens at the next election as a result of the Government's foreshadowed gold tax impost. It will have far-reaching implications for the Government-not just in places such as Kambalda and the other major mining towns of Australia but all over Australia in areas where people are associated with the industry. For instance, the people who produce the drills in Brisbane, the people who produce the diamond drills in Sydney, the people who produce the chemicals used in the industry will suffer dramatic cutbacks as a result of the introduction of this tax. Senator Harradine, in a most eloquent speech today, mentioned the shareholders. They too will be affected because the mining companies will no longer be viable.

It has been suggested that something like $1 gained in tax will lose the country $2 in export income, or $2 in earnings for the mining companies. We will not break our commitment to oppose the gold tax. The Opposition has been very firm on this right from the start. In June 1987 the Leader of the Opposition, Mr Howard, said:
We are totally opposed to the introduction of a gold tax.
We are standing firm. He continued:
A gold tax would jeopardise the future of many existing mines and prevent the opening of new ones. Exploration and the level of investment in this important sector would also decline rapidly.

The Government has acted differently. It has made it known, through the introduction of the Bill, that it condones a gold tax. It is interesting to note than on 7 July 1987 our Prime Minister, Mr Hawke, gave the public an undertaking that he would not introduce a gold tax during the next three-year term of a Labor government. That was another broken promise. It makes one wonder when the broken promises will finish. That is another example of why this Government has earned a reputation as the highest taxing government in Australia's history. I seek leave to incorporate in Hansard a letter to Mr Carmichael from Senator Button dated 23 July 1987.
Leave granted.
The letter read as follows-
MINISTER FOR INDUSTRY,
TECHNOLOGY AND COMMERCE
PARLIAMENT HOUSE
CANBERRA, A.C.T. 2600
23 July 1987
Dear Mr Carmichael
I am writing to you about the matter of a gold tax which I understand has come up in the context of your consideration of the coverage of the Jewellery reference.
In developing the reference it was not my intention to have the Commission re-open the question of introducing a gold tax.

This issue was considered by the Government following the August 1986 ``Gutman'' report on the taxation of gold mining. In response to that report, the Government decided not to introduce a gold tax because the importance of encouraging exploration and development, and of maximising production and the consequent export income generated by the gold mining industry, outweighed the arguments in favour of removing the industry's long-standing tax exemption.

In a letter dated 7 July 1987 to Mr Duncan Bell, Chairman of the Australian Goldmining Industry Council, the Prime Minister gave an undertaking that the Government would not introduce a gold tax during its third term of office. A copy of the letter is attached.
In view of the Government's commitment to the industry, I consider it would be inappropriate for the Commission to examine the taxation of gold mining in the context of this reference.
Yours sincerely
JOHN N. BUTTON
Mr W. Carmichael
Chairman
Industries Assistance Commission
P.O. Box 80
Belconnen A.C.T. 2616

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Senate. As I have said, the Government has a working reputation of being the highest taxing government in Australia's history. In July 1983, four months after this Government was elected, it introduced a tax on lump sum superannuation. The next month, in its first Budget, Treasurer Keating introduced new excise taxes on fuel, beer and cigarettes. For good measure, he also threw in an assets test on pensioners. In December 1983, the Government cut the tax exemption for Army reservists by 50 per cent. In February 1984 it introduced a Medicare levy-a health tax. In July 1984, it introduced a resource rent tax. That will come back to haunt the Australian people in terms of oil exploration. In August 1984, wine sales tax and fuel excise tax were increased. In June 1985, in the face of a blow-out in the deficit, Treasurer Keating unveiled his great tax White Paper with much fanfare. Who can remember the details three years later? There were promises of major tax changes to spread the burden more equitably. In September 1985 the new Keating package was unveiled with the introduction of capital gains taxes and the disallowance of entertainment expenses. In May 1986 the fringe benefits tax legislation was introduced into Parliament and this has really hit the the mining industries in isolated areas. In July 1986 the corporate tax rate was increased from 46c to 49c. The famous tax arm of the trilogy was broken in the fourth Labor Budget in August 1986. The Medicare levy was increased and fuel excise went up a further 3c a litre-a 300 per cent increase in excise in three years under a Labor Government.

SPEECH.PARA: I am bringing these facts to the attention of the Senate today because they demonstrate the fact that extra taxes and imposts have been put on the Australian community-in this particular case, they have been put on a productive industry. The promised tax cuts announced two years ago have been deferred. Bracket creep is knocking the heck out of average taxpayers. Senator McKiernan, when he goes back to Western Australia, must not forget to tell his people about the promised tax cut which will come in in July next year. This promised tax cut will mean that every average wage earner with two dependent children will have to be given $56 a week extra. Let us wait to see what happens. Let us see whether the Australian people are given the promised tax cuts next year or whether this will be another broken promise. Let us see whether the tax cuts will restore the average wage earner's weekly take home pay to its comparative level in 1983.

Senator McKiernan has given a good argument about why he wants to tax his people in Western Australia out of existence. But such arguments are often based on the reasoning that if other industries pay tax, why should the gold companies not have to pay up? Such questions are based on a very broad misunderstanding of how the system really works. Senator McKiernan has probably been down mines more than anyone in this building. I think it would be a good idea if he went down again, because if he did he would learn a bit about what goes on. The gold industry is not totally exempt from tax. All the usual taxes are paid, except corporate tax. Shareholders pay full income tax on dividends arising out of goldmining profits. Other companies which pay corporate tax are able to pass on an imputation credit to shareholders who receive a corresponding credit against their income tax liability.

The integration method of taxation which is currently applied to the goldmining industry has the advantage-I am sorry to see that Senator McKiernan has left the chamber-that the undistributed profits are not taxed in the first instance. They are invariably applied towards further development and investment. More funds are therefore available from the internal company resources for the vital purposes of expanding an industry, putting money back from whence it has come. As we all know, encouragement of more investment in productive activities is absolutely essential for the future of Australia. Sometimes I wonder, sitting on this side of the chamber, whether the Government side has much interest in the productive resources of Australia. I have often made the point in this place that the Government is always slamming the people of rural Australia and not taking any interest in those vital export industries which give us all a decent standard of living.

When discussing this Bill, we must remember that without the existing positive tax regime the Australian goldmining industry would not have expanded to the extent to which it evidently has during the 1980s. It is well for everyone to know that for 40 years, from 1933 to 1972, government policy led to the price of gold being fixed. It is difficult to imagine what effect such a freeze would have on any other industry. What loss of income did the industry suffer in those years because the price for gold was fixed? I think that is very hard for us all to comprehend. The industry did not rip the Australian people off at that stage and it is not ripping them off now.

If a gold tax is introduced, the long term goldmining industry will be seriously jeopardised. Not only will new projects not proceed, but also the tax will result in the serious reduction of the life of many existing operations. In simple terms, it will take the icing off the cake. In fact, it will do more than that; it will destroy the cake itself. The industry now mines deep deposits and this is a costly operation. In addition to the much higher capital cost of mine development as a result of both underground mining and the treatment of the sulphide ores with the new mining techniques now in operation, the companies have to provide all the infrastructure of power, water, roads, housing and airstrips. They also sometimes provide schools and medical services.

If this industry is to continue in future, there will be higher capital costs. When the incentive is taken away, those companies will move offshore and that is not going to be good for Australia. Marginal mines will close and investment will stop. If that is being done by a government which says it has the interests of the Australian people at heart, I think that government stands damned. It is attempting to bleed yet another essential resource based industry.

The goldmining industry is not asking to be privileged through not paying tax. It is only arguing that the present system applying to goldmining, which encourages facilities to reinvest part of the profits in the industry, is in Australia's interests. It is in Australia's interests to expand this system. Therefore, the same encouragement for investment should be provided to all Australian industries. Sir Arvi Parbo, the head of some major companies and probably the greatest Australian at the moment, has suggested that incentive should be given not only to the goldmining industry, but to some of the other export oriented industries which produce wealth for our country.

I strongly urge the Senate to take note of the concerns of the gold industry and heed the warnings about the possible outcome of the imposition of a gold tax in Australia. Some of the smaller mines will suffer greater damage than the larger ones. If this tax is introduced, there will be a quick mining of the marginal deposits, leaving considerable amounts still in the ground never to be mined. This tax, which Senator McKiernan said was a good thing for his State of Western Australia, is basically retrospective in that mines do not just spring up overnight. Every goldmine in Australia probably has an eight-year lead time. It is a retrospective tax because some of the people who started goldmining some six or seven years ago will now be hit with all the disadvantages of having a tax placed on their produce.

At a time when our foreign debt is $120 billion and we have just had our worst ever monthly trade deficit, the Government wants to cut the legs out from under our gold exporting industry, which in 1987-88 earned our country $2.56 billion in export income. The present round of the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade (GATT) demonstrates this Government's total lack of appreciation of the importance of our export based industries. We will have more to say about the GATT round in the next few days. The gold industry is a contributor to our export income; the third most important contributor behind wool and coal. This Government stands condemned for jeopardising yet another export industry by the mooted introduction of a tax on goldmining.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sheil Sen G.

TALK.START.PARA: —At this very moment there is an exhibition of Irish gold touring Australia. It is a gift from the Irish people to Australia for our Bicentennial. One of the items in that gold exhibition is a lunula that was crafted in 1800 BC. At the moment there is also an exhibition of Macedonian gold and treasures showing in Melbourne. These things are priceless and irreplaceable and are evidence of the romantic history of gold, which is the history of the modern era. It is a romance that has been associated with wars and piracy. Men have even drowned because they would not take off their gold belts. It is a history of glory and perfidy and broken promises. This proposed gold industry tax also has a history of perfidy and broken promises.

SPEECH.PARA: For a long time I have been trying to find out just what is the value of an ounce of gold. Nobody seems to know. I have made extensive inquiries. It is no good saying that the price of gold can be measured only in American dollars, deutschmarks or Swiss francs, because those currencies fluctuate. But I think the value of gold does not alter and probably has not altered since it was first discovered. When the world moved onto the gold standard an ounce of gold was worth so much coal, so much steel, so much wheat and so much of many other commodities in order to give it a value. The amount of paper we have to pay for an ounce of gold fluctuates and can rarely be said to be the value of an ounce of gold. For example, when dictators finally bring their countries to ruin and have to flee they do not take the paper money; they take the gold or the pearls or the diamonds or the paintings, or something that has value. It is not the paper that is of value; it is the gold itself. At one stage the United States fixed the price of gold at $34 an ounce for many years. That was hailed as a great move to stabilise currencies in the world. It disadvantaged all the gold-producing countries in the world, one of which was Australia. For 30-odd years Australia might have got a lot more money for its gold than $34 an ounce. It was one of the most massive rip-offs in history.

There is a quintessential conundrum that has been exercising the minds of men for years; that is: who commits the greater crime, the man who robs a bank or the man who opens a bank? That conundrum has not yet been answered. There is an old fable that I would like to draw to the mind of the Government relating to the introduction of this gold industry tax. That is the fable of the man who killed the golden goose. That is precisely what the Government is doing with this tax. I was raised on a goldmine. I have worked underground. I have heard the cracks, screams and groans of rocks as they take up their sheer forces. I know that the underground mining people live with a fearsome threat over them all the time, as do their families. Occasionally terrible accidents happen, but they accept this as part of their life. They do everything they can to avoid tragedies occurring but it is a different and a hard life. Miners have to live where the lode is. They cannot live in cities by choice; gold is where they find it.

Even with all modern science, there is still no magic formula for finding gold; one has to get out and find it where one can. Mining men have been the front-row men in the development of any country. So it has been in Australia. We have a history of giving incentives for goldmining people to go out, because they have to face the harassment of distance, for a start, and the harassment of high costs for all the commodities that they require and the high costs of educating their children. They have to send their children away for education. They deserve the encouragement of a government and any incentive they can get. Most of these things have been taken off people. Now there is a threat of taxing the industry. There is an old adage that says, `Anything the Government wants less of, it taxes; anything it wants more of, it subsidises'. In this case it must want less gold because it is introducing a tax on gold.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Queensland Government taxes gold production directly. This is an extension of corporate taxation that all other companies pay. Why don't you ask the Queensland Government to remove its gold tax?

—It is nice the hear a socialist bring up his arguments about other governments and what they are doing. It has been the policy of our Government federally and in Opposition not to tax the gold industry. What other countries do and what other States do is no affair of ours. We are talking about the Federal Government now. I am surprised that in this debate we have seen Western Australian Labor senators supporting a tax on the industry. I might add that Queensland Labor senators are also supporting a tax on the gold industry. We have fledgling industries in Queensland that are trying to get off the ground but this tax is going to clip their wings. Why should the Government do this? I listened to the argument put forward by Senator McKiernan, but it is not a realistic one and it does not do justice to what the gold industry has been to Australia.

SPEECH.PARA: This has been a long debate. I will lend whatever support I can to the Opposition in its attempt to rid us of the proposition of a gold industry tax. I hope that people will take note of the fact that Labor senators in this place are supporting it. It is a retrospective tax and a regressive tax that we should not be faced with if we want to develop this country further.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bishop Sen B.K. .

TALK.START.PARA: —On this occasion I wish to speak on the Sales Tax (Exemptions and Classifications) Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1988. In so doing I draw attention to the fact that this Bill is before us because, when the Government drafted its original legislation following the introduction of the Budget, it was unable to express its intention as it wished to do. The original Sales Tax (Exemptions and Classifications) Bill 1988, which was introduced on 23 August 1988, appeared deliberately not to tax plastic bags which are used for the wrapping of bread, and for the taking away of fruit and vegetables and which are used in supermarkets and in other retail outlets for taking goods away generally. The deliberate omission of dealing with that material signalled a message to industry at large and retailers in general that those particular items would be exempt from the 20 per cent tax.

SPEECH.PARA: In introducing this amendment Bill in the other place the Minister for Industrial Relations (Mr Peter Morris), in his second reading speech, said that the Bill would ensure that goods used by retailers to wrap or secure goods for marketing are subject to tax at the rate of 20 per cent. It introduced a retrospective note. I note that my colleague Senator Michael Baume has foreshadowed an amendment which will be moved at the committee stage dealing specifically with this retrospective provision. The deliberate attempt by the Government to make this retrospective just highlights the ineptitude of it being unable correctly to draft its original legislation, which was, as I said, introduced on 23 August.

TALK.START.PARA: —Just the latest example of it.

—Indeed, it is the latest example of it, and there are plenty of others to draw upon. It shows that either the Government is inept at drafting legislation or it has changed its mind somewhere along the way. Either way, it turns out that the provision is retrospective and as such is unacceptable.

SPEECH.PARA: There are several other things that are relevant in this overall context, but there are some things which flow directly from the imposition of this 20 per cent tax specifically on the plastic bag item that I have mentioned. It does in fact represent a quasi-tax on food and clothing, which have traditionally been tax exempt. It does mean, for instance, that a loaf of bread will have this tax imposed upon it, because we buy our bread in plastic bags. Through the imposition of the tax on a plastic bag, we are therefore in effect paying a tax on a loaf of bread.

The same applies to children's clothing and other items which have traditionally been subject to the emotional debate about our broad-based consumption taxes which this Government has said that it is opposed to. In fact what we are getting is a tax on such items by the back door. Slowly but surely the body of sales taxes, indirect taxes, is being built up on more and more goods and we are seeing a de facto introduction of a consumption based tax without consumers knowing precisely how much is involved and, indeed, without having an opportunity of seeing just how great is the rate of growth of this collection of sales taxes.

As I said, the bags on which this tax is to be imposed are plastic bags used, for example, on a loaf of bread, the thin plastic bags used for taking fruit and vegetables from supermarkets, with which so many of us are familiar, the plastic bags that are used at the checkout counters in supermarkets, and of course, those used in other retail outlets as well. So the imposition of a tax on the plastic wrappings on all sorts of items which have been tax exempt has effectively meant that the goods are subject to a tax. Thereby of course, the legislation represents a considerable extra cost to the community and will impact on all retailers, whether large or small.

This brings to mind the general collection of sales tax, which has increased so greatly in the time that this Government has been in office. It is interesting to look at the published figures for the financial year 1986-87 dealing with the sale value of taxable goods included in returns by each class and business type. These figures show that in the year 1986-87 the total amount of sales was valued at approximately $33.2 billion, on which sales tax of $6.3 billion was collected. That means that we are paying an average of 20 per cent consumption tax, by whatever name one chooses to call it, on goods which are in fact taxable. When the argument about whether there should be a broad-based consumption tax has been entertained by various individuals, it has been on the basis that the rate of tax should be no larger than about 10 per cent. Yet the way in which this Government has implemented its growth of sales tax, which is about 147 per cent, has meant that we are paying an average of 19.14 per cent on all those classes of goods.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is a consumption tax you have when you are not having a consumption tax.

—It certainly is. I would not like to call it a Clayton's consumption tax, but I would like to call it a de facto consumption tax because that is what we are seeing. As has already been pointed out in this debate, sales tax collections in this current year represent 10.4 per cent of all taxes collected. This is a growth over the period of six years since this Government came to office from the 1982-83 financial year percentage of 8.5. Each year there has been an increase in the amount of sales tax collected by this Government.

SPEECH.PARA: We do seem to have a government which is obsessed with the collection of tax from whatever source it can get it and by whatever means. But the questions `What is tax collected for, where is the benefit to the community, and what is the purpose of raising the tax in terms of providing good government for the people' are not addressed by this Government. Since this Government came to office the total tax take has more than doubled. The last Fraser Government Budget had a tax take of about $40 billion. In this current year the tax take by this Government will be in excess of $80 billion. I ask the people whether they feel twice as well off. When I have gone into various parts of Sydney where families are struggling to make ends meet, I have not met anyone who has said, `I feel twice as well off because this Government is raking in twice the amount of tax'.

The reason I think this debate on sales tax has been highlighted by the Opposition is simply to alert the public to the fact that so much money is being paid by way of de facto consumption tax. While the Government says that it is not in favour of consumption taxes, it imposes them at a high and mighty rate. It is well for people to remember the figures. It is well to remember that of the 50 categories of business items on which sales tax is imposed-they include everything from motor cars to floor coverings, confectionery, stationery and other paper products, toys, games and novelties, jewellery, suitcases, photographs and cameras, musical instruments, canvas goods and ropes, and all manner of manufactured pet foods-every item affects the average family. But on those items we are all now paying nearly 20 per cent effective de facto consumption tax.

I think it is most important that Senator Michael Baume has foreshadowed the amendment which is aimed at getting rid of at least the retrospective part of this legislation. When we come to the committee stage I think more information will be laid before the Australian people so that they can realise how the Government is duping them; how it says, on the one hand, that it will not have a bar of a consumption tax, and how, on the other hand, it has introduced sales tax on so many items and that it will impinge even on the loaves of bread we buy. The hypocrisy will be laid for people to see.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crichton-Browne Sen N.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to speak to the Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 5) 1988, which gives effect to measures announced in the May economic statement and, in particular, which removes certain tax exemptions currently available to the goldmining industry. Before I present the arguments in opposition to this legislation and to the announcements, I will support my case by referring to the arguments, not in terms of their depth but in terms of their force, that are being put by the Western Australian Labor Government.

SPEECH.PARA: I bother to do that because I was in the chamber some weeks ago when Senator Walsh, the Minister for Finance, responded to a dorothy dix question from Senator Beahan-Labor, Western Australia-asking Senator Walsh about the tax on gold, a tax which Senator Cook continues to describe as a corporate tax. I can only assume that Senator Cook talks about it as a corporate tax because he has not read section 23 (pa) of the Income Tax Assessment Act. I recall that Senator Walsh in answering that question described those opposed to the legislation as `spivs who lounged around Perth'. I do not know whether the honourable senator was being selective in his description or whether it was all-embracing, but one is moved to observe that the Labor member for Kalgoorlie (Mr Campbell) subsequently spoke against the tax in the House of Representatives and crossed the floor against his Party, against his Caucus and against the legislation. I do not offer to Mr Campbell any altruistic motives. He had two choices: to confront his Caucus and risk censure and the unlikely but possible prospect of losing his endorsement, contrasted with the certainty of losing his seat. It was a question of losing his endorsement or losing his seat, and he knew that the prospect of losing his seat was far greater than the prospect of losing his endorsement.

So he made an expedient decision and voted against the Government. Do we judge him to be a spiv? Do we judge him to be a lazy layabout lounging about Perth? Or does he have some special dispensation? Has he got some exemption? Is he quarantined from the outrageous claims of Senator Walsh in respect of those who are opposed to the legislation?

The same might be asked of the Premier of Western Australia, who is desperately hanging on to the final threads of power. He is presently leading a failed Government about to be ignominiously dumped out of office in Western Australia in February next year. Is this man a spiv by definition? Is he a lazy person who lounges about Perth? It is worth noting his comments. In the State Parliament on 26 May this year Mr Dowding was highly critical of the Liberal Party. He said:

I am disappointed that the Liberal Party was not more supportive of the State Government and the goldmining industry's attack over the last five years on the attempt by the Federal Government to remove the exemption.
He was being critical of the Western Australian Liberal Opposition for not being more aggressive in opposing a gold tax. He described the debate as:
. . . a very serious and very important issue which the Leader of the Opposition should have had the strength of character to support fully, but he does not have that strength of character.
He was criticising the Liberal Party in Western Australia for not being more aggressive in its opposition. Mr Dowding was reported in the Australian Financial Review of 26 May 1988 to have said:
I believe it is a clear breach of faith with the Western Australian Government and the community and as far as I am concerned the fight is far from over.
He was talking about the May statement and the proposed tax on gold. He said that it was `a clear breach of faith'. In the West Australian of 16 May 1988 it was stated:
The Federal Government has enough revenue without seeking to raise a further $100m to $600m through a gold tax, according to the Premier, Mr Dowding.
`Federal revenues are up dramatically and I do not think there is a need to increase Federal revenues now', Mr Dowding said.
The gold industry was already paying a de facto income tax in the form of dividend imputation where shareholders in gold companies paid tax on their dividends.

As reported in the Daily News of 13 May, he said that the Western Australian Government maintained its opposition to any form of tax on gold. He was asked a question-a dorothy dixer no doubt-by Dr Gallop, one of his own backbenchers, in the Legislative Assembly of Western Australia. He asked the Premier:
Can the Premier restate the Government's position on gold tax? Can he say what support he might expect for the Government's stand on this matter?
The Premier, Mr Dowding, responded in these terms:

This Government is and has been at all material times opposed to the removal of the tax-exempt status of gold. In order to advance the situation in a constructive way I have asked the Minister for Agriculture to reform the gold policy committee and to ask it to report to the Deputy Premier and myself as soon as practicable on what steps can be taken in the face of the Federal Government's decision . . .

Those are the words of the Premier of Western Australia, Senator Cook's State colleague. He made similar statements on a number of other occasions, but I think the point has been made. What did Mr Grill say about Mr Campbell?

TALK.START.PARA: —I am sure you are going to tell us.
—I am sure the Minister knows, but let me tell those who do not know. This is what Mr Grill said of Mr Campbell:

SPEECH.PARA: It was a courageous decision that reflected the feelings of the vast majority of the people in his electorate.

Mr Grill said of Mr Campbell's being under the threat of the Caucus in the Australian Labor Party that he felt so intensely about this issue that he himself would resign from Parliament if Mr Campbell was disciplined.

TALK.START.PARA: —From the Party, I think.

—Yes, of course. Those comments show the strength of feeling, emotion and commitment of the opposition to a tax on gold. Would anybody suggest that those people are spivs? This is an example of selective abuse by Senator Walsh of those who disagree with him. His attitude is: when logic fails use foul language and abuse.

SPEECH.PARA: I return to the substance of the Bill. The amendments within it are to take effect from 1 January 1991. They include the tax exemption for income from goldmining contained in section 23 (o) of the Income Tax Assessment Act. When speaking on the issue of the so-called gold tax exemption, two points, in my view, ought to be emphasised and reiterated. To begin with, the goldmining industry is an important earner of export dollars. By 1990, for example, gold is expected to overtake meat, iron ore, wheat and wool to become Australia's most valuable export earner after coal.

TALK.START.PARA: —Wool is actually at the top of the list.

—It is for the moment. In 1987 the value of Australian gold exports was $1,694m and increased growth in earnings is expected in the immediate future. Hence, the goldmining industry plays a vital role in correcting Australia's serious trade imbalance, as further evidenced by the recent worsening current account figures. In this regard, I refer honourable senators to the statement of the Treasurer, Mr Keating, on 16 December 1986. In announcing the continued taxation arrangements for the gold industry at that time, Mr Keating said:

SPEECH.PARA: The importance of encouraging active exploration and development, and of maximising production and the consequent export income generated by the goldmining industry, outweighed the arguments in favour of removing the industry's longstanding tax exemption.

One might well ask Senator Cook what has happened since then. What significant events, what significant changes, have taken place in Australia's economy, in Australia's balance of payments figures, that would cause the Treasurer to review his position and decide now that that industry--

TALK.START.PARA: —Do you want me to answer that question?
—In due course.
—I am prepared to answer it now.
—Okay.

—The significance is that the Government reduced company taxation from 49c in the dollar to 39c in the dollar. The gold industry is in fact booming. Profits on average are about $260 per ounce of gold mined. They are significant events in terms of this Bill.

—The question I asked was: What events have taken place, what circumstances have arisen. What balance of payments figures have been released, to indicate that since that date we can now afford a tax on the goldmining sector? Of course there has been nothing-nothing except the greed of this Government for further revenue at any price. No longer is it making realistic economic judgments of what is good for an economy; all it wants to do is suck the system, soak up every single dollar of taxation it can find. It finds that the goldmining industry, and in this respect one of the few industries in Australia, through the free market forces and through a sensible taxation regime has been able to flourish, to expand and grow. So the first thing the Government says is, `Hey, here is an industry; let's suck this dry too'. One ought not to forget what the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) of this country said before the last election. He said, `There will be no tax on gold in the life of the next Parliament'.
—That is right, and we are adhering to it.

—That is right, and that is the only thing that makes this legislation prospective to 1991-the expediency of the Government in its desperate attempt to get re-elected, otherwise there would be a tax on gold right now. Frankly, if the Government were feeling a little more secure, it would have broken that promise like every other promise it has broken and introduced a tax on gold. The problem is that that is one of the few promises the Government put in writing and signed, and it used it in the advertising during the last election.
—You deserve credit for actually acknowledging that point. Some of your colleagues have not acknowledged it. Some of them have pretended that we have broken a promise.

—The promise is not broken, the promise is kept to the letter, not a day or a moment longer. The contract stands, but the logic of a tax on gold in 1991 is no different from a tax on gold in 1987, 1988 or 1989. The only thing is that the Government has made a commitment and so it is stretching out the starting date of the legislation to overcome that commitment.

SPEECH.PARA: We ought to look at the monthly current account disaster which this Hawke Government is inflicting upon the Australian people. For the first four months to October this year we have seen the deficit blow out to $5.4 billion, already slightly more than half the $9.5 billion figure predicted in the Budget for 1988-89. Furthermore, the statement that the gold industry does not pay taxes is an absolute myth; it is a fallacy which ought to be dispelled, but it is a fallacy which is perpetuated by the Labor Party in seeking to justify its present legislation. The only distinction is that the goldmining industry does not pay corporate tax, but it pays all the other usual taxes paid by all other companies. Unlike shareholders in companies in other industries, the shareholders of goldmining companies pay income tax at their marginal rates on dividends arising from goldmining profits. While companies in other industries do pay corporate tax, they are able to pass on franked dividends to shareholders who receive a corresponding imputation credit against their income tax liability. Shareholders in goldmining companies receive unfranked dividends which are therefore taxable at the shareholder's marginal rate. It ought to be remembered that the retained profits by goldmining companies manifest themselves in the aggregate price of the shares, so people wishing to enter the share market would be tempted to look at the goldmining industry, see the attractive incentive it has and buy its stock and up goes the price of the stock. As I say, that aggregates in the profits on which capital gains tax is paid at the marginal rate when the stock is sold.

The basic difference, therefore, between the gold industry's integration tax system and the normal imputation tax system is that, for gold companies, retained profits are not taxed initially. Additional dividends and capital gains resulting from re-invested retained earnings will, however, be taxed when they reach the shareholder. This simple distinguishing feature provides an environment conducive to the essential re-investment of profits and reduces the incentive for profits to flow to overseas shores where more favourable tax regimes are available.
It is argued-it is not a debate I want to get into now-that corporate tax exemption in Australia is causing enormous profits to be repatriated out of Australia by overseas companies.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Walsh has made that point.

—Well, it is my view that because there is no corporate tax on gold in Australia this has caused the overseas corporations to re-invest in Australia. As long as the profits are re-invested in Australia, they are quarantined from the initial corporate tax. The moment they are repatriated overseas, they are then paying the tax level at the home rate. Once the Government introduces this tax regime, it will be just as economically logical for overseas corporations to repatriate the profits home, pay the profits at home and not pay them in Australia. At present they are encouraged to re-invest in Australia.

SPEECH.PARA: It must be realised that the gold industry is still in a phase of recovery from the 39 years up to 1972 when the price of gold was fixed owing to the fact that it was a commodity which was used as a unit of currency. It ought to be remembered that the treatment of gold during this time caused the demise to a very large degree and the decline of many goldmining towns-I am more familiar with Western Australia than anywhere else-such as Reedy's, Agnew, Leonora, Cue, Meekatharra and Wiluna. These towns very much contracted and almost became ghost towns. During that same period we saw almost every goldmine on the Golden Mile close down. If it had not been for the fact that Western Mining Corporation Ltd found its nickel out of Kalgoorlie, Western Mining Corporation at that time was proposing to transfer all its operations into the metropolitan area. It is not without significance to note that when the Whitlam Government abolished the exemption for prospectors-the 23 (pa) to which I referred earlier-employment in the industry fell for every year during the period that the exemption had been removed. The exemption was reinstated by the then Treasurer, Phillip Lynch, quite properly in 1977 as a result of a commitment he made in the main street of Kalgoorlie, Hannan Street. Since that time the industry has again flourished. In the late 1970s under the free market--

TALK.START.PARA: —World economic factors have caused it to flourish. Gold is a counter-cyclical metal; it sells well when there is a need to hedge against inflation and there is international economic uncertainty.

—The point that Senator Cook makes does not detract in any way from the proposition I put. What he says is right, of course, that there are other circumstances external to Australia that have caused the industry in Australia to flourish, but I have to say to Senator Cook that one thing is certain: that the price of gold is not influenced by the level of production in Australia which is a proposition he put in Question Time some days ago. Australia produces only 6 per cent of world output and there is nothing Australia can do--
—You are talking about saturating the market though.

—Is Senator Cook seriously putting to this chamber that by imposing a tax on gold one is reducing production and, therefore, increasing price? On the other hand, is he saying that increasing production as a result of a cave-in on taxation--

SPEECH.PARA: Debate interrupted.
Sitting suspended from 12.45 to 2 p.m.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: NATIONAL ABORIGINAL AND ISLANDER HEALTH ORGANISATION

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Tambling Sen G.E.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs. In answer to a question yesterday Senator Bolkus, then representing the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs, quoted from and tabled a statement prepared by Mr Hand. I quote from that statement:

QUESTION.PARA: In a Minute dated September 8th reference was made to an Auditor's Report on NAIHO. This report was compiled before I was Minister and this was the first time it was drawn to my attention.

Is it a fact that Mr Hand was fully briefed, as an incoming Minister, in July 1987, including being briefed on the implications of the Arthur Andersen and Co. report on the National Aboriginal and Islander Health Organisation? Will the Minister now table a copy of this initial brief to the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs? Is it also a fact that a Department of Aboriginal Affairs memo to the Minister dated 29 August 1988 and initialled by Mr Hand on 31 August 1988 specifically drew attention, attachment II, to the assessment of the same auditor's report? In view of the serious misleading of the Senate yesterday, as well as the cover-up of the false and misleading answer given in the House of Representatives on 8 November, what action is now proposed by the Prime Minister, Mr Hand or Senator Bolkus?

TALK.START.PARA: —We need a resignation.

—I think Senator Panizza is right. He has summed it up. The Opposition is looking desperately to get some sort of scalp as a result of these particular matters, but I am afraid it will be disappointed. Senator Tambling continues to make the assertion in the latter part of his question that there has been a deliberate misleading of the Parliament in relation to the original answer given by Mr Hand, the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs, in another place. I reject that completely, and indeed the answer given by the Minister in the other place on that initial occasion to Mr Shipton is accurate. I am asked a series of questions about the sort of briefing that the Minister might have received during his induction into the Aboriginal affairs portfolio, when Ministers are commonly briefed on a range of issues relating to matters of concern within their portfolio.
—Being house trained.

—That is one way of putting it. No doubt Mr Hand-as would all other incoming Ministers-would have received a general briefing on matters of concern within the portfolio. He has indicated that a range of matters were brought to his attention in September relating to the auditor's report into the National Aboriginal and Islander Health Organisation, or an incarnation of that body, if you like, which preceded his time as Minister. In relation to the general briefing he may have received, of course I am unable to say personally whether such a briefing would have adverted in any way to any such report on the National Aboriginal and Islander Health Organisation.
—Find out and table the document.

—I have no intention of tabling a document of a briefing by officers of the Department to the Minister on his coming into office. The fact is that the Minister has indicated that the auditor's report was drawn to his attention on that date, 8 September, which I think Senator Tambling mentioned in his question. It is also claimed that the matter was brought to the attention of the Minister on 29 August. I am in no position to know anything of any such minute of 29 August. I think Senator Tambling said that it was an attachment. I have made a brief note to that effect, but in relation to that particular matter I shall try to establish whether that was the case.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Tambling Sen G.E.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. I quoted from the prepared statement of Mr Hand, read out yesterday. The end of that quote stated:

QUESTION.PARA: . . . and this was the first time it was drawn to my attention.

That refers to a minute of 8 September. I asked Senator Tate to comment particularly on the ministerial briefing of July 1987. I believe that document is now document No. 17, if the Minister needs a reference for it to table it, which I think he should do. It is a very serious matter in view of the statements by Mr Hand in the House of Representatives and by Senator Bolkus yesterday. My supplementary question is: If the Minister claims that 8 September was the first time this matter had been drawn to his attention, how does Senator Tate now account for the fact that he has tabled a letter of 29 August which draws attention to this particular document?

TALK.START.PARA: —In so far as I tabled a document of 29 August, it may have had some reference in it to some attachment, which is what I understand Senator Tambling to be saying. I do not have any information to hand on the particular significance of it or the way in which it was presented to the Minister at the time. Until that is available I cannot fully answer the question.

—Has the attention of the Minister representing the Minister for Transport and Communications been drawn to the lobby by the Australian acting profession to extend the minimum time for locally produced television shows screened each year on Australian commercial television networks by more than three times, to 365 hours? In view of the increasing profit margins of the large commercial television networks, is the Government giving consideration to the request of local actors for a better deal from the media barons who control commercial television? Will the concern of the desperate public, continually bombarded during the non-rating season by repeat episodes of such aged classics as Hogan's Heroes, Gilligan's Island, the Addams Family, the Munsters and The Brady Bunch be addressed in light of the plea from Australian actors? In view of the success overseas of such Australian series as Neighbours, which is certain to improve Australia's balance of payments, will the Government provide further opportunities for Australian actors to help the economic effort and reduce the amount of imported programs dumped on the public in non-rating times?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I hope that Senator Jones is not asking me to comment on the respective merits or personal appeal of The Addams Family and Neighbours. Bearing that in mind I am aware of the reported activities of a delegation of actors, writers and producers calling themselves the Make it Australia Committee urging that the minimum requirement of 104 hours of first release Australian drama be increased to more than 300 hours. Commercial television programming standards and requirements are set by the Australian Broadcasting Tribunal (ABT), which is the independent statutory authority that has responsibility in this area. The ABT is currently drawing to a close a major review of Australian content standards on commercial television. I am advised that the results of that review will be announced in 1989. The Government, as is well known, is presently reviewing the Broadcasting Act and the regulatory framework covering broadcasting in Australia. One of the issues under consideration is whether it would be appropriate to have a set of objectives for broadcasters laid out in the legislation to assist both the ABT and the public to assess the performance of our commercial broadcasters. One such objective could be along the lines that Australian programming be developed to the maximum extent possible. There are ways to achieve this other than through formally increasing the number of hours.

ANSWER.PARA: As to the provision of opportunities for Australian actors, which was a central theme of Senator Jones's question, the broadcasting legislation already requires licensees, as a condition of holding a licence, to undertake to use Australian creative resources. The Broadcasting Act already requires licensees, as a condition of holding their licences, to undertake to use Australian creative resources. Clearly, this is something that could be the subject, I think, of more enforcement attention in the future. In addition, the Government has finally provided $70m in the current financial year to establish the Australian Film Finance Corporation which will fund qualifying Australian production, both for film and for television, and that should also assist in meeting the objectives to which Senator Jones has correctly drawn our attention.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: NATIONAL ABORIGINAL AND ISLANDER HEALTH ORGANISATION

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask the Minister representing the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs: In light of his absence yesterday, has he bothered to brief himself or be briefed on the matters which were dealt with by Senator Bolkus on behalf of the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs? My question of substance, which follows the question asked by Senator Tambling, is: Firstly, does the Minister remember tabling in the early hours of Friday morning or late on Thursday night in the Senate a series of documents which included a ministerial submission from the Department of Aboriginal Affairs (DAA) addressed to Mr Hand relating to the proposed meeting with the National Aboriginal and Islander Health Organisation (NAIHO) on 31 August? Does he recall tabling that submission without the attachments I and II which provided a briefing on NAIHO's budget and a background history on NAIHO respectively? Is the Minister aware that, in response to a request from Senator Crichton-Browne, Senator Bolkus produced those attachments in the Senate yesterday? Is the Minister further aware that the second attachment refers specifically to:

QUESTION.PARA: An independent review of NAIHO's systems of financial practices undertaken by Arthur Andersen and Company in July 1986 . . .

The attachment confirms various negatives about NAIHO which, in the interests of brevity, I will not detail. I ask the Minister specifically: Has he seen the briefing note which he produced on Thursday night and the attachment produced yesterday which make a clear reference to the audit report from Arthur Andersen and Co.? Again, I put it to the Minister that, in light of those clearly established facts-facts established by him and his ministerial colleague-it has been said by the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs:
In a Minute dated September 8th reference was made to an Auditor's Report on NAIHO. This report was compiled before I was Minister and this was the first time it was drawn to my attention.

I ask the Minister: In light of the question about the original briefing the Minister received from his Department with respect to Arthur Andersen and Co. and with respect to the specific matters which have now been disclosed to the Senate by him and his ministerial colleague, how can he deny that the statement made by Senator Bolkus on behalf of Hand misled the Senate yesterday?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not believe that the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs, through Ministers in this place, has misled the Senate as to his knowledge of the report by Arthur Andersen into the activities of the National Aboriginal and Islander Health Organisation. The fact that there may have been some reference to that audit being undertaken does not necessarily mean that the Minister had a fully informed mind in relation to those matters which were the subject of the auditor's report. I have here a document from Mr McDonald dated 8 September 1988 which states:

ANSWER.PARA: in my brief to you for your meeting with NAIHO on 31 August (part copy attached) I referred to an audit of the organisation conducted by accountants Arthur Andersen and Co. in 1986. As this investigation was conducted during your predecessor's term of office, it is possible that you have not seen the original report. I am therefore attaching a copy for your information.

I think there is a recognition there that the Minister did not have available to him a copy of the audit report by Arthur Andersen into the National Aboriginal and Islander Health Organisation such as would have allowed him to have used its conclusions and findings in the course of his discussions and deliberations in relation to the National Aboriginal and Islander Health Organisation. As I have said, I believe that there is a recognition there that, whatever might have been attached to a note in earlier correspondence, it was recognised that the Minister's coming into the portfolio required that he be informed and given a copy of this report so that he could then take it into account. And that is what is revealed there.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. Now that the Minister has had a chance to refresh his memory, from this morning or whenever it was that he looked at this document, I ask him whether he agrees that before the meeting of 31 August which, of course, was before 8 September, the Department specifically drew to the attention of the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs the existence of the report of Arthur Andersen and Co. of July 1986 which indicated that NAIHO's systems of financial control were inadequate; inadequate accounting records were maintained; a limited amount of information was conveyed to people outside NAIHO such as the Minister and DAA; and substantial items of expenditure for various items were not supported by documentation or did not appear unusual. Does the Minister agree that all those matters were drawn to the attention of the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs on the evidence that the Minister made available to the Senate not later than prior to 31 August?

—It is true that some material relating to the National Aboriginal and Islander Health Organisation was provided to the Minister as part of a briefing but it was quite clear that what was not provided was a copy of the audit report itself. Its full description of the situation in the National Aboriginal and Islander Health Organisation and its findings, conclusions and recommendations would have been an essential part of any eventual decision making process in which the Minister was engaged. As I have said, it was not until a later time that that report was forwarded to him. Obviously officers realised that, in the transition of Ministerial responsibility, he had not had the advantage of apprising himself of the Arthur Andersen report.

—I ask the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce: In light of continued media speculation and in view of the importance of the steel industry to Australia's manufacturing industry, has the Government responded to the Steel Industry Authority report?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I responded on behalf of the Government to the Steel Industry Authority recommendations relating to the steel plan this morning. Lest I be accused of government by press release I should indicate to the Senate the essence of that response-to the Steel Industry Authority report and to the report of the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Finance and Public Administration, chaired by Mr Martin. The Government has decided that the steel plan will end on 31 December 1988. No further bounties will be paid on the production of steel. Tariff protection will continue at low to moderate levels-that is, nought to 14 per cent cent-phasing down to 10 per cent as the maximum level. Developing country preferences will be reintroduced for all steel products and countries. There will be no special provision in regard to by-law entry of steel products. No changes will be made to the trade practices legislation. However, the Government will consider action in future if it proves to be necessary.

ANSWER.PARA: Finally, the Government supports the process of negotiating agreements at plant level between the Broken Hill Proprietary Co. Ltd (BHP) and the unions. These plant level agreements which are expected to be finalised shortly will cover matters such as productivity targets, employment security, training and work practices. That means that, as from 31 December, the Government will have no direct involvement in the steel industry at all apart from some monitoring of aggregate statistics relating to imports, exports, productivity and so on. I should just report that at present BHP is producing at maximum capacity, to satisfy both export markets and a strong growth in domestic demand for steel. The current level of productivity measurement per employee is between 320 and 350 tonnes per man-a figure which compares with 180 tonnes per man in 1983 when the steel industry plan started. During the period of the plan, BHP has invested $1.5 billion and has foreshadowed further investments. That is in response to a commitment to invest $800m. Employment in the industry has stabilised. During the life of the plan the Government expended $146m on bounty or subsidy assistance as against $350m which was announced at the time of the plan as the maximum level which the Government would be prepared to spend.

The Government believes there is strong confidence in the industry at present, reflected in BHP's announcements regarding investments, its decision to expand capacity at Port Kembla and the proposed establishment of a new Sydney mini-mill. The Government believes there is no further need for assistance or continuation of the steel plan and proposes no further direct intervention.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Treasurer. Has the Foreign Investment Review Board (FIRB) been downgraded from a department to a section? Has its staff been cut from 40 to 20, and are many of those staff part time? Has a ceiling been imposed on the number of staff members in the Foreign Investment Review Board? Furthermore, can the Minister confirm that only one prosecution has occurred under the Foreign Takeovers Act since it was enacted by the Fraser Government in 1976, and that this prosecution was unsuccessful? In view of the massive and increasing volume of foreign investment buying up our primary and tourism industries, rural and urban businesses and properties, when does the Government intend to upgrade the FIRB, increase its staff and equip it to protect Australia from being sold off to foreign investors at bargain basement prices, or even at highly inflated prices as seems to have happened in the residential market?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —With regard to the last part of the question, I would have thought that, if bits of Australia had been sold off at highly inflated prices, that is, at prices well above their long-term value, that was a bit of good business. A number of assumptions and presumptions in the question are incorrect. Firstly, there has been no change to the Foreign Investment Review Board for a number of years. Secondly, the Treasury support staff for the FIRB was changed from a division to a branch some time last year. At the time the Government announced in September 1977 that it would monitor more closely, or tighten up on, the purchase of residential real estate in Australia, the number of staff was 15. The number has recently been increased to 20. Of course, there is a ceiling on staff numbers, as there is in all comparable bodies in government, with the recent exception that agencies have been allowed within the last 12 months to substitute a limited amount of money for staff-in other words, to vary the average staffing level by up to half a per cent provided it is done within the financial limits set.

ANSWER.PARA: The Foreign Takeovers Act, the parent Act, was passed not by the Fraser Government in 1976, but by the Whitlam Government in 1975. Bits of Australia are not being sold at bargain basement prices. More important than those small mistaken assumptions in the question is the fact that Senator Haines and the Australian Democrats do not like foreign borrowings and they do not like foreigners taking equity in Australia. I suppose that they are defensible enough positions in themselves. But the fact is that, while we continue to run a current account deficit-and I have not heard many propositions ever come from the Australian Democrats that would do anything but make the current account deficit worse-we can make a choice between increasing borrowings abroad and increasing foreign ownership of Australian equity. There is no alternative. It has to be one or the other, unless we can get rid of the current account deficit altogether. If there were some painless way of doing that, I am sure we would have done it, and I am sure the previous Government would have too.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question follows the question of Senator Hill to the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade yesterday. I refer to the fact that the Minister, in response to Senator Hill's question, said that the offence by the Yugoslav security officer who shot an Australian protester was not one for which a claim of immunity could be made until the closure of the consulate when article 26 of the Vienna Convention on Consular Relations came into effect. My question of the Minister therefore is: Were other measures not available to the Australian Government to ensure that the Yugoslav authorities yielded up the officer concerned for appropriate investigation and trial in Australia? In discussions between the Australian Government and the Yugoslav authorities, was the question of the possibility of the officer concerned not receiving a fair trial in Australia raised?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not believe that other ways were available of ensuring that this man came to trial.
—We suggested one course of action to you yesterday, but you ridiculed it.

—I can do without Senator Hill's help, just as I can do without the help of that other elegant fop on the Opposition front bench who creates havoc and devastation every time he opens his mouth on foreign policy issues. Those pleasantries aside, the truth is that, so long as the consulate remained a consulate, it was physically inviolable by the Australian Government or anyone else, even though the person concerned may not at any stage have been able to enjoy or claim formal diplomatic or consular immunity. But the premises remained inviolable and to that extent there was a degree of de facto immunity thus associated with the situation until the time that the consulate premises were closed. Once the premises were closed, and the functions of the consul thus terminated, the situation arose where the Australian Government was then bound by the terms of the Vienna Convention to give safe passage out of the country to the people whose functions were thus terminated. That is the construction of that article that has by and large been accepted and certainly, as I said yesterday, that is the textbook construction of it, creating an obligation even for someone in gaol legitimately on an offence to be escorted safely out of the country. That was the conundrum that we faced.

ANSWER.PARA: I am sure that Senator Harradine, with his appreciation of theological metaphysics and a whole variety of other things that preoccupy him in this chamber, will appreciate the nicety of the situation in which we found ourselves. There was just no way through that analysis of it. I did not derive any assistance then or now from the contribution of the Opposition on this subject. The Government's reaction has been perfectly clear all along-that we regard the original shooting incident as deplorable, unacceptable, intolerable and indefensible, and we have reacted to the best of our ability in the whole course of events subsequently.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask a supplementary question, Mr President. The Minister has not directly answered the question that I asked and, as he particularly used the word `indefensible' in his response, I again ask: In discussions between the Yugoslav authorities and the Australian Government authorities, was the question raised of the possibility of the officer concerned not receiving a fair trial? To what extent were the Minister's original statements a cause of that?

—The question was not raised at any stage about the potential of the officer receiving a fair trial. I was at pains to point out in a number of public statements that to the extent that the consulate believed that the circumstances occuring at the time-the demonstration and so on-justified the response of the officer, that was something he would amply be able to raise in his own defence in the course of any trial. The ground of the objection was never put in those terms to me directly or in communications between my Department and the Ambassador or to our people in Belgrade. It was put simply in terms that they believe themselves entitled to be offended at the so-called absence of protection from the demonstration. They believe the officer on their side was justified in reacting as he did. We even had the extradordinary statement from the Yugoslav Foreign Minister yesterday that it was an occasion for pride and satisfaction for the Yugoslav people that the personnel at the consulate reacted as they did. That was the nature of their response. They believed under those circumstances that the reaction of the Australian Government in closing the consulate and in expelling the whole staff was not justified. It had nothing to do with the point the honourable senator was trying to make.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: NATIONAL ABORIGINAL AND ISLANDER HEALTH ORGANISATION

TALK.START.PARA: —I direct my question to the Minister representing the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs. Who from Mr Hand's staff or his Department attended the meeting between the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs and representatives of the National Aboriginal and Islander Health Organisation in the Minister's office on 31 August to discuss funding of NAIHO? Did anyone from the ministerial office or the Department make a note of those discussions? If so, will the Minister table such note or notes? If no record was made, does not the Minister agree that this is strange, considering the subject under discussion and the desirability of all parties to fully understand any commitments given?

—I do not know whether a note was made in relation to that particular meeting, but it would not be strange if the meeting itself did not issue in a decision. I agree that it would be odd if a minute were not taken of a decision made by a Minister in relation to funding, but as the meeting did not eventuate in such a decision, as Mr Hand indicated in his answer in another place, I believe that it may not be surprising if a minute or a note recording the various elements of the meeting were not made. Nevertheless, I will seek to find out whether such a note was made. As I said, in so far as it was a discussion, a meeting of the Minister and the National Aboriginal and Islander Health Organisation representatives, who were representing themselves in a sort of revamped fashion and making a plea for consideration of the Minister, it would just be a discussion without the need to formally record an important decision which would be the case if a funding decision had been concluded.
—Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. Was the Minister aware of any staff members either from the Minister's office or from the Department, being in attendance at that meeting?
—I will check on that for the honourable senator.

—Is the Minister representing the Treasurer aware that the former Treasurer, Mr John Howard, said on the Australian Broadcasting Corporation's 7.30 Report last night that in his final year as Treasurer average living standards in the Australian community were higher than they are now? Can the Minister provide the Senate with the economic facts and figures necessary for an assessment of the validity of that claim?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I did not see the 7.30 Report last night, but I am told that Mr Howard made the statement that Senator Colston said he did. It is obvious-and this is the charitable view-that Mr Howard is looking back at 1982-83 through rose-tinted spectacles. It is true that some families were better off in 1982 and 1983 because they had just had a two-year wages explosion where nominal wages went up by 13 per cent in 1981 and by 14 per cent in 1982. So for those people who kept their jobs there had been a large increase in real income, which is not the same thing, necessarily, as average living standards or average per capita income; but there had been a substantial increase in real income for those people who were able to keep their jobs. That category excludes the 209,000 who lost their jobs in the last 15 months of the Fraser-Howard regime. In making the statement that he did, Mr Howard has also chosen to ignore the more than 1.1 million people who have obtained jobs since this Government has been in office. In other words, in the last year of the Fraser-Howard regime, 200,000 people a year were losing their jobs. Since this Government has been in office an extra 200,000 people, coincidentally, have been getting jobs. The numbers are about the same: one has a negative sign in front of it and the other has a plus sign in front of it.

ANSWER.PARA: The unemployment rate in the March quarter of 1983 was 10.4 per cent. Inflation peaked at above 11 per cent. We had just had a round of tax give-aways under those circumstances but it did not help anything at all in the end. It was designed to help the Fraser Government to fall over the line in another election-but that did not happen. What we had at that time was the big treble: double-digit unemployment, double-digit inflation, and a $10 billion Budget deficit looming, as Senator Stone was kind enough to tell us, on or about 6 March 1983. As I said before, that followed the wages explosion in 1981 and 1982 of 13 per cent and 14 per cent respectively.

Over the last 5 1/2 years, largely because there has been a successful wages policy in place, employment has grown at rates which are without precedent in Australia's economic history. Largely because of that growth in the number of employed, which is just above 18 per cent--
Opposition senators interjecting-

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! There are too many interjections.

—Ron, the last time I saw a mouth that big it had a brown paper bag stuffed in it. Largely because of that unprecedented growth in employment, in total more than 18 per cent in the last 5 1/2 years, real disposable per capita incomes have increased by 4 1/2 per cent, if we want the total, or by 4 per cent if we want to exclude capital sourced income-the definition that Mr Peacock prefers-whereas, on the same measure, all real disposable household income fell by 1.8 per cent in that golden year of 1982-83, and excluding capital sourced income-and this is Mr Peacock's preferred definition-it fell by 2.5 per cent.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: NATIONAL ABORIGINAL AND ISLANDER HEALTH ORGANISATION

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Crichton-Browne Sen N.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I direct my question to the Minister representing the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs. I refer him to Mr Don McDonald's minute to the Secretary of the Department of Aboriginal Affairs dated 3 December in which Mr McDonald suggested that the senior officers, who on 1 December agreed on their version of the Minister's telephone call of 8 November, were `more concerned with rewriting history than recording the truth'. He then said:

QUESTION.PARA: After the Minister spoke to me on 8 November I think I made a brief note about that call in my diary. I can't confirm that as the diary is in my Perth office. You might want to ask Mr Westbury to secure the diary to check what I wrote at the time.

Has that been done? If so, will the Minister table any relevant extract? If not, will the Minister arrange to check the diary in view of the fact that Mr McDonald's recollections, as he notes, were written without the benefit of hindsight-unlike others involved in this business?

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not know whether the diary referred to has been sought to be obtained from the Perth office of the Department. I will undertake--
—Has the shredder been at work?

—I doubt whether any shredder has been at work. In fact, it will be well known that a lot of material has been sealed in anticipation of the various inquiries that are taking place or about to take place. It is quite out of the question that such a diary would be put through the shredder. That is an absurd allegation to make. Mr McDonald himself does not say that he definitely made a diary entry. He thinks that he may have done so. I believe that that diary entry, if it does exist, is an important one. If it can be made available, it will be.

—I ask a supplementary question, Mr President, as I did not hear the end of the Minister's answer. Did the Minister give a commitment to the Senate that he would recover the entry that Mr McDonald believes he has made and make it available to the Senate?

—What I said was that, if such a diary entry exists, I believe it can be recovered and it ought then to be made available-if, as I say, it is found to exist. I emphasise that Mr McDonald is not asserting that he did, in fact, make a diary entry on that date.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Land Transport and Shipping Support. I refer to claims that the Adelaide to Mount Gambier Blue Lake passenger rail service could be closed, despite the fact that it has been revamped and rescheduled only in the past year or so. Is the Minister able to provide a response to these claims about the future of one of only a handful of passenger rail services remaining in South Australia and operated by Australian National (AN)?
