—I am advised that no request has been received by the Federal Government relating to the closure of the Blue Lake passenger service operated by Australian National. Australian National is a government business enterprise and has been provided with a legislative charter to enable it to operate independently and commercially with minimum government intervention. The success of that policy has been demonstrated by a 66 per cent reduction in real terms in AN's call on Australian taxpayers since 1982-83. I expect that AN will be reviewing all its operations continually, including passenger services, to ensure that these are delivered as efficiently and as economically as possible and at minimum cost to the taxpayer. Maybe that kind of review is the source of the present report. I make the point that any proposal to reduce or close services in South Australia would require the agreement of the South Australian Minister. Under those circumstances this may be a subject that Senator Maguire will care to take up in that direction.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: NATIONAL ABORIGINAL AND ISLANDER HEALTH ORGANISATION

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs. Did Ms Harriett Swift make a note of the conservation between her employer, the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs, and Mr Don McDonald of the Department of Aboriginal Affairs after the Minister had had discussions with representatives of the National Aboriginal and Islander Health Organisation on 31 August? If so, will the Minister table Ms Swift's record of the conversation? If no such record is available, does this mean that the only record of that discussion is Mr McDonald's original note of 1 September and his subsequent elaborations on what occurred, all of which assert that the Minister told him he had decided to fund the National Aboriginal and Islander Health Organisation?

—I am not aware of any note by Ms Harriett Swift recording the meeting between the National Aboriginal and Islander Health Organisation representatives and the Minister because, as I understand it, and as I am advised, she was not present at that meeting. Indeed, in answer to Senator Boswell's earlier question, I have since been advised that only Mr Geoff Pryor was present at that meeting between the Minister and the National Aboriginal and Islander Health Organisation.
—She was present at the discussions with the Minister after, though.

—I am coming to that. As I understand it, Senator Reid's question relates to any discussion between Mr McDonald and the Minister following that meeting. Naturally, that is a quite separate matter. In relation to that meeting, I have no record available to me of the discussion taken down by Harriett Swift. If that is the case, Mr McDonald's note of the time is the only existing written record purporting to convey what occurred in that discussion with the Minister. However, Mr McDonald himself makes it clear-the honourable senator talked about subsequent elaborations by Mr McDonald as being the only source of a written record of that discussion with the Minister-in his long letter of 3 December to the Secretary of the Department that he has been misquoted in the senior officers record of proceedings of 5 September as saying that the Minister had directed that the National Aboriginal and Islander Health Organisation receive $180,000. Mr McDonald has made it clear that that particular record, which stood on the file for several months, is now repudiated by him as not accurately conveying his discussions with the Minister. So the question of what transpired at the meeting with the National Aboriginal and Islander Health Organisation is a matter for what one might call--
—Rewriting?

—No, not at all, except in so far as Mr McDonald himself agrees that the minute purporting to record his view given to the special officers meeting of 5 September is not accurate. That is a very important qualification.
—No, no, no.
—I get `No, no, no'. What he said on 3 December--
—Are you blaming a class 11 officer?

—I am not blaming anyone. I am just saying that Mr McDonald himself has said, `I do not agree that I said that the Minister had ``directed that the National Aboriginal and Islander Health Organisation receive $180,000'' '. I am saying that Mr McDonald himself indicates that the record of proceedings of the senior officers group of 5 September does not accurately record his rendering of the conversation held with the Minister. I believe that that is a very important qualification.
—I ask a supplementary question, Mr President. Does the same answer apply to Mr Pryor?

—I am quite confident that Mr Pryor agrees with the answers which have been given by the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs, Mr Gerry Hand, in relation to what transpired at the meeting with the National Aboriginal and Islander Health Organisation--
—Did he make a record?

—I have already attempted to answer that in relation to Senator Boswell's question-and that is that Mr Pryor was the only ministerial staff member present at that meeting and he did not make a record of those proceedings.
—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Treasurer. In view of their importance to society, I ask the Minister: What is the tax treatment of brown paper bags?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —Brown paper bags per se are unlikely to have any implications for taxation. However, when they are stuffed full of money it could well be different and raise issues similar to those raised by Senator Schacht in a question last week concerning the tax treatment of the proceeds of blackmail and bribery, particularly as they related to the Bjelke-Petersen Foundation. I understand that the destination of a couple of brown paper bags, the existence of which was revealed yesterday, was a company called Kaldeal Pty Ltd. Apparently, the Queensland National Party was running two separate accounts: one for the proceeds of blackmail which went to the Bjelke-Petersen Foundation; and the other for brown paper bags which went into Kaldeal Pty Ltd.

—Mr President, I raise a point of order. The question directed to Senator Walsh was on paper bags. We are now getting completely away from the subject of paper bags, and onto a much different subject. I ask you to ask the Minister to come to order and talk about paper bags.
—Order! There is no point of order. Senator Walsh was answering a question on behalf of the Treasurer and was dealing with taxation issues.

—I think it should be noted for the record that several of my colleagues sitting behind me were asking Senator Boswell whether he was the bagman. Neither the Bjelke-Petersen Foundation nor Kaldeal Pty Ltd is likely to be classified as a public benevolent institution, which is the relevant definition in the Income Tax Assessment Act for donations-if one could use that term-to be claimed by the giver as a deduction from the giver's taxable income. Those payments would seem to have been in the nature of voluntary payments or gifts, about which the Master Tax Guide on page 309 notes:

ANSWER.PARA: The test of the assessability of a voluntary payment or gift is whether, from the recipient's point of view, it accrues to him by virtue of his office or employment, i.e. as additional remuneration in relation to services rendered. The motive of the donor and the periodicity of recurrence of the payment are relevant but not decisive factors. Ex gratia payments for honorary services, unsolicited donations received by an evangelist, an award received as best and fairest footballer, and instalments of a signing-on fee paid to an amateur footballer on joining a professional team have all been held to be assessable.
This would seem to apply to somebody receiving a brown paper bag stuffed full of money, because he held public office.

TALK.START.PARA: —A National Party Oslo lunch.

—A National Party Oslo lunch; that should also be put on the record. So as this Tax Guide points out, it would apply to a footballer's best and fairest award or the unsolicited donations received by an evangelist. The brown paper bags in question would seem to have been in the nature of direct compensation for services. On that question, the Master Tax Guide says:

ANSWER.PARA: All remuneration or rewards for personal services, whether received in the capacity of employee or otherwise in connection with an employment or the rendering of personal services--

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I raise a point of order. In terms of talking about taxation treatment of wrapping material, the Minister is also obliged to inform the Senate of the taxation treatment of leather bags in which large sums of money go disappearing in hotels.
—Order! There is no point of order.

—I must say that I am surprised at Senator Puplick. Almost as often as Senator Chaney sees fit to try to defend the antics of the Queensland National Party and the former Bjelke-Petersen Government, I do not understand why Senator Puplick insists on leading with his chin so often. I notice that Senator Stone is not trying to defend the Queensland National Party; Senator Brownhill is not trying to defend it; not even Senator Bjelke-Petersen is trying to defend it-just Senator Puplick. Senator Puplick is trying to lay a trail of smoke to hide the record of infamy of the Queensland National Party. As I was saying when quoting from the Master Tax Guide:

ANSWER.PARA: . . . rendering of personal services, are income in the ordinary sense of that term within sec. 25 (1) and must be included in assessable income.

The fact that such transactions may be carried out by a third party does not appear to affect the tax liability associated with that kind of activity. Although, if some of the money stuck to the fingers of the third party, that would probably be different. As I said in response to Senator Schacht's question last week, it will be up to the Commissioner of Taxation, or his deputy, to make that final decision about these matters. I daresay, as I understand section 16 of the Act, the precise judgments made about that issue will never actually be disclosed. On the broader question of this transaction, I remind the Senate of Paddy Crick, as quoted by Cyril Pearl in Wild Men of Sydney. Paddy said:

If a person came to me and offered me 10,000 pounds to put through a matter for him, and I could put it through in a legitimate and honest way . . . I would take the amount, just as a barrister would take a 5,000 pound fee.
That seems also to be the prevailing ethos of the Queensland National Party.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: NATIONAL ABORIGINAL AND ISLANDER HEALTH ORGANISATION

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Lewis Sen A.W.R

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs. I refer the Minister to the minute from Mr Don McDonald, dated 3 December, to the Secretary to the Department of Aboriginal Affairs. I ask whether it is a fact that in this minute Mr McDonald says:

QUESTION.PARA: `. . . I have absolutely no doubt that at the end of his meeting of 31 August with NAIHO, the Minister had decided to fund NAIHO with effect from 1 December' `He (that is, Mr Hand) said ``I have decided to fund NAIHO . . . Obviously, you don't agree with the decision'' ' `I have never had any doubt that he agreed to fund it' `There is absolutely no doubt in my mind that the Minister decided on August 31 to fund NAIHO'

In view of these totally unequivocal statements from the senior officer briefed by the Minister immediately after the meeting in question, how can the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs possibly maintain that he did not mislead Parliament when, on 8 November, he said: `I am yet to make a decision'?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is true that Mr McDonald, in his minute to the Secretary of 3 December, made the claims as to the way in which events transpired as outlined by Senator Lewis. Obviously, I cannot deny that they are quotations from that document. But they have to be contrasted with the document of 2 December, where Mr McDonald also said:

ANSWER.PARA: The Minister then read me the text of an answers he had given earlier that day-
this is referring to a recollection of the events of 8 November-

to a question about his `decision' to fund NAIHO. I confirmed that the answer was accurate and consistent with my recollection of his advice to me after his meeting with NAIHO some weeks earlier. I have since read the relevant Hansard, which was consistent with the Minister's earlier reading to me, and have no reason to change my view on the accuracy of his reply.

I believe that there is some difficulty in reconciling the two documents, the one of 2 December and the one of 3 December, as they were put forward by Mr McDonald. Nevertheless, I think that is something which obviously has to be taken into an overall context. The context of the telephone call in the presence of several other senior members of the Department I think must lend some weight to the original rendering in written form of the recollection of that event by Mr McDonald of 2 December. It is in relation to that particular recollection that the Minister's answer is vindicated.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Lewis Sen A.W.R

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. Does the Minister agree, in comparing a note made on 2 December with a note made on 3 December, that Mr McDonald, when he was called to the telephone on 2 December, was engaged in departmental activities? Further, did Mr McDonald have no warning of the fact that he was about to be asked by his Minister a very serious question relating to an answer which the Minister had given in the Parliament that day? I ask whether the Minister agrees that Mr McDonald has subsequently explained the reply he gave on the telephone that day by saying:

QUESTION.PARA: I thought then, and still do, that the answer the Minister gave in the House was loose enough to be `consistent', particularly in view of the possibility of DEET funding and the doubts which had probably been raised in the Minister's mind by the audit report. Bear in mind that this all took place by telephone and there was no attempt to confirm any of this in writing.

Does the Minister accept these explanations by Mr McDonald as to the reason why he was able to say on 2 December that he thought this answer might have been consistent with his recollection but that subsequently on 3 December, when he had been able to refresh his memory, he was able to give a more accurate response as to what had occurred in his note on 1 December and his recollection of the events of 31 August?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —No, I do not agree because Mr McDonald in his note of 2 December says that he had had the opportunity to read the relevant Hansard. In that respect, I believe that, in other words, he had an opportunity to go beyond what might have transpired in a busy day when he took a call in the Perth office from the Minister. I agree that would have a certain pressure about it. But he says:

ANSWER.PARA: I have since read the relevant Hansard, which was consistent with the Minister's earlier reading to me, and have no reason to change my view on the accuracy of his reply.

I believe in that situation Mr McDonald, in leisure as it were, had reason to confirm after his reading of the Hansard-in other words, Mr Hand's reply to Mr Shipton-that the answer given by Mr Hand was accurate.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: UNIVERSITY OF NEW SOUTH WALES: EDUCATIONAL TELEVISION LICENCE

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 1 December Senator Lewis asked me a question as Minister representing the Minister for Transport and Communications about a radio licence for the University of New South Wales. I seek leave to incorporate the text of that answer in Hansard.

ANSWER.PARA: Leave granted.
The answer read as follows-

There were a number of reasons why the Department of Transport and Communications could not renew the licence held by the University of NSW, notwithstanding the fact that the University proposed to use the licence for a very worthwhile purpose-educational broadcasting.
It is true that the licence, issued under the Radiocommunications Act, was first granted some 20 years ago. However, the university now proposes to use the licence for a somewhat different purpose.

Originally, the licence was to operate a transmitter to distribute educational programs to particular lecture sites off the campus. The programs were sent on UHF channel 48 (changed to channel 43 in 1980) and, at that time, UHF reception was not generally available to the general public.

This is an important point because a licence issued under the Radiocommunications Act cannot be used for providing a service to the general public. It is not meant as a substitute for a licence issued under the Broadcasting Act. A Broadcasting Act licence can only be granted by the Broadcasting Tribunal through the public inquiry process. Educational broadcasting is part of public broadcasting and there are already a number of educational public radio services licensed under the Broadcasting Act.

Since 1979, the university has been advised by the Department on several occasions of the requirement to seek a Broadcasting Act licence if it wished to proceed with an educational broadcasting service. I am advised that the University has not in fact used its former licence for the past 5 years, except for the occasional conference such as the recent ANZAS conference.

It is acknowledged that, at this stage, there is no firm commitment to Public Television, a situation known to the University. However, in March of this year, I, as Minister for Transport and Communications, allowed, for the first time, test transmissions to be conducted by Public Television groups, to enable such groups to show their wares, raise support and undertake research into community attitudes and support for Public Television.

I also said that before the Government could seriously consider giving the go-ahead for Public Television in some permanent form, a much clearer picture was needed of what Public Television groups were proposing and a reasonably convincing case of its viability without relying on Commonwealth funds or advertising. I understand that neither Mr Willis nor Mr Dawkins has received any detailed proposals on public or educational television.

Finally, the Government will also consider the question of Public Television in conjunction with other reviews currently taking place-National Broadcasting Review and Pay Television. It is important to ensure that if Public Television is introduced in some permanent form, it be done so after careful consideration of all possible options. There will also need to be full consultation with a range of interested parties, including public and educational television groups, the Public Broadcasting Association of Australia and, in respect of educational television, the Minister for Education, Employment and Training.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 1 December Senator Jenkins asked me a question concerning a uranium pilot plant at Kalgoorlie. At that time I gave her a general answer but I was short on specifics. I can now give some detail. I understand that the construction of the pilot plant commenced on October 1979 and was completed in September 1980. Testing of uranium ore from the Yeelirrie uranium deposit was undertaken until December 1981, when the work was completed. Since then the pilot plant has been used intermittently for short periods as a general metallurgical test plant, mainly carrying out grinding tests on a variety of ores for third parties.

ANSWER.PARA: Approximately 170 road trains transported a total of 10,000 tonnes of ore from Yeelirrie to the pilot plant during 1980 and 1981. A shipment of 200 tonnes of ore from the Olympic Dam mine in South Australia was transported by road to the pilot plant for grinding test work in 1984. Olympic Dam ore contains copper, uranium, silver and gold. In each case, the ore was transported in accordance with the code of practice for safe transport of radioactive substances and I understand that both Western Australian and South Australian government authorities were notified as appropriate prior to shipment.

The yellowcake produced at the Western Mining Corporation Ltd pilot plant is stored in drums at the Lucas Heights establishment of the Australian Nuclear Science and Technology Organisation. However, I understand that in 1982 the then Commonwealth Government approved exports of small yellowcake samples, totalling around six kilograms each, to a number of uranium converters in Europe and the United States for analysis.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: DEPARTMENT OF ABORIGINAL AFFAIRS: UNACQUITTED GRANTS

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have a deal of material to table for the benefit of honourable senators in relation to questions and matters to do with the portfolio of Aboriginal Affairs. On 28 November 1988, Senator Crichton-Browne asked, firstly:

ANSWER.PARA: How many unacquitted grants does the Department of Aboriginal Affairs have outstanding nationally?
I am advised that as at 5 December 1988, 1,462 grants made by the Department had not been formally acquitted. Secondly, the honourable senator asked:
What are the numbers for each State?

The numbers for each State are as follows: New South Wales, 382; Queensland, 254; Victoria and Tasmania, 16; South Australia, 175; Western Australia, 444; and Northern Territory, 191. This makes a total of 1,462. Thirdly, the honourable senator asked:
What is the Government doing about these unacquitted grants?

It has been normal departmental practice each year to focus on the acquittal of grants made in the previous financial year when audited financial statements became available from auditors, which is usually in the following November-December. However, in 1988 the situation has been different and, with the prospect of the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission commencing on 1 January 1989, the State directors of the Department were instructed to give particular attention to the acquittal of grants with a view to minimising any carryover into ATSIC administration. Desirably, the target number should be zero but, because of the operational and ongoing process associated with the making of grants and the release of funds, such a result is just not practical.
Fourthly, Senator Crichton-Browne asked:
Why have they occurred?

The funding process involves, firstly, the approval of a grant for a defined purpose. The purpose may be of an ongoing nature or for a one-off situation. Secondly, the approval is conditional on the grant recipient providing accountability for the use of the funds in outcome as well as financial terms. Thirdly, for an ongoing organisation, financial accountability is required on a quarterly basis culminating in the provision of the organisation's audited annual financial statements. Fourthly, an organisation's audited annual financial statements do not usually become available until around November-December. The Department's financial rules are therefore framed to require the receipt of these statements by the end of the second quarter of the financial year. Fifthly, with most grants acquittal must await the provision of the audited annual financial statements.

Sixthly, two procedural factors are inherent in the process and are likely to delay acquittals. In the first place, the non-receipt of audited statements is particularly critical in remote areas where auditors are few in number and other matters are often given greater priority. In the second place, deficiencies in the audit report can range from qualifications of a serious nature to technical inconsistencies. These deficiencies are more frequently of a minor nature but still require administrative effort to resolve before an acquittal can be formally made. It is the latter problem which is largely responsible for the present level of unacquitted grants in a present staffing situation where resources are scarce and often overstressed. Seventhly, a third factor is the level of expertise in financial management and accounting in the grant recipient organisation. This matter is being addressed through training and on the job experience. Under the Aboriginal employment development policy, a special program has been established to provide training for Aboriginal organisations, directors and staff.
Fifthly, Senator Crichton-Browne asked:
Are the departmental officers sufficiently skilled to deal with the matters?
The answer is yes. Sixthly, the honourable senator asked:
Is the Department enforcing financial rules and guidelines for the administration of these grants?
The answer is yes. Seventhly, he asked:
. . . are grants still being made to organisations who presently have unacquitted grants?

Yes, but only after careful consideration of all the circumstances by the Department's State directors. It should be noted that many organisations are meeting the urgent needs of and services to their communities. Accordingly, State directors may, under delegation, make provision to continue funding to an organisation ending the formal acquittal of a grant or grants made previously.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: DEPARTMENT OF ABORIGINAL AFFAIRS: UNACQUITTED GRANTS

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crichton-Browne Sen N.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the Minister's answer.

The answers provided today by the Minister for Justice (Senator Tate) are in total conflict with the answer that he provided through his advisers last week during the Committee of the Whole stage of the Appropriation Bills. The Minister told the Committee that the acquittal of grants was an ongoing process and that I should not expect to find any variations in the numbers on an annual basis other than the variations on a month by month basis. QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: NATIONAL ABORIGINAL AND ISLANDER HEALTH ORGANISATION

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have been provided by the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs (Mr Hand) with answers to questions asked in the Senate yesterday, 5 December 1988. There was a series of them. I have no doubt that you will require me to go through them, Mr President.
—They may be relevant to what we are about to debate.
—They may well be. Firstly, there was a request from Senator Crichton-Browne. He asked: Why were attachments to minute 5851 dated 29 August not tabled? The answer states:

ANSWER.PARA: Senator Tate tabled Minute 5851 . . . last Thursday. The purpose of tabling it was to show the Minister's annotation on it. The attachments to the document were tabled by Senator Bolkus yesterday.
Secondly, Senator Boswell asked: Why was Don McDonald not present at the 31 August meeting? The answer states:

This was not the first occasion on which the Minister has conducted meetings without Departmental officers present; however, in this case NAIHO requested a private meeting due to Mr McDonald's longstanding opposition to that organisation. Mr McDonald fully briefed the Minister before the meeting and was available on standby throughout it.

Senator Tambling asked the following questions: Is it true that the 8 November meeting was held only after the Shipton question? Secondly, were minutes produced only after the matter was raised again on 1 December. Thirdly, when and where was the 8 November meeting held? Fourthly, did anyone contact Don McDonald on 1 December to discuss the Shipton question? The answer states:

(i) and (ii) already dealt with by Senator Bolkus in Question Time; (iii) was covered in the statement from Mr Hand; (iv) Mr Hand's Senior Private Secretary, Mr Geoff Pryor phoned Mr McDonald on 1 December to ask him whether he had written the note expected as a result of the November 8 telephone conversation.
Mr McDonald said that he had not; Mr Pryor did not pursue the matter further.

Senator Teague asked this question: Has the private secretary to the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs responded to Mr McDonald's 22 September note asking for advice as to any decision to resume funding to NAIHO? If not, why not? The answer states:
No, because a decision is yet to be made.
Senator Watson asked: Is there any record of the 8 November meeting other than the 1 December record? The answer is no.

Apparently Senator Chaney, in a speech on the motion to take note of the papers tabled, foreshadowed two other questions. The first concerned Glenda Humes's note for file of 18 October. Apparently the question asked: Does the quotation attributed to Harriett Swift-some concern about funding for staff positions-indicate that a decision had been taken, that it was only the amount that needed clarification? Another question arose out of Senator Chaney's speech on the motion to take note of the tabled papers: Do the minutes of 1 September, 15 September, 22 September and 13 October this year and the NAIHO letter of 1 September likewise indicate that a decision had been taken, that only the details of the actual amount needed clarification? The answer to those questions states:
the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs has never attempted to conceal the fact that he was moving towards funding a national representative body in Aboriginal health.
Indeed, this was made clear in his original answer of November 8 to Mr Shipton and has been reiterated on several occasions since.
The meeting with representatives of NAIHO held on August 31 took him one step further in that process.

It is true that some detailed consideration of the proposed NAIHO budget (of the kind referred to by Ms Swift in her conversation with Miss Humes) took place both before and after the August 31 meeting as part of that process.
The outcome of the 31 August meeting fell far short however, of a Ministerial decision to resume funding.

If Mr McDonald had been convinced that a resumption of funding had been directed by the Minister, it was his job to prepare a letter of offer and other formalities. He did not do so for the simple reason that he never received the necessary instruction to do so.
The fact remains that funding for NAIHO has not recommenced. This will only occur if and when the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs approves of such a proposal.

His answer to Mr Shipton remains correct, and indeed, before proceeding to his subsequent supplementary statement in the House on November 8, Mr Hand checked with senior officers, including Mr McDonald, to ensure that they had no doubt about the accuracy of his statement. Had any senior officer, including Mr McDonald, had any doubts about the Minister's reply to Mr Shipton, they were explicitly invited to tell him on that day. The fact is that none, including Mr McDonald, stated any doubts.
They are the answers to questions which arose during Question Time and during debate on a motion yesterday.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Short Sen J.R.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The DEPUTY PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —The President has received the following letter, dated 6 December, from Senator Chaney:

INTERJECT.PARA: Pursuant to Standing Order 64, I give notice that today I propose to move-
`That, in the opinion of the Senate, the following is a matter of urgency:

The need for the Prime Minister to dismiss the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs because of his misleading of Parliament over the question of funding for the National Aboriginal and Islander Health Organisation and the subsequent attempts to falsify the record in defiance of all accepted public service procedures.'
Senator for the State of Western Australia
More than the number of senators required by the Standing Orders having risen in their places-

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That, in the opinion of the Senate, the following is a matter of urgency:

The need for the Prime Minister to dismiss the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs because of his misleading of Parliament over the question of funding for the National Aboriginal and Islander Health Organisation and the subsequent attempts to falsify the record in defiance of all accepted public service procedures.

This is not the time to discuss the appalling fraud that this Government represents on the Aboriginal people of Australia, the lies that it has told them, the way it has brought them into disrepute in the community, with its national land rights and its treaty and all the other nonsense that has distracted it from the orderly administration of government programs. This is not the time to talk about the incompetence of the Ministers who have represented Minister Hand in this place, lawyers both who have brought into this Parliament documents which are, on their faces, inaccurate.

Unfortunately, there is a great deal that we will not have time to encompass in this debate but the point we wish to deal with today is the simple fact that Parliament has been successively misled both in the House of Representatives and in the Senate, on the latest occasion only yesterday in this place. We have seen the subsequent attempts of the Government to cover this up, to lay a smokescreen, to muddy the waters and to distort and pervert the procedures of government. We are raising a matter which goes to the integrity of government and the integrity of the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke). The question is: Will Mr Hawke impose any sorts of standards at all upon his Minister for Aboriginal Affairs (Mr Hand), or will he allow this mess to continue to roll on without any concern being shown on his part? We need look no further back than to the events in the Senate of yesterday if we want to see the clearest possible example of the Senate being misled by a man who is legally qualified and who, in the space of a few minutes, put down a statement on behalf of Minister Hand that was inconsistent with the documents that he himself had tabled on the same day in the Senate.

I do not have time to labour the point, but the simple facts are that this Minister, who is now leaving, Minister Bolkus, came in here and made a statement on behalf of the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs, a statement which said that the first the Minister knew of the Arthur Andersen and Co. report on the National Aboriginal and Islander Health Organisation (NAIHO) was when he got a minute from Mr McDonald on 8 September. Yet the Minister himself produced attachments I and II to the document that was given to the Minister, a document which has been initialled by the Minister and marked for detailed treatment by Mr McDonald, on the day of his meeting with NAIHO. The Minister himself brought in attachments I and II, which make it quite clear that the Minister's attention was drawn, in both of those attachments, to the existence of the Arthur Andersen report. So on the simple statement of the Minister yesterday, that was the first that he had heard of this report. Since this is so important, let me quote his actual words:
This report was compiled before I was Minister and this was the first time it was drawn to my attention.

This is simply one of the more recent examples of this Parliament being misled. We have another document which we believe to be the original briefing note given to the Minister, which makes it clear that when he first became Minister in 1987, these matters were drawn to his attention. It will be interesting to see whether Minister Tate produces that document on behalf of the Government, perhaps tomorrow, long after this debate is dealt with.

The whole sorry episode shows a determination to mislead this Parliament that is akin to when we raised matters with respect to the Estimates Committee. We had the hurried telephone conference after the questions were raised in the House of Representatives and the Senate. Why does the Government deal with these delicate matters by telephone? Why does it demand from a senior officer over the telephone his statement as to whether the Minister's answer was accurate. What a nonsensical way to proceed. No lawyer dealing with a matter of such importance would behave in that way. It would be a quite extraordinary and pathetically unprofessional approach adopted by the Government, if it were not simply a dishonest one.

There are two legs to this Opposition motion. The first is that the Parliament has been misled, and the second is that there has been an attempted falsification of the record, a breach of Public Service procedures. I will not have time to deal with all of those matters, but the other speakers on behalf of the Opposition, Senator Stone and Senator Short, are people who have served in the Public Service, who are aware of the procedures and who, from their dealings with Ministers, are aware of the nonsense that this Minister speaks. On radio this morning he suggested that a decision is made by a Minister only when something is signed. What absolute nonsense! How often do people see Ministers and obtain decisions as was the case in this particular instance, as evidenced by all the documents which were available until the time that this matter was raised in the Parliament?

It is important to get the sequence right and to look at the contemporaneous, as against the subsequently constructed, records. We know that NAIHO was a discredited organisation. We have the independent auditor's report which was tabled just a few days ago and which was drawn to the Minister's attention, when he first became Minister. We know, because the Government has told us, that it was drawn to his attention before he had the meeting with NAIHO at the end of August this year. We know that NAIHO sought renewed funding, and in February 1988 Minister Hand wrote that he was not prepared to agree at that time.

Let me quickly point out to the Senate that that is another example of misrepresentation, of the misleading of this Parliament, as recently as yesterday. We find a clear misstatement by Minister Hand, in the statement made by Minister Bolkus yesterday, as to what he was requiring of NAIHO. He says there was a requirement of restructuring. That is clearly not what was required by the Minister in the letter which was tabled earlier in this place. Again, it is just another example of misleading. There are so many that it is hardly worth pausing on any one of them. We know-there is no dispute over the fact-that Minister Hand met with NAIHO on 31 August 1988 and we know that he was briefed by his Department, given a clear statement of the problems and advised to raise points for evaluation. The Minister was clearly advised by his Department not to agree to funding. He was clearly advised by his Department that points should be raised for evaluation. It was not expected that the Minister would make a decision.

If I may leap ahead to some of the later material put on paper by Mr McDonald, I remind the Senate that in his memorandum of 3 December Mr McDonald made it clear that in the conversation he had with the Minister, the Minister made it clear that he had not expected Mr McDonald to agree with the decision to fund NAIHO. Mr McDonald's response, obviously, was blunt. It all fits together. There is very little that can be suggested is out of place with the reality as it can be clearly demonstrated on the uncontested documents before us. We know that Mr McDonald was, according to the brief, to attend this meeting. It is clear, on the face of the document, that Mr McDonald was to attend. We are not in possession of information as to why the Minister did not have him at the meeting. It is common ground, however, that it was the Minister who spoke to Mr McDonald after the meeting. Indeed, he marked the memorandum back to the Department with these words, `Refer details of meeting to D. McDonald as soon as possible' and it was initialled by the Minister on the date of the meeting. We know that a conversation took place and we have Mr McDonald's account of that conversation. We have, of course, a very valuable piece of external evidence from the organisation concerned, an organisation which has had long experience of dealing with governments. On the very same day as Mr McDonald committed his record of the discussion with the Minister to paper, NAIHO wrote to Mr Hand and said this:
Dear Gerry,

I am writing to follow on from the discussions of yesterday relating to the funding of NAIHO. In undertaking the fine tuning of the agreement reached yesterday, I would ask that we consider the following points.

Then follow points which are utterly consistent with the other documentation which is available to us. The points raised go to the detail of how much and precisely what activities would be funded. There is no suggestion that there is any doubt about the matter of whether or not funding would occur. Indeed, the letter, in its penultimate paragraph, says:
Bearing in mind the Budget position as discussed, we would seek your agreement to a small increase in the indicative figure of $193,000 of $5,000.

Mr McDonald's minute, which has caused a great deal of comment and has had a lot of attention in this place over recent days, was of the same date, 1 September, and part of that minute reads as follows:

At the end of the meeting the Minister informed me that he had approved funding of about $180,000 for NAIHO with effect from 1 December. He would confirm this with a written advice to the Department. In response to a question from me, the Minister agreed that points 1 and 2 and attachment II of the attached brief were an appropriate description of NAIHO's role for the purpose of the letter of offer.

The importance of that is that one can see that there was discussion about the detail of what was to go into this agreement on the part of the Minister in his discussions with Mr McDonald. Therefore, both the organisation itself and the public servant who is dealing with the matter are making it quite clear that they see an agreement as having been concluded, the public servant on the basis of the advice which he has been given by the Minister himself and the organisation on the basis of the conclusion of the quite separate discussion-a point worth making and, indeed, Senator Austin Lewis made the point to me this morning-held with the Minister without the presence of Mr McDonald. The same conclusion was reached by Mr McDonald on the basis of his quite separate discussions with the Minister after that meeting.

I need to deal quite briefly with the fact that there then follows a succession of internal minutes or memoranda within the Department of Aboriginal Affairs, all of which confirm the existence of an agreement and the fact that there is no more than a discussion on detail and quantum. The one minute which has been seriously challenged is that of the senior officers meeting. That challenge needs to be dealt with because it has been used to cast doubt over the general proposition that the Minister's statement in the House of Representatives that he had not agreed to funding was in error. What Mr McDonald said in his memorandum of 3 December was this:

The minutes of the Senior Officers' meeting . . . are partly in error. My recollection is that I reported that the Minister had decided to fund NAIHO. There was some comment from several other officers, including a question about the cost of this decision. I believe that I estimated the cost would be `about $180,000' but do not agree that I said that the Minister had `directed that NAIHO receive $180,000'. As you know, the . . . minutes are a much edited version of proceedings and should not be regarded as anything like a verbatim record.

That is Mr McDonald's explanation of the correction about which so much has been made by the Government. With respect to the further memoranda, I remind the Senate of the note that Mr McDonald put forward on 15 September saying that the Minister's office was to refer details of the meeting to D. McDonald as soon as possible-`They are not here; could they be chased up, please?' There is the note from Mr Pryor-`Geoff somebody says that you were the only official present at the meeting'. There is no challenge to McDonald there or at any later time until the matter was raised in the Parliament. McDonald followed that up with a more formal note on 22 September pointing out that he had not received the details and that until he had received that he would not be in a position to process funding action. Notice again that this is purely a communication on the question of process.
Again on 3 October we find Mr McDonald saying:
I raised the issue of NAIHO funding with Ms Swift and Andrew Jackomos . . . they still had one aspect to sort out.

Again, there is no suggestion that there was anything other than a commitment to funding. Again, we find the same thing in the memorandum which has been made available from Glenda Humes, who says that she raised the question of NAIHO funding again with Harriett Swift, who apologised for the delay in sending the Department relevant information concerning the funding. She said:
. . . there is some concern about the precise amount needed and that 2 staff positions (. . . funded by DEET) needed to be sorted out.
It seems pretty clear from these minutes that the Department is proceeding on the basis of funding having been approved and the detail still being a matter for discussion and agreement.
We then get to what happened in Parliament itself. The Minister was asked, in a series of questions by Mr Shipton, this question:
Has the Minister recommenced funding to that organisation; and if so, on what grounds?
In what was a very loose answer-that is the expression that was used by Mr McDonald-the Minister said this:
. . . I have met with representatives of that body and have discussed funding arrangements for the future. I am yet to make a decision.

The Opposition does not rely only on the inaccuracy of that particular statement. As I said earlier in the debate, it is quite clear that in the statement made by the Minister, through the mouth of Senator Bolkus only yesterday-a statement that was in writing and from the Minister's office-there have been other misrepresentations to this Parliament. One of the key points made by the Opposition is that that statement is simply not in accord with the facts as they are described in great detail by Mr McDonald in his memorandum of 3 December.

There is no doubt that the water has been muddied by the extraordinary minute of 1 December, which purports to be a record of a telephone conversation which took place on 8 November. Much has been made of that minute in defence of the Minister. I can only say that it is an extraordinary procedure that when a matter has been raised in the Parliament and dealt with by telephone conference we have a situation where nothing is committed to writing-or nothing committed to writing has been shown to the Opposition-until 1 December when the matter was further raised in both the Senate and the House of Representatives. It was not until Senator Tambling had raised this matter again in the Senate that this three-week-old note was put down. We find it contains the interesting proposition that Mr McDonald agreed to provide a minute confirming the telephone conversation of 8 November.

I ask those people who are seeking to make a judgment on these papers to mark the attention that Mr McDonald gave to the follow-up of his discussion with the Minister of 31 August-a discussion which involved Mr McDonald getting what, I am told, was the unwelcome news for the Department that the Minister was to fund NAIHO. We find Mr McDonald consistently putting in writing his concerns at the lack of follow-up to that conversation and that decision. We find nothing after the allegation from the senior officers that Mr McDonald had been asked to provide a minute. We now have Mr McDonald's own explanation for that. He says that he was not asked to do that. I simply ask those senators who have to make a decision on this: Is it not extraordinary that he was so conscientious in committing things to paper before 8 November and so slack-if we are to believe that that request was made-in failing to do so after 8 November?

We find this to be a very peculiar minute which focuses only on the record of the senior officers meeting of 5 September and says that Mr McDonald and the Minister were in agreement that the senior officers' minutes were not correct. We now have Mr McDonald's explanation to the extent to which he says those senior officers' minutes are not correct. That is a matter which in no way relieves Mr Hand from responsibility for misleading the House of Representatives.
In terms of the minute of 2 December, which Mr McDonald provided in response to a request from the Secretary, Mr McDonald said-and the Senate will recall that this was over the telephone:

The Minister read . . . the text of an answer he had given earlier that day to a question about his `decision' to fund NAIHO. I confirmed that the answer was accurate and consistent with my recollection of his advice to me after his meeting with NAIHO some weeks earlier.
That sits oddly with the suggestion that the Minister misled the House on that particular occasion. However, we again have Mr McDonald's own explanation for that. On 3 December Mr McDonald stated:

I do not agree that I accepted that the Minister had not approved funding to NAIHO. I have never had any doubt that he had agreed to fund it. As I indicated in my note to you of 2 December, I agreed in our conversation that the Minister's answer was `consistent' with my recollection of the 31 August meeting. I thought then, and still do, that the answer the Minister gave in the House was loose enough to be `consistent', particularly in view of the possibility of DEET funding and the doubts which had probably been raised in the Minister's mind by the audit report.

I conclude this segment of the debate by simply reminding the Senate that in this memorandum Mr McDonald asserts not once, not twice, but three times that there was absolutely no doubt in his mind at the end of the meeting of 31 August with NAIHO that the Minister had decided to fund NAIHO with effect from 1 December.

It is quite clear that Mr McDonald, having been put in a very difficult situation by the Minister in a telephone call, is asserting very clearly the position as it was conveyed to him by the Minister. The administration of this Government in this area has been cheap, it has been dishonest, it has tried to hide the truth and it requires the dismissal of this Minister.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable senator's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —A very serious accusation has been raised concerning the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs (Mr Hand). Basically it is that he misled the House of Representatives in particular; but there is a call on the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) to dismiss the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs because of his misleading of Parliament over the question of funding for the National Aboriginal and Islander Health Organisation (NAIHO) and the subsequent attempts to falsify the record in defiance of all accepted Public Service procedures. The fact is that that particular allegation cannot at all be sustained. As for misleading the Parliament, I think we need to go back to the very core and element of this particular allegation. It revolves around an answer given to Mr Shipton in the other place on 8 November 1988. The relevant question was:

SPEECH.PARA: Has the Minister recommenced funding to that organisation;-
being the National Aboriginal and Islander Health Organisation-
and if so, on what grounds?
Mr Hand replied:
. . . I have met with representatives of that body and have discussed funding arrangements for the future. I am yet to make a decision.

That remains the fact. Mr Hand is yet to make a decision in relation to the funding of the National Aboriginal and Islander Health Organisation. That particular answer given in the House of Representatives was confirmed as accurate by the very senior officers who gathered in Mr Hand's office on 8 November. Those present were Mr G. Pryor, Mr R. Winroe, Mr D. O'Rourke, Mr M. Strokowsky and Miss H. Swift. This is what is recorded in a memorandum signed by those present on 1 December:

The matter of NAIHO was discussed and it was agreed that the Minister should telephone McDonald concerning the Senior Officer Meeting of 5 September as the record of that meeting incorrectly recorded that the Minister had made a funding decision in respect of NAIHO.
The Minister then telephoned Mr McDonald in the presence of the abovementioned officers; the conversation was on the conference line it was clear to those in attendance that:-

(A) Mr McDonald and the Minister were in agreement that the Senior Officer Meeting minutes were not correct as the Minister had not approved funding to NAIHO, as NAIHO had been asked to revise their proposal; and
(B) Mr McDonald agreed to provide a minute confirming the telephone conversation.

Immediately following the answer we have that discussion with Mr McDonald-I will obviously make clear, in the absence of Mr McDonald's physical presence, why his taking part in that conversation was important-an indication from those senior officers, including Mr McDonald, that the Minister's answer was, indeed, accurate. On 2 December Mr McDonald, having been asked to recollect a telephone conversation he had with the Minister on that subject on 8 November, stated:

The Minister then read me the text of an answer he had given earlier that day to a question about his `decision' to fund NAIHO. I confirmed that the answer was accurate and consistent with my recollection of his advice to me after his meeting with NAIHO some weeks earlier.
He then stated:
I have since read the relevant Hansard, which was consistent with the Minister's earlier reading to me, and have no reason to change my view on the accuracy of his reply.

There we have it only a few days ago. The officer who is mainly concerned in this particular matter and upon whom the members of the Opposition must rely to make out their case that the Minister misled the Parliament, was saying-not merely under the pressure of some phone call that he received from the Minister when he was undertaking other duties in the Perth office, but after he had had the time to read at leisure the relevant Hansard-that he had no reason to change his earlier point of view that the Minister's answer was accurate and consistent with Mr McDonald's recollection of the Minister's advice to Mr McDonald after the meeting with NAIHO at the end of August.
There it is. There could not be anything plainer. But what has to be looked to is the real genesis of members of the Opposition's concern about this matter.

TALK.START.PARA: —What about the memo of 3 December?

—I am coming to the memo of 3 December, the honourable senator will be pleased to know. Let us not jump ahead of ourselves. What needs to be contrasted with that clear and unambiguous statement by Mr McDonald on 2 December-it is consistent with what is recorded by senior officers on 1 December relating to a conversation held on 8 November-is the minutes of the senior officers group of 5 September. It is recorded in those minutes-the record having been made by an officer who is named at the head of the record of proceedings-that Mr McDonald made this contribution concerning the funding of the National Aboriginal and Islander Health Organisation. He was purported to have stated:

SPEECH.PARA: At a meeting with the Minister on Thursday 1 September, the Minister directed that NAIHO receive $180,000 this year in funding. This is to be confirmed in writing.

Senators will recall that it is that minute of the senior officers group of 5 September, the record of proceedings, which provided the whole basis for this series of agitated questions asked by senators both at Question Time and in consideration of the appropriations. The fact is that that minute is inaccurate. The authority for saying that it is inaccurate is Mr McDonald himself. In the minute of 3 December, Mr McDonald stated:

The minutes of the Senior Officers' meeting of September 5 are partly in error. My recollection is that I reported that the Minister had decided to fund NAIHO. There was some comment from several other officers including a question about the cost of this decision. I believe that I estimated the cost would be `about $160,000' but do not agree that I said that the Minister had `directed that NAIHO would receive $180,000'. As you know, the SOM minutes are a much edited version of proceedings and should not be regarded as anything like a verbatim record.

In fact, those particular minutes were taken by members of the Opposition over the last several days as not only a verbatim record of what transpired at that meeting, but as indicating Mr McDonald's true state of mind. They do not. In so far as much of their claim that Mr Hand misled the Parliament has been based on their now revealed as false notion that he directed that NAIHO receive $180,000, then I believe that their case can quickly be seen to be without any firm foundation. Mr McDonald himself repudiated those minutes and claimed that they were not an accurate record of his recollection of the events of 1 September. This is despite the fact that it lay on the record and would have been known to Mr McDonald and others for the period from 5 September to 3 December, almost three months. Nevertheless, even though it was allowed to lie on the record it does not accurately reflect at all what he told that senior officers meeting.

I suppose the proof of the matter is in the fact that if, as it is said, Mr Hand decided that there was to be funding for the National Aboriginal and Islander Health Organisation, it is odd that months later one can find no evidence whatsoever-because there is no such evidence-that any funding occurred. No funding has occurred. There has been no funding of the National Aboriginal and Islander Health Organisation whatsoever. There has been no authorisation of funds; no approval of money has been directed. Senator Chaney said he thought it was nonsense for us to be looking for some sort of written record of the Minister's authorising the funding of the National Aboriginal and Islander Health Organisation. The honourable senator wants to talk about proper public administration, and it is also one of the charges laid against the Minister that he is revealed in this sequence of events as not engaging in the proper administration of his portfolio. I would have thought it was absolutely essential that where there is a funding decision by a Minister it be recorded properly. Certainly, that is the practice of Ministers as far as I know. I am sure Senator Newman, who is looking at me, would have expected Mr Newman, when he carried a portfolio, if he authorised a particular funding decision to note it in the normal way, following the usual course in which documents are presented to Ministers for authorisation.

TALK.START.PARA: —Wouldn't you rather be on the other side?

—No, I am quite content to be here because, as I say, the fact is that there has been no authorisation of funds to flow to, and no approval of moneys being directed to, the National Aboriginal and Islander Health Organisation. There is not a skerrick of paper to that effect, no note saying it has been approved or not approved, with the `not approved' struck out, which is the normal practice, and the `approved' being signed by the Minister. There is nothing like that.
—Just a covering of tracks; a rewriting of history.

—Senator Newman will search in vain for anything like that. Nothing will be found. I am absolutely astonished that Senator Chaney should think that the funding of an organisation to the tune of $200,000 should be made without any written authorisation by the Minister to that effect. All we have is a series of discussions as to possible funding formulas or options if the Minister wished to carry his disposition through to a decision to fund. He has never denied that he was disposed to fund what he took to be a revamped National Aboriginal and Islander Health Organisation if in fact it could be shown that it was worthy of such funding. He has indicated that he is favourably disposed, but nothing could properly be done until a number of deliberations and discussions had been undertaken. Of course, nothing was done.

SPEECH.PARA: Further, the suggestion that there has been some attempt to falsify the records is a grave charge. There has been no attempt to rewrite history, as has been asserted by Mr McDonald. The fact is that there is no need to make such allegations if one understands that the way in which the matter was raised in the House of Representatives on 8 November naturally alerted the Minister to ensure that his answer was indeed accurate. That is a very normal response by a Minister to--

TALK.START.PARA: —Not to rewriting records.

—He has not rewritten any records. He sought from the officer primarily involved, Mr McDonald, after Question Time on 8 November a recollection of the events which occurred. That recollection is as outlined on 1 December 1988. Once again Senator Chaney asks us not to believe this point. But the officers present-Mr Pryor, Mr Winroe, Mr O'Rourke, Mr Strokowsky and Miss Swift-all indicate that Mr McDonald had agreed to provide a minute confirming that telephone conversation. I believe that, had that been forthcoming at that time, the Senate would have been spared much of this debate. Indeed, Mr McDonald did provide a minute, as we know, on 2 December, which once again, without going into it at length, makes it abundantly clear that he agreed that the answer given by the Minister was accurate and consistent with his recollection of the matter. That answer was not given just on the basis of an attempt to deal with a telephone conversation; it was given by the Minister with the Hansard in front of him and therefore with the ability to consider the matter more leisurely.

SPEECH.PARA: When the conversations which form the subject of this particular attempt to indicate that the Minister misled the Parliament are taken as a whole they indicate that quite proper discussions took place to ascertain the sources of funding within this portfolio and others should the National Aboriginal and Islander Health Organisation funding have got the proper ministerial green light. As far as the amounts and the sources were concerned, it is quite clear that a lot of work had to be done to enable the Minister to come to a properly considered decision rather than give it some quick deliberation which could then be the subject of criticism.

It is not surprising, though Senator Chaney makes much of it, that the organisation concerned chose to speak as though an agreement had been reached. I have been in many situations where persons with whom one is negotiating or who are lobbying one try to convey at the end of the meeting the impression not just that a sympathetic hearing has been given but also that agreement has been reached and a decision has been arrived at in their favour. This is not a particularly odd occurrence in correspondence and when dealing with people's recollections.

In relation to the audit report by Arthur Andersen and Co., which was discussed in the chamber yesterday, the fact is, as I think I indicated during Question Time, that Mr Hand wanted, or at least needed, to be aware of the deliberations and considerations which went into the findings and the recommendations of that particular report, which were not provided to him until the time indicated in the relevant document. Mr Hand, as indicated by Mr McDonald's memorandum, was not in possession of the Arthur Andersen report but needed to be. Mr McDonald was so conscious of the need for his Minister to have a copy of the report that, noting, no doubt, that in the transition from one Minister to another the report possibly had not been made available, he quite properly undertook the task of bringing that report to the Minister.

The fact is that in all these matters the Minister has acted as he ought to have done; namely, in giving an answer to Mr Shipton he answered absolutely honestly and accurately, and the recollection of the Minister at Question Time on 8 November 1988 has been vindicated, verified and substantiated by Mr McDonald not only in general telephone conversations after that Question Time, as recorded in the minute of 1 December, but in a very specific paragraph of Mr McDonald's minute of 2 December.

TALK.START.PARA: —With his arm up his back?

—It is a very grave accusation for the honourable senator to make, that Mr McDonald was put under such inordinate pressure that, to use the honourable senator's term, he had his arm twisted up his back. The honourable senator is suggesting that Mr McDonald gave an inaccurate and improper response and I am sure that he would not have done that. The fact is that the Minister's answer of 8 November is accurate and, by no stretch of the imagination, misled the Parliament. It has been vindicated and authorised, as it were, by Mr McDonald in his recollection as recorded in the minute of 2 December. I believe that much of the heat in this matter has a catalyst in the senior officers meeting of 5 December, at least as recorded in minutes which are now agreed by Mr McDonald to be inaccurate; to have not conveyed at all what he told the meeting; and, therefore, to have not conveyed at all his recollection of the truth of that meeting. The Government rejects this motion and finds that it has no substance.
—Order! The Minister's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macklin Sen M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —We are debating an urgency motion brought forward by the Opposition in the following terms:

SPEECH.PARA: The need for the Prime Minister to dismiss the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs because of his misleading of Parliament over the question of funding for the National Aboriginal and Islander Health Organisation and the subsequent attempts to falsify the record in defiance of all accepted public service procedures.

We are dealing with two items and I do not think the second item has yet been addressed in this debate. The first item deals with the answer given in the House of Representatives by the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs (Mr Hand) in response to a question put to him by Mr Shipton. The second item refers to a question that was raised today in Question Time by Senator Tambling regarding a statement put down by Senator Bolkus on behalf of the Minister for Justice (Senator Tate) yesterday in Question Time and where that statement will lead us.

I say at the outset that our view with regard to this matter is somewhat tinged by the exercise that we believe is probably being conducted by the Opposition-that is, an attempt to bolster its policy on Aboriginal affairs-to which my Party is in total opposition. We believe that it is a policy that will only be to the detriment of the Aboriginal people of this country. It purports, amongst a whole host of things, to suggest that Aboriginal people should have equal treatment. There is nothing wrong with equal treatment but, as I stated in a notice of motion in this chamber last week, if Aboriginal people in this country were treated equally their health budget would be far in excess of what it is at the moment. In fact, they have the worst health record and the highest infant mortality rate of any minority group in the world. If equal treatment is to mean anything there should be equality of outcome. Likewise, when land is stolen from the white people in this country it is generally returned to them. When land is stolen from Aboriginals it is said to be something nice. I am quite happy with equal treatment. We totally dissociate ourselves from the Opposition's policy statement.

This item does not deal with policy; it deals with the attitude of the Minister to Parliament in giving Parliament information. In the various documents that are before us the first matter that is raised refers to the answer given by Mr Hand in which he said:

Thirdly, I have met with representatives of that body and have discussed funding arrangements for the future. I am yet to make a decision. I point out that a national inquiry is being conducted by both the States and the Commonwealth regarding future health care policy for Aboriginal people; and that body will be reporting back in February.
I think the next sentence is also pertinent:
Because of the restructuring I had hoped to have discussions with representatives from NAIHO, if it could be worked out with them, about funding arrangements in December.

In other words, there is a clear implication that a decision is in train and that, if it could be worked out, money would be flowing as early as December. From other documents we know that that is 1 December. I do not think there is any doubt in this range of documents that the Minister was of the view that, pending a number of items, he intended to allow money to go back to the National Aboriginal and Islander Health Organisation (NAIHO). Unfortunately, what we are stuck with in this debate is when a decision is a decision for the purposes of the Minister. That is a very difficult one. I believe that in terms of ministerial arrangements the way in which these things are done is fairly idiosyncratic. I imagine that it differs from department to department and from Minister to Minister. Undoubtedly, it is a process in which the Minister receives advice from a number of departmental officers and people in his own office. He reaches a certain decision and that decision might then be put to relevant people. Negotiations and changes may then take place with regard to that decision. A final proposition would then be made in regard to a level of funding that might be given to a particular body. Decisions under those organisations are a process not a point, and I think it is fairly clear that the Minister had embarked on that process. I think it is equally clear that he had not finished that process, at least up till now.

In addressing these documents our position on that question is that we do not believe we have been presented with sufficient evidence to prove the case that the Opposition is putting forward. It may be that those documents are in existence. Obviously, with the leaking of documents from the Department which is going on, those documents may very well turn up. I do not think one can say that, on that basis, the Minister is innocent either. In fact, on the basis of these documents one would have to say that the whole issue smells. But I do not think one could actually say that, on that question, the issue has been proven. I think it is quite a reasonable exercise for a Minister to make a statement that a decision had not been made if he had not finally agreed to sign the paper releasing the money.

However, I believe that the other matter, that raised by Senator Tambling earlier this afternoon, is quite different. It relates to answers given yesterday by Senator Bolkus. I hasten to say that I do not think this has anything to do with Senator Bolkus. He was carrying out his job as Minister representing the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs, and clearly his statement yesterday is-and it is represented in the Hansard in this way-a statement from the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs. It says:
In a minute dated September 8th reference was made to an Auditor-General's report on NAIHO. This report was compiled before I was Minister and this was the first time it was drawn to my attention.

I had not seen that statement but when Senator Tambling raised that matter this afternoon it certainly rang bells with me. A Minister coming into his ministry obviously has a detailed briefing. I find it inconceivable that senior officers-it is probably a matter where the senior officers should be sacked if this occurred-would give a Minister a briefing in which that item would be excluded. It just does not sound credible.

I went on a hunting expedition which was finally aborted by Senator Tambling turning up some more material from the little fax machine that he has which seems to have a direct link to the filing cabinets in the Department of Aboriginal Affairs and, when he asks a question, the filing cabinet provides him with the material. Because this material does not have a date on it, I do not know whether this is actually the material in question. Unfortunately we are in the situation of not being able to make a determination until we hear the next speaker as to whether--

TALK.START.PARA: —That is why I asked the Minister to table it.

—I accept Senator Tambling's interjection. I will provide a copy of this material to the Minister. I have written `July 87' on it because it is probably part of the briefing note; it certainly reads like one. It is headed `National Aboriginal and Islander Health Organisation (NAIHO)' and sets out the issue, the current position and the background. It gets to the point on page 2. It states:

SPEECH.PARA: On 7 May 1986, the Minister instructed that the accounts and administrative practices be audited in depth. The independent professional auditor, Arthur Andersen and Co.-
I interpolate that the Minister's correction to his own answer in the House of Representatives on 8 November referred to Andersen and Co., so he knew about it on 8 November at least-
found that NAIHO's system of internal control over operations and finances was inadequate . . .
and so it goes on. The last part states:
. . . such contract projects would depend on NAIHO's putting in place an acceptable core administrative establishment and implementing the recommendations of the Arthur Andersen report.

I have to deal with vast amounts of paper, as does every senator in this place. If the Minister had said yesterday in his answer to Senator Bolkus, `This report was compiled before I was a Minister and this is the first time I have ever had a chance to read it', I would have accepted that explanation-one does not expect superhuman efforts by Ministers-but he did not say that. He said that this was the first time it was drawn to his attention. He did not even have to read it. It simply had to have been drawn to his attention. If that is correct, the report was drawn to his attention. I do not believe that any other construction can be put on that information.

It may seem to people who are listening to this debate that this is rather a trivial point, but the document the Minister provided yesterday was by way of a defence document. Presumably it was very carefully worked over. If it was not, there might even be reason for sacking some people. It was very carefully worked over; it had to have been. That was a statement that presumably the Minister himself vetted. If the Minister vetted the statement that Senator Bolkus brought in here yesterday it should have rung bells. He must have known that it had been drawn to his attention before. There may be other constructions that I have not thought of, and that is why I say that, on that issue at least, we are not able to make a determination. At this moment I cannot imagine that there could be any satisfactory explanation brought forward. On any fair reading of this matter-not the original question, which we believe is not proven-and starting where we started, which is from the point of view that the Minister is innocent, and not from where I think the Opposition started, which is that the Minister is guilty, I do not think it takes us to the point where if we were sitting on a jury we would want to deliver a guilty verdict. However, on the second question I find it inescapable that the Minister has in fact misled the Senate, not the House of Representatives. In terms of that part of Senator Chaney's motion, which refers to `. . . subsequent attempts to falsify the record in defiance of all accepted public service procedures', I have to wait because, as I said, I do not know whether that second document is authentic.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is a misleading of the Parliament that is claimed, not a misleading of the House of Representatives.

—Yes, but this document has not been vouched for by anybody yet and I do not know where it came from. I am simply saying that if that document was in the briefing notes in July 1987 I believe the Minister has misled the Senate in terms of the document that he produced through Senator Bolkus yesterday. Misleading the Senate is extremely serious, and so it should be, because we have to rely on what we are told by Ministers. That is the only way in which this place can operate. It is a serious matter. I will be listening carefully to subsequent speakers, who I hope will be able to say whether this document exists and whether this document is part of the briefing notes and, if so, what explanation they could possibly have for another document coming in here and the Minister saying, `This is the very first time that this has been drawn to my attention'. It is obvious that it was drawn to his attention, or should have been drawn to his attention, in July 1987. If this document is correct it was drawn to his attention in July 1987.
—What about the briefing notes of August 1988?
—I only have a quarter of an hour.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Stone Sen J.O.

TALKER.NAME: Senator STONE
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to pick up the debate this afternoon at about the point at which Senator Macklin left off. The extraordinary thing about the development of this issue is the manner in which-as Senator Macklin implied and may even have said-it has been transformed in the past 24 or 36 hours from an accusation or a question about the behaviour of the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs (Mr Hand) in misleading the House of Representatives, and I do not resile in any way from that charge, to a further charge, which Senator Macklin has quite rightly said is at least as serious and I suppose to most honourable senators it might be regarded as even more serious, of misleading the Senate. Let us take the particular passage in the Minister's defence which was read into the Hansard yesterday in this place by the Minister for Consumer Affairs (Senator Bolkus), who was temporarily representing the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs because of the absence through illness of Senator Tate. We are glad to see him back here today. There is a passage in that defence by the Minister, prepared, as Senator Macklin said, as a defence document and therefore presumably very carefully prepared, which says that until the receipt of a minute from his Department dated 8 September 1988, the audit report by Arthur Andersen and Co. into the financial administration of the National Aboriginal and Islander Health Organisation had not been brought to his attention. They were the Minister's words.

SPEECH.PARA: Let us examine that claim. I will come back to the other aspects of the matter in due course but it is very important to pursue this point now, it having been so cogently raised by Senator Macklin and by Senator Chaney, who spoke earlier. The previous Minister for Aboriginal Affairs, Mr Clyde Holding, underwent a process of education in the portfolio, as all Ministers in that portfolio seem to do. As a consequence he caused NAIHO to be investigated by Arthur Andersen and Co. As a consequence of the very damning report which it submitted and which was tabled in this place yesterday, Mr Holding ordered that funding for NAIHO cease at 31 December 1986.
