When subsequently Mr Hand became Minister for Aboriginal Affairs, as was pointed out in the question asked here earlier this afternoon by my National Party colleague Senator Tambling, the Minister would have received the normal briefing documents from the Department bringing to his attention all matters and issues which in the Department's view required his attention. I presided over the preparation of many such documents and they follow a set pattern. They are brief, they are to the point, and they raise issues which the Department believes the Minister needs to know about. There is not the slightest doubt in my mind that the Department would have taken the view that in relation to NAIHO the Arthur Andersen report was a matter which the Minister needed to know about. Indeed the Department took that view because, we have been told by Senator Macklin a moment ago, there is now in the possession of at least honourable senators on this side of the chamber a document which we believe to be the briefing paper in question. We trust that before very long the Minister now representing the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs in this place, Senator Tate, will confirm that by tabling an authenticated copy of the same document from the brief which went to Minister Hand in July 1987. I quote from one or two passages of that document because it makes it perfectly clear that the Minister was made aware of the existence of this document in the first days of his coming to office. The briefing paper states:

The independent professional auditor, Arthur Andersen and Co., found that NAIHO's system of internal control of operations and finance was inadequate, as was the information and advice provided to the Minister, the Department and other government organisations. . . NAIHO's response to the report was to reject some key aspects of the report, conditionally to accept others, and to demand over $1.75m to implement appropriate recommendations, and a further $22,000 for a full NAIHO executive meeting.
The minute goes on to say:
The Minister-
that is, Mr Holding-

found this ignoring of the major thrust of the report quite unacceptable and personally met with NAIHO officers on 22 September and advised them that DAA direct grants to NAIHO would continue only to the end of 1986.

So it went on. Clearly, the Minister was in possession of that document. Yet the statement by the Minister has been placed before this chamber that 8 September 1988 was the first time that this document was `drawn to his attention'-not read in full, but `drawn to his attention'. Let us have another look at the substance and veracity of that claim. One of the documents tabled in this place on 1 December-that is, last Thursday-was a letter dated 15 February 1988 from the Minister to Mr Shane Houston who rejoices in the title of National Coordinator of NAIHO. In that letter the Minister referred to a meeting which he had had with representatives of NAIHO on 27 January relating to a proposed budget for NAIHO. The Minister said that he was not prepared to agree to their proposals at that time. My point in mentioning this document is this: anyone familiar with Public Service procedures would understand that before the Minister had that meeting with NAIHO representatives, he would have had another specific briefing from his Department-as far as we can see this may have been the first such meeting he had with NAIHO-about the matters he should have in mind when dealing with that organisation.

I say to the Minister representing the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs in this place, through you, Madam Acting Deputy President, that we in the Opposition would be grateful if the Minister would examine the record in that respect also and table, for the information of the Senate, any such briefing paper that went to the Minister in advance of the meeting of 27 January. We will see whether there was any mention in that briefing paper-if such a briefing existed-of the Arthur Andersen report. Certainly, if there had been such a mention, how could the Minister say, through his mouthpiece yesterday, that 8 September this year was the first time the report had been `drawn to his attention'?

TALK.START.PARA: —That is clearly and obviously wrong.

—As Senator Chaney interjects, that is clearly and obviously wrong, and it is clearly and obviously misleading the Senate. I come back to later events commencing with the meeting between the Minister and NAIHO representatives on 31 August 1988, to which there has been a lot of reference already. As Senator Chaney said, there was a briefing minute on 29 August to the Minister by Mr McDonald, which has been tabled in this place, for the purpose of that meeting. That minute was seen by the Minister because it carries his personal annotation sending it back to the Department and asking, `Refer details of meeting to D. McDonald as soon as possible'. The minute refers to attachment I and attachment II which were tabled in this place yesterday because Senator Tate failed to table them last Thursday, no doubt through inadvertence. Both attachments to that document referred to the Arthur Andersen report. They are not lengthy, involved or complicated attachments. The first is a single page which states in part:

SPEECH.PARA: It makes-
that is, the submission to the Minister from NAIHO-
no indication that any attempt has been made to address issues of concern identified by Arthur Andersen in its 1986 audit report.

There it is in black and white in an attachment to a minute which went to the Minister on 29 August, which the Minister has clearly seen. As Senator Chaney said in the Senate earlier, there was more detailed reference to the Arthur Andersen report in attachment II to the document. Mr McDonald recorded a note for file about that meeting, which he was excluded from attending even though he was the senior officer in the Department and supposedly responsible for dealing with these matters. He noted:
At the end of the meeting the Minister informed me that he had approved funding of about-
note the word `about'-
$180,000 for NAIHO with effect from 1 December. He would confirm this with a written advice to the Department.
The final sentence of Mr McDonald's minute has not received much attention. I draw the Senate's attention to that sentence which reads:

In response to a question from me, the Minister agreed that points 1 and 2 in attachment II of the attached brief were an appropriate description of NAIHO's role for the purpose of the letter of offer.

Two points arise from that. The first is that Mr McDonald there records that he personally drew the Minister's attention to attachment II to the briefing minute. There can be no question that the Minister saw attachment II, if there was any question in the first place. Secondly, Mr McDonald records that the Minister agreed that the two points referred to serve as an appropriate description of NAIHO's role `for the purpose of the letter of offer'. One does not write a letter of offer unless one has decided to fund. One may have not decided finally on the amount of funding down to the last $1,000 or $5,000, as NAIHO itself pleaded, but one has decided to fund. That makes a nonsense of the Minister's subsequent claim in the other place that no decision had been made. That view is strongly confirmed by the letter written by Mr Houston and the other NAIHO representative at the meeting of 31 August to the Minister on the following day-that is, 1 September-following up. They began their letter by saying:
I am writing to follow on from the discussions of yesterday . . . In undertaking the fine tuning of the agreement reached yesterday . . .

There was also the record of the departmental senior officers' meeting which I think Senator Chaney has already dealt with at some length. I do not propose to go over the same ground. There was a series of relatively insignificant minutes-on their face-following that meeting, the first being a handwritten note from Mr McDonald to Mr West, who I think is in the Minister's office, saying that the Minister's office was to `Refer details of the meeting to D. McDonald as soon as possible'. `They aren't here. Can't they be chased up, please?' On 22 August Mr McDonald wrote again-this time to the Senior Private Secretary-saying:
I have not yet received these details, particularly those relating to the level of the Minister's funding approval.

Following that minute, did Mr McDonald receive a question from the Minister's office and the Senior Private Secretary saying, `What funding approval? The Minister has not decided to make any funding to NAIHO yet'? Did any such minute issue? Not a bit of it. It was only subsequently, on 1 December or, as the officers in question allege on 8 November, that they purportedly came to the view that no such funding agreement had been arrived at. There was never any process back to the Department to question this stream of minutes which went from Mr McDonald. There was no attempt to question at that stage the record of the senior officers' meeting of 5 September which gave the same understanding. There was no attempt at any time to do things required by normal public service process and procedure.

The clear implication is: firstly, that the Minister did mislead the House of Representatives on 8 November when he replied to the question from the honourable member for Higgins, Mr Shipton. Secondly, after having given that answer, there was a hurried conference in the Minister's office between five people, including three departmental officers. A conversation then took place between the Minister and the hapless Mr McDonald in Perth. Through that course we have had an attempt to rewrite the history of this matter.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! Senator Stone, your time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Collins Sen R.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —Both the first and second parts of this motion have to fail. With respect to the comments made by Senator Macklin on the second part of the motion, I think it is fair to say that the Opposition currently has a new toy to play with. I think the question about statements made in the Senate yesterday regarding previous advice to the Minister on the audit report is something that has only just recently been discovered. The second part of the motion states:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . subsequent attempts to falsify the record in defiance of all accepted public service procedures . . .

This in fact refers to the senior officers' meeting which questioned the version of events given by Mr McDonald. I draw the Democrats' attention to the fact that the second part of the motion does talk about `public service procedures' rather than parliamentary procedures. It is a clear reference to the statement made by Mr McDonald on 3 December that people were trying to rewrite history. I intend to deal with that issue separately.

So far as the most substantive part of this motion is concerned-there is no question as to what constitutes the most substantive part of the motion-that the Minister should resign because he misled Parliament, he most clearly did not mislead Parliament at all. If one refers to the actual questions and answers, he gave two answers to the Parliament; one on 8 November and one on 1 December. Both of those answers were absolutely correct. It is important that the Senate take note of the context in which the first question was asked by Mr Shipton on 8 November. He said:
Has the Minister recommenced funding to that organisation-
that is, NAIHO-
and if so, on what grounds?
In answer to that question, the Minister said:
I am yet to make a decision.

That answer was absolutely correct. In respect of providing a decision for which the Minister was properly accountable to the Parliament, he had not made a decision. It is a fact that in this plethora of documents which have been tabled in the Parliament, not a single document exists which directs the Department to take the necessary action required following a proper ministerial decision to fund NAIHO. In fact, Mr McDonald's interpretation of events claims that the funding was to commence on 1 December. To this day, 6 December, demonstrably no such funding has gone to NAIHO and the documents which have been tabled demonstrate that that is the case.

The Democrats made the appropriate point that, if one reads these documents with a predisposition to judge the Minister guilty, one could interpret them as leading to that conclusion. If one were fair and read the documents dispassionately, one would find the reality is that they indicate that there was no such decision. One can go back to 15 February this year, when there was a letter from the Minister to Mr Houston, who headed NAIHO. I will confine myself to reading the final paragraph because of time constraints. It states:

As I indicated to you at our meeting on 27 January, I am not prepared to agree to your proposal at this time, although I remain open to any suggestions which may emerge from my forthcoming meetings with Aboriginal people throughout Australia or from the National Conference of Aboriginal Health Services in Sydney in February. I would expect, however, that any arrangement which I will be able to approve would need to cost substantially less than the $448,000 which your budget proposes.

The letter of 1 September from NAIHO, upon which the Opposition places such great weight, also indicates clearly that there was no final ministerial decision for which the Minister is accountable to Parliament. The second last paragraph of that letter reads:
Bearing in mind the budget position as discussed, we would seek your agreement to a small increase in the indicative figure of $193,000 of $5,000.
I stress the words `indicative figure'. It is an indication--

TALK.START.PARA: —Of the funding-the size of the funding decision taken.

—I say to the honourable senator that I am perfectly capable of making my own points and I listened to him in complete silence. It is an indicative figure. If the Minister had attempted to mislead the Parliament by saying that he was opposed to NAIHO receiving any funding, perhaps there would be some purpose in the Opposition's motion. The Minister has made it perfectly clear to the Parliament-not once, but twice-that he is fundamentally in favour of funding NAIHO. There is no secret about that. The Minister conveyed to the Parliament quite forthrightly that he is predisposed to refund this organisation, provided it is restructured. There is no question at all that the Minister discussed potential funding for NAIHO, because he is on the public record of the Parliament as having said that. The question is: What constitutes a decision upon which the Minister is properly accountable to the Parliament? The Leader of the Opposition, Senator Chaney, gave a fascinating interview with Pru Goward this morning. I think, considering Fred's record as Leader of the Opposition--
—Please refer to him properly.

—I thought it was a fairly friendly salutation. If the honourable senator wants me to abuse the Leader of the Opposition instead, I will. Anyone can call me Bob. As far as Fred's record as Minister for Aboriginal Affairs is concerned-and it was a good one-he was far more precise in applying the tests to his own decision making than he applied to Minister Hand in his interview this morning. Pru Goward asked the question:

SPEECH.PARA: But his basic defence-
that is, Gerry Hand's defence-
is that he has never denied that he supports re-funding the health organisation?
That is correct. The Minister said that in Parliament. Senator Chaney replied:

We're reduced to playing with words, Pru. I mean, and at that stage he hadn't. But what he replied in the Parliament was that he had yet to make a decision. And yet the contemporaneous documents, the documents that were prepared back at that time, at the end of August, the beginning of September, make it quite clear that he had made a decision. It wasn't a decision which was final as to amount.
Nor indeed was it final as to anything else. Pru Goward then said:
But Gerry Hand argued on `AM' that he had checked this quite carefully with his Department and, because he had signed nothing, then it wasn't officially approved.
I hope that is the test which applies to ministerial decision making as far as accountability to Parliament is concerned. Pru asked:
It cannot be official until he's signed something?
I would agree with that assertion, to which the Leader of the Opposition in the Senate replied in the following terms:
I must say that I think that's very much a lawyer's argument and doesn't really fit in with the political realities.

That is a nonsensical statement, because the reality is that Ministers do have to make decisions which comply with the law as well as with the politics of the day. The Leader of the Opposition knows that. Of course the Minister has to be legally and politically accountable in his decision making. I am glad he did not apply the same tests to his own decision making as he applies to this Minister's.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is about your standard.

—I look forward to Senator Walters's contribution to this debate. Let us have a look at the rest of these papers, particularly the minute of 18 October this year, which was signed by Glenda Humes, whom I know to be a very competent officer of the Department, and which is well and truly after the meeting of 31 August. She says:

SPEECH.PARA: I raised the question of NAIHO funding again with Harriett Swift who apologised for the delay in sending the Dept relevant info concerning the funding. She said that there is some concern about the precise amount needed and that 2 staff positions (TAP funded by DEET) needed to be sorted out and how long would they be funded under DEET.

This memo clearly indicates that the Minister had not made a final decision to fund NAIHO. In fact, the decision, as the NAIHO letter itself points out, was conditional on a number of matters which had at this point not been resolved. When the Minister makes a decision for which he is properly accountable to the Parliament, that decision is backed up with a ministerial directive to his Department to commence the funding. For reasons of which I am not aware, but of which the Minister was certainly aware, and clearly related to matters with which he was not satisfied, that minute was never sent to the Department. There was no directive; there was no decision made to fund NAIHO. Therefore, the answer given to the Parliament on 8 November and again on 1 December was absolutely correct.

TALK.START.PARA: —Now quote Miss Humes's last paragraph-the one where she is going to withhold information.

—I have only five minutes left in which to speak. This is a tabled document available to the public. She suggested that any queries which might be raised at Senate Estimates committee hearings may be taken on notice-a quite proper suggestion. The Minister had not made a decision to fund NAIHO.
—To withhold information from the Senate.

—That is nonsense. Because I have canvassed it, I have to devote some time to the last part of the original motion, which has now been changed during the debate, relating to the discrepancy between the statement made by Mr McDonald on 2 December and the one made by him subsequently in which he corrected the record. The fact is that the statement made by Mr McDonald dated 2 December is absolutely unequivocal in respect of its reference to whether the Minister misled the Parliament. Mr McDonald said categorically that in his view the Minister did not mislead the Parliament. How then can this discrepancy have occurred? I am prepared to offer my own suggestion, which I think is the correct one. I preface my comments by saying that this is purely my own view on the matter; I have not had the benefit of speaking to Mr McDonald about it, nor would I personally consider it to be proper if I did so. What I have to say is purely speculation on my part about the matter; but I think it is probably correct. The statement that Mr McDonald made on 2 December is absolutely correct and accords with all of the papers that have been tabled in this Parliament that the Minister had not made a final decision on funding NAIHO. The Minister indicated that he was predisposed to fund it but had not made a final decision, as all of the papers attest. Therefore, his answer to the Parliament was correct. Mr McDonald confirmed that.

SPEECH.PARA: But what happened subsequently? An article in the Weekend Australian of 3-4 December 1988, which I read last night and with which I have no dispute, makes a number of references to Mr McDonald which obviously would have been quite personally hurtful to him. Time constraints forbid me from quoting the article more fully. In any case, people can read it for themselves. The article states:
So Mr McDonald agrees now that he was incorrect.
The article goes on to say:
How do we know about Mr Hand's talk with Mr McDonald in which the latter saw the error of his ways?
The article goes on further to say:
With Mr McDonald's rethink, Mr Hand has closed the circle of self-protection.

I have commented often in the 12 years that I have been a member of parliament that the reality is that people in politics tend to forget the impact on people not engaged in politics of being quoted in newspapers, particularly in a non-complimentary fashion. This sort of thing upsets them considerably. On a number of occasions over the years people have come to me who have been quite distraught because they have received any publicly at all. This sort of publicity does upset people. It is absolutely clear from any fair reading of the contribution--

TALK.START.PARA: —You get used to it.

—It does not concern me. I am talking about people who are not involved in politics. It is clear from both the opening and closing paragraphs of the letter that Mr McDonald wrote, clearly under some distress, on 3 December that he was deeply upset about the article that appeared in the Weekend Australian. That is what has prompted him. There has been no pressure from the Minister and no pressure from the Department. He wrote his original note on 2 December in a calm and relaxed atmosphere. That was simply his clear recollection. But he was absolutely distressed when he read the Weekend Australian, as I imagine a lot of people in his position would be.

SPEECH.PARA: It is simply a question of interpretation. Both stories are probably correct. The Minister was clearly predisposed to fund NAIHO. He probably said as much to Mr McDonald. In fact, I am sure he did say as much to Mr McDonald. But it is clear from any fair reading of the minutes, of the attachments and of the notes flowing backwards and forwards to the Department that the Minister had not made that decision. That decision was not made. The Minister had not made a decision for which he was properly accountable to this Parliament and, therefore, the answers given by the Minister on both 8 November and 1 December in the House of Representatives were absolutely correct. The motion should fail; the Minister did not mislead the Parliament.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Short Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —This debate is about propriety in government; it is about basic acceptable standards of ministerial conduct. It is about ministerial responsibility and integrity. It is about the cardinal principle of our whole parliamentary system-that Parliament be the forum where the truth, and only the truth, is told. That is what this debate is about. These are the criteria and the principles against which the conduct of the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs, Mr Hand, and the conduct and standards of the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) are to be judged. On each of these criteria, on each of these basic principles, there can be only one judgment of Mr Hand's conduct in this sorry, sordid affair, and that judgment is failure-failure to maintain acceptable basic standards of ministerial conduct and ministerial responsibility; failure to tell the Parliament the truth and only the truth at all times. There is only one honourable course open to any Minister who has so breached this basic essential standard, and that course is resignation. There is only one honourable course open to a Prime Minister whose Minister fails to meet these basic standards and who, nevertheless, refuses to resign, and that is dismissal of that Minister.

SPEECH.PARA: This Hawke Labor Government is once again under the spotlight of public propriety-this time because of the actions of the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs, Mr Hand. However, this is by no means the first time that the spotlight has been so focused on this Government. Just 12 months ago, another Hawke Cabinet Minister, Mr John Brown, was forced to resign because he told lies in the Parliament over an Expo contract. We all remember Mr Mick Young and his notorious breaches of ministerial propriety over the Harris-Daishowa affair, the Paddington Bear affair and, most importantly, the Combe-Ivanov affair, when he placed the very security of this country at risk. Then we had Mr Keating, the winner of the award for the world's second worst Treasurer, and the scandalous misuse by him of his travelling allowance and the privileged treatment he was given by the Australian Taxation Commissioner. The list of failed, disgraced Hawke Government Ministers is long. It is growing, and Mr Hand is merely following in notable company.

The matter at issue is very simple; the charge is simple and unambiguous. That charge is that the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs, Mr Hand, misled the Parliament on 8 November and, again, just last Thursday on 1 December when he claimed, in response to questions from the honourable member for Higgins, Mr Shipton, that he had not yet taken a decision to fund the National Aboriginal and Islander Health Organisation (NAIHO). He also misled the Parliament-this time the Senate-yet again yesterday when he claimed in this place, through Senator Bolkus, not to have been advised prior to 8 September this year of the Arthur Andersen and Co. report on NAIHO. I seek leave to table a briefing note on that matter which we understand Mr Hand received from his Department when he first became Minister.
Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —The evidence that Mr Hand had taken a decision to fund NAIHO on 31 August is both damning and overwhelming. Senator Chaney documented the case very fully and adequately when leading off this urgency debate on behalf of the Opposition. Let me just repeat some of that damning, unequivocal, overwhelming evidence. Let me stress that this is not hearsay evidence or evidence that dropped off the back of a truck, as Mr Hand quite stupidly claimed on AM this morning. It is evidence contained in documents tabled in this Senate in recent days by Government Ministers themselves. The case is very simple, very clear cut and very unambiguous. It is that the Minister had a meeting with representatives of NAIHO on 31 August to discuss its application for re-funding by the Department of Aboriginal Affairs. We have no written evidence of what actually took place at that meeting on 31 August because there appears to be no written record of the meeting available. What we do know, however, is that immediately after the meeting the Minister advised a senior departmental officer, Mr Don McDonald-I quote directly from his note for file written the following day-that:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . he had approved funding of about $180,000 for NAIHO with effect from 1 December. He-
that is, the Minister-
would confirm this with a written advice to the Department.

The conversation between the Minister and Mr McDonald-who incidentally, it was intended would attend the meeting with NAIHO but he was subsequently excluded-was not just a fleeting conversation between a Minister and a public servant. Mr McDonald records in his note for file of 1 September that he discussed with the Minister the appropriate description of NAIHO's role for the purpose of the letter of offer to the organisation, a point that Senator Stone picked up so well. How can we have a letter of offer of something when there has been no decision taken? Mr McDonald has elaborated on that discussion with the Minister in his much later minute of 3 September. In paragraphs 2, 3 and 4 of that minute Mr McDonald said:

2. Let me make it quite clear from the outset that I have absolutely no doubt that, at the end of his meeting of 31 August with NAIHO, the Minister had decided to fund NAIHO with effect from 1 December. He conveyed that decision to me verbally immediately after the meeting. Ms Harriett Swift of the Minister's staff was also present at that time.

3. I am very clear on our discussion, which took place in the Minister's own office. He said ``I have decided to fund NAIHO . . . obviously you don't agree with that decision''. I replied ``obviously'' but made no further comment. The Minister then went on to discuss aspects of his decision, including the fact that he had told NAIHO representatives that they could purchase a car if they were prepared to go without some other item from their capital budget.

4. During our discussion the Minister also said that he thought the Department of Employment, Education and Training `DEET' might meet some of the salary costs of NAIHO's budget, which would reduce the total cost of DAA's contribution. A figure of $180,000 was mentioned as the total cost although this was a `ballpark' figure, rather than a firm budget. I also asked the Minister about the purposes which I should include in the Department's letter of offer to NAIHO. I recommended two of the three points from NAIHO's 1986 letter of offer. The Minister agreed with this. I think we would hardly have got to this sort of detail if we `the Minister and I' had not been certain that the decision to fund NAIHO was firm.

The Senate will note that Mr McDonald has stated that a member of the Minister's own staff, Ms Harriett Swift, was present during this discussion. Ms Swift has not at any time, to the Opposition's knowledge, refuted Mr McDonald's understanding of that discussion between the Minister and Mr McDonald on 31 August. The evidence suggests strongly the contrary. I refer the Senate to two documents to support the view that Ms Swift's understanding was that the Minister had agreed to fund NAIHO and that the only question to be resolved was the level of funding. The first document is a minute from Mr McDonald to a first assistant secretary, programs policy, on 13 October, where in a handwritten postscript he said:
I also raised the issue of NAIHO funding with Ms Swift and Andrew Jackomos on 12 October. They said they still had one aspect to sort out.
In an internal minute on 18 October Ms Glenda Humes, to whom Senator Collins referred, and who by that time appears to have taken over Mr McDonald's duties-and why, we have not been told-said:
I raised the question of NAIHO funding again with Harriett Swift who apologised for the delay in sending the Department relevant information concerning the funding.
She said that there is some concern about the precise amount needed and that 2 staff positions . . . needed to be sorted out eg how long would they be funded under DEET.

All that evidence makes it inconceivable that if Ms Swift did not agree with Mr McDonald's interpretation of his discussion with the Minister on 31 August, these file notes would exist. These notes can mean only one thing-that is, that Ms Swift, too, believed that the Minister had already agreed to fund NAIHO. There is more evidence to support this. In particular, there is the minute from Mr McDonald to the Minister's senior private secretary, Mr Pryor, dated 22 September, pointing out for the third time that he had not yet received details of the 31 August meeting between the Minister and NAIHO as the Minister had directed, including, Mr McDonald wrote:
. . . particularly those relating to the level of the Minister's funding approval for the organisation. Until I receive this I will not be in a position to process funding action.

That minute was written to the Minister's senior private secretary three weeks after the Minister's meeting with NAIHO. Mr Pryor, the Minister's senior private secretary, was at that meeting. If the Minister had not agreed to fund NAIHO, then Mr Pryor would have corrected Mr McDonald's understanding as contained in that 22 September minute. He did not do this.

I have gone into this amount of detail because it needs to be made absolutely clear that this matter is not simply one person's word against another's. It is not simply a matter of Mr Hand's word against Mr McDonald's word. All the evidence supports overwhelmingly the fact that the Minister told Mr McDonald on 31 August that he had agreed to re-fund NAIHO.

I have not yet referred to NAIHO's letter to the Minister dated 1 September, the day after the Minister's meeting with NAIHO. That letter appears to make it clear that the Minister told the NAIHO representatives that he had agreed to re-funding. That would seem to be the logical conclusion from the first paragraph of that letter, which states:
In undertaking the fine tuning of the agreement reached yesterday I would ask that we consider the following points.

It went on to discuss various points of detail. Even if these words are subject to a different interpretation, as Mr Hand claimed in his statement read into the Senate on his behalf by Senator Bolkus yesterday, that would still not affect in any way the validity of the Opposition's charge that Mr Hand told officers of his Department and his own staff immediately after the meeting with NAIHO that he had decided to fund the organisation. There is more evidence of a similar nature to that which I have already outlined to indicate quite conclusively that the Minister failed to tell the truth in the House of Representatives on 8 November and on 1 December and in this Senate through Senator Bolkus yesterday.

In the very limited time remaining I want to turn briefly to a matter with which Senator Stone dealt so comprehensively-that is, the appropriate Public Service and ministerial procedures in respect of decision taking. Mr Hand's assertion on AM this morning that a decision is not a decision until it is fully signed off in writing by a Minister is simply ludicrous. If this were a commonly accepted view, then all public-and I might say, private sector-activity would cease forthwith. Was the Minister seriously suggesting, for example, that a Cabinet decision is not a decision until the Cabinet minute has been prepared and finalised, that decisions taken within his Department are not decisions until someone has signed something, that a decision made by him and conveyed to an officer of his Department has no effect until it has been signed off in writing, or that an undertaking the Minister might give on behalf of the Government with an outside person or organisation carries no significance at all until it has been documented and signed by the Minister? What absolute nonsense? No organisation can work on that basis and they do not even pretend to.

In my 20 years in the Commonwealth Public Service, in my dealings with Ministers and others over that time, from both sides of politics, and in my years in industry, I never once saw business done on that basis. Why? Because it would cause all decision making to grind to a halt. Mr Hand's statement this morning was quite nonsensical. It was a red herring, a straw man, and I treat it with the contempt that it deserves.

The matter of urgency moved by Senator Chaney today is of the utmost importance. The Opposition's motion should not be necessary. Mr Hand should have resigned voluntarily by now. That he has not done this, and neither has Mr Hawke exercised his responsibility as Prime Minister to dismiss Ministers who lie to the Parliament and to the Australian people, speaks volumes for the extent to which basic standards of propriety, integrity, responsibility and decency in government have sunk under this Government.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McMullan Sen R.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to deal with the motion that is before us, not the one that I think the Opposition wishes it had before us in light of some of the evidence it claims to have come up with at Question Time. The motion relates to two things. It relates to an allegation that the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs (Mr Hand) has misled the Parliament over the question of funding for the National Aboriginal and Islander Health Organisation (NAIHO)-that is, whether or not it was funded, which is a debate about the answers given in December-and to allegations of subsequent attempts to falsify the record.

SPEECH.PARA: There has not been a lot of consideration given to those allegations because the Opposition has been trying to tack some new items on in the hope that they will bolster what is otherwise a very weak argument. We are not talking here about some minor criticism of the Minister. The proposal is that the Minister ought to be dismissed. Obviously, it requires a very serious finding of error by the Minister to justify that. I do not pretend that, if a Minister is found to have misled the Parliament, that is in any way minor. I am not endeavouring to do that. Certainly, in a matter as serious as that which is addressed in the questions of 8 November and 1 December, if the answers had been misleading it would have been an extremely serious matter. But I think the evidence that has been put by Senator Tate and Senator Collins, and to which I wish to refer, establishes that those answers were not misleading.

I want to refer briefly to the allegation of `subsequent attempts to falsify the record in defiance of all accepted public service procedures'. I find this allegation a cause of significant concern, not because I think the Minister has done such a thing or because any evidence has been presented that he even attempted to do so, but because the only way someone can substantiate a claim that there had been an attempt by the Minister to falsify the record in any of the matters referred to is to have it sustained that there was a conspiracy by the Minister and several senior public servants so to do. I regard that as an absolutely deplorable allegation against senior, responsible, respected public servants-not people appointed to their positions by this Government, not political hatchet people or whatever-who have held senior positions under both governments in the Department of Aboriginal Affairs (DAA). That little tack on, in the hope that it will help put together a threadbare case, is an absolutely unreasonable proposal which has not been substantiated.

TALK.START.PARA: —What do you think the Minister and those other public servants are doing to Mr McDonald?
—I do not wish to make any reflection on Mr McDonald.
—That would be very unwise.

—That is kind of the honourable senator. I am not making any reflections. The only people in this Parliament who are reflecting on public servants are Senator Stone, Senator Short and Senator Chaney. They have made an implied allegation of conspiracy on the part of senior public servants without a shred of evidence. They just wish it were true because it would substantiate their case, so they assert it.

SPEECH.PARA: We need to make one brief diversion to deal with the point that Senator Chaney made early in his remarks about the compounding concern about inefficient administration in the Department of Aboriginal Affairs under Minister Hand. There are various definitions of what constitutes efficient administration, but I simply want to refer to the figures that are published in the annual report of the Department of Aboriginal Affairs dealing with the proportion of the funding to DAA which goes to administration as against projects. Those figures show that the proportion of DAA funding absorbed in administration in 1987-88 was the lowest in 15 years-I might say, 25 per cent lower than when Senator Chaney was the Minister. I make that point because there has been an attempt to paint a background that is entirely misleading.

I come back to the specific matter before us: Did the Minister mislead the Parliament over the question of funding for the National Aboriginal and Islander Health Organisation? It comes back to that question of whether or not he made a decision. I will deal with the Hansard quotes in a moment. We are not asking whether he had made up his mind about whether it ought to be funded or whether he had formed an opinion, but whether he had made something that could reasonably be interpreted as a decision. Many people have defined what is not a decision but let us talk about what is. The Oxford Dictionary refers to a decision in this context as the settlement of an issue.

TALK.START.PARA: —Do you have to go to a dictionary to know what a decision is, Senator?

—I have to explain it to the three opposite because they have all got it quite wrong. A decision is a final settlement of a question. I suppose in commonsense parlance we could say that the Minister made decisions about funding the National Aboriginal and Islander Health Organisation in the sense that he made a decision to meet with some people, to consider what they had to say. But no decision in the sense of the obvious context of the answer that he gave to Mr Shipton, no final decision that would lead to funding that organisation, no decision to recommence funding, has been made.

SPEECH.PARA: Obviously, as I said, the Minister has made up his mind about some matters and he has made that very clear to the Parliament. He has made up his mind that he has a predisposition to fund a national Aboriginal health body if the appropriate conditions are met. In that sense of the word `decide' lots of decisions are made, but they are not decisions to recommence funding, which was the question asked by Mr Shipton. He asked: `Has the Minister recommenced funding to that organisation?' The answer to that question is that no such decision has been made.

TALK.START.PARA: —Why didn't he write back to NAIHO the day after receiving that letter and tell them it was in error?

—Quite clearly and simply, no such decision has been made. I will come back to the NAIHO letter in a moment. There are a series of qualifications and preconditions upon any agreement before it can get to the stage of being a decision capable of being implemented. It was quite clear, and it is clear in the letter from NAIHO and in all the comments that have been made and actions that have taken place since, that further negotiations were to be required.

SPEECH.PARA: The interpretation of `decision'-in this context the final settlement of an issue-is reinforced by the context of the Minister's reply and by the questions from the honourable member for Higgins (Mr Shipton) to which he was replying. The subsequent motions which Mr Shipton tried to move on 1 December gave a very clear indication of what the Opposition thought it was onto, but it was quite wrong. The basis upon which he proceeded has been acknowledged, I think by everybody now, as absolutely incorrect. The question on 1 December asked whether the Minister:
. . . directed that NAIHO receive $180,000 in funding this year, prior to the answer he gave me to my question in this House on 8 November 1988?

Quite clearly he did not. I think everybody acknowledges that he did not-certainly Mr McDonald does-and no action has been taken. If we want to interpret whether a decision has been made, we should look at the context and at the subsequent actions to see what happened after the alleged decision, between 31 August and 6 December. Alternatively, if people want to indulge in conspiracy theories, let us go back to between 31 August and 8 November, when the matter was first raised in the Parliament. No action was taken by the Minister to implement any so-called decision to fund NAIHO. There was plenty of time for action to be taken, but none was taken because no such decision had been made. Dealing in that context with those questions and answers, both Senator Tambling and Senator Stone have said by way of interjection that the Minister made no reference in those two answers to the need for the restructuring of NAIHO. They are absolutely incorrect. In both answers he made it quite explicit that it was agreed in the negotiations that a condition would be the restructuring of an Aboriginal and Islander health body. The loose allegations that are made here do not reflect any credit on the people who make them.

We have subsequent evidence also that no decision had been made. We find a note from Mr Jackomos of the Minister's staff to Mr McDonald seeking further information about the NAIHO audit report. We find there quite clearly that that is the sort of query that is made preparatory to any final decision. It is not subsequent to a decision. One does not ask about those things after one has made the decision; one asks before. That is what is being done-further information is being sought. All the information from Mr McDonald on 13 October and from Miss Humes on 18 October is the same. They are saying that there are still matters to be sorted out; the matter is not finalised. There is no question of the Minister's predisposition to fund NAIHO once the negotiations are settled if a satisfactory agreement can be achieved about the amount of money, about the purpose to which the money is put and about the structure of the organisation which is to receive the money. That is not a big secret. The Minister has made that clear on every occasion it has been discussed in the Parliament and in public.

That combination of conclusions reached does not constitute a decision, a final settlement of the matter. It does not come close to constituting a final settlement of the matter. As Acting Chief Justice Fox said in the Federal Court in 1981, when talking about public administration:
In ordinary usage, the special feature of a decision is its conclusiveness, or finality for the time being, and this is to be contrasted with the thought or consideration which precedes it.
I understand that in defining terms some people like to use `loosely' misleadingly in the hope that people will not understand what the words mean. That is very unfortunate for them, and that is--

TALK.START.PARA: —I would loosely regard it as consistent-like the Minister's answer.
—It is unfortunate that I have to upset Senator Stone in this matter, but sometimes the facts are disturbing.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Chaney had to admit this morning on radio that it was not a decision which was final. That is absolutely correct. There is a process that leads to a decision. There are a lot of stages in that process. If each of those stages is to be defined as a decision, then the English language no longer makes any sense, and the process of decision making in government no longer means what anybody has previously thought it to mean. There is certainly nothing in the statements made by anybody in this Parliament, or in any of the documents that have been tabled, that contradicts Mr Hand's view that he had not made a decision to recommence funding NAIHO. Even if Mr McDonald is right about the discussion that took place on 31 August- and I am not saying whether he is right or wrong because it was a conversation between two individuals to which nobody here was privy; I suspect the truth lies somewhere in between because the memory plays tricks on everybody-it does not establish that a decision had been made to recommence funding NAIHO, which was the question that the Minister was required to answer and which he was answering. After reading Hansard, Mr McDonald was prepared to confirm his previous advice that the Minister's statement was accurate.

It seems to have been forgotten in some of the discussions what the Minister actually said, in the enthusiasm to find that he might have misled someone. It is clear that no decision has been made to recommence funding NAIHO, but what has happened is that funding arrangements have been discussed. The Minister has said that he hopes to have worked out funding by December. That is not a secret; that is what he said in the Parliament on 8 November. He had a predisposition which was probably understood by NAIHO and Mr McDonald to fund such a body and that the figure might be about $180,000 to $200,000. That is not a secret either. That is what he is reported to have said, in the Hansard of 1 December. He did not mislead the Parliament. There is no need to hide behind technicalities. The motion should be rejected.

We should get away from this series of attempts to create diversions from the principal issues that are before us in Australian politics and in the discussion of matters to do with Aboriginal affairs. We should get away from attempts to destroy people's characters. We should not get involved in muckraking exercises. We should get back to dealing with fundamental issues of concern to Aboriginal people. Therefore, I think the motion should be rejected.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I table a document and seek leave to make a very short statement in relation to it.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —During the debate on this motion, Opposition senators and Senator Macklin referred to a document concerning the National Aboriginal and Islander Health Organisation which it was claimed was provided to the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs (Mr Hand) in July 1987. I believe that Senator Short tabled what he claimed to be the document. I now table an official copy of that document numbered 17, which is an extract from a briefing document entitled `Significant Current Issues'. I also table a copy of the front page of that briefing document. Lest I subsequently be accused of doctoring the tabling of papers, I do not, nor do I claim to, table the complete document entitled `Significant Current Issues'. I am advised that none of the other pages of that document relate to the National Aboriginal and Islander Health Organisation.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —in reply-I thank the Minister for Justice (Senator Tate) for that statement and for the tabling, which confirms the matters which were raised by the Opposition; namely, that as long ago as July 1987 the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs (Mr Hand) received advice on the National Aboriginal and Islander Health Organisation (NAIHO) which included reference to the report of the independent auditors.

SPEECH.PARA: I wish to speak very briefly in response, in the few minutes that remain in this debate, not least because of the closing remarks of Senator McMullan, who made a plea that we should stop destroying people's reputations and stop muckraking. I totally reject that quite offensive statement and remind Senator McMullan that in this difficult area the problem that we are consistently facing in this Parliament is the getting of accurate information about matters where there is clearly serious maladministration. The Opposition makes no apology for bringing these matters forward and will continue to do so. We put the Government on notice that, with the very strong interest in Aboriginal affairs matters on the Opposition benches, we will continue to deal with issues of maladministration as they come to our attention.

A couple of things can be said in terms of the defence which was mounted. The principal defence during the debate was: how could it be said that the Minister had agreed to funding when so far no funding had gone to NAIHO? That demonstrates the thinness of the defence available to the Minister. Since this matter was raised in the Parliament on 8 November it has been a matter of extraordinary concern at the political level and the Minister has been trying ever since to tailor his situation to meet the fact that the Opposition had raised this matter. The simple points that can be made which demonstrate quite clearly that this Parliament has been misled are to move away from the areas where there has been an attempt to muddy the stream, to demonstrate that in some way poor Mr McDonald did not really mean it when he said over and over again that the Minister had made it plain to him that he had agreed to funding. The organisation which met with the Minister in August of this year and wrote the next day made it clear that it regarded itself as having obtained an agreement for funding from the Government, subject, certainly, to negotiation on detail.

That letter, which was dated 1 September and received by the Minister shortly afterwards, has not been responded to. There has been no attempt to correct the statement contained in that letter that the meeting with the Minister resulted in agreement. I draw the attention of the Senate again to the consistent statements made by Mr McDonald that he has absolutely no doubt that at the end of the Minister's meeting on 31 August with NAIHO the Minister had decided to fund NAIHO with effect from 1 December.

Even more cogent and beyond challenge is the fact that only yesterday the Minister told us, through the mouth of Senator Bolkus, that the report was compiled before he was the Minister and that it was the first time it had been drawn to his attention. We have now had the clearest possible illustration that in July 1987 the Minister was briefed on the existence of this report. We have a very strong inference drawn by Senator Stone that before the meeting of January 1988 it would again have been brought to his attention. It is not a matter of inference but a simple unassailable fact that the memorandum that was prepared for the Minister for his meeting with NAIHO in August contains the clearest possible references to the independent audit. The attachments in which those references were made were specifically drawn to the Minister's attention and the Minister has signed the minute from the Department.

The matter is conclusive. I commend the motion to the Senate, and I trust that this motion will be a lesson to the Government that the Parliament is entitled to accurate information from its Ministers.
Question put:
That the motion (Senator Chaney's) be agreed to.

DIVISION.RESULT.PARA: Question so resolved in the negative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Maguire Sen G.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the paper.

I wish to speak to the report entitled Taxation Statistics 1985-86. In particular, I wish to refer to a table on page 426 of the report which has some very interesting data on fringe benefits tax. For example, it is clear that total collections from that tax nationally from July 1986 until the end of March last year were $528m, of which only $9.4m was collected from the rural sector. When we look at the proportion of the total collections of fringe benefits tax from the rural sector, based on this official report, we find that only 1.8 per cent of all fringe benefits tax collected in Australia came from the farm sector. In fact, 5,300 primary producers throughout Australia actually paid the tax-about 3 per cent of all primary producers in the Australian economy.

In effect, the statistics report from the Commissioner of Taxation suggests that 97 per cent of farm producers did not pay fringe benefits tax; It is very interesting to note that of the $9.4m collected in the farm sector, only $1.3m came from farm partnerships and only $300,000 in fringe benefits tax was collected from sole traders. In total, only $1.6m came from partnerships and sole traders, compared with $5.9m from farm companies, both private and public. That breakdown suggests pretty strongly to me that the fringe benefits tax, to the limited extent that it was paid by the farm sector, was paid by people incorporated as companies or private companies. Presumably farmers with lower incomes paid far less fringe benefits tax than the wealthiest farmers.

I think these figures really do expose as scare campaigns the campaigns that have been run over recent years by both the Liberal Party and the National Party about the fringe benefits tax. Members of the Opposition have been right round Australia in every State over the last several years trying to scare farm sector producers by saying that they would be liable for the fringe benefits tax and that they would be financially disadvantaged and inconvenienced by the fringe benefits tax. The figures in the Tax Commissioner's statistics report make it clear that the extravagant claims about the fringe benefits tax made by the Opposition and the National Farmers Federation over recent years were, in fact, pure fiction. The figures do not support the suggestion that the farm sector would be hit heavily by the fringe benefits tax.

Regrettably, many primary producers around Australia clearly were misled by the Opposition's claims. Needless and baseless financial worries were caused to a number of farmers as a result of these scare campaigns about the fringe benefits tax. Both the Liberal Party and the National Party of Australia stand condemned for making claims about the fringe benefits tax which clearly had little relevance to the everyday position of the overwhelming majority of Australian farmers. Only recently I have seen letters in rural newspapers in my State trying to convey the impression that most farmers are paying the fringe benefits tax. I have made the point that the Tax Commissioner's statistics suggest that 97 per cent of farmers in Australia have not had to pay fringe benefits tax. That exposes very clearly indeed the claims made by Opposition politicians about the tax.

Of course, the revenue being collected as a result of the fringe benefits tax-$848m last financial year-will help finance the reductions in personal income tax which will occur next year. So while few farmers paid fringe benefits tax, many will qualify for the reductions in personal income tax next year which will be funded in part by the revenue collected from the fringe benefits tax. So there is to be a quite important redistribution of tax in the Australian community. Many will benefit from the income tax cuts; few have paid fringe benefits tax.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

DEBATE.TITLE: DEPARTMENT OF EMPLOYMENT, EDUCATION AND TRAINING

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Calvert Sen P.H.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the paper.

I wish to address my remarks on the annual report of the Department of Employment, Education and Training to the section in the report entitled `Community Based, Aboriginals and Youth Affairs'. This section of the report deals essentially with the community youth support scheme (CYSS), the community training program (CTP) and the community volunteer program (CVP), which the Government has decided from 1 January 1989 will be amalgamated and funded under the auspices of Skillshare. I address this subject as one who has had considerable experience in the workings of the community youth support scheme, having been Chairman of the Clarence CYSS for many years.

The Department states that the aims of these community based programs are to encourage communities to assist unemployed people at the local level and to develop their capacity for obtaining and retaining employment. The idea of encouraging communities to work together to seek answers to the growing problem of unemployment is certainly a commendable one and one which in theory provides a catalyst for some very worthwhile programs. It is appropriate when discussing this report to encourage the many thousands of people throughout Australia who have provided invaluable assistance to CYSS, CTP and CVP in a voluntary capacity over the years. Their hours of unpaid assistance and professional expertise have allowed these programs to fulfil their role. It is quite obvious that without these community minded people many of these programs would not operate at all.

When the Government introduced the concept of Skillshare I, like many others, welcomed it because as a former CYSS chairman I was aware of the multitude of training schemes and other volunteer based schemes that existed in the community. I always had the feeling that these schemes would be of much more practical value if they were amalgamated. I was pleased to see that the Government, quite rightly, decided to bring at least these three schemes under the one umbrella. This amalgamation takes away from the community youth support scheme the support that those young unemployed people have relied upon, but replaces it with a more practical training scheme to try to develop some skills that could be of benefit to the young unemployed. Under Skillshare the age restrictions have been completely abolished, so there are no specific schemes for youth under the present program. It will cater for all unemployed. Skillshare was lauded as the answer to all these programs and at the same time it promised ongoing commitment to assist the unemployed.

However, the Government has failed to acknowledge that the introduction of Skillshare will go hand in hand with the demise of some existing CYSS groups. I refer particularly to programs in New Norfolk, Queenstown and Clarence, in Tasmania, which have so far failed to receive Skillshare funding. The situation in New Norfolk and in Queenstown, which I visited last Saturday, is particularly critical as both these communities are very isolated. Prior to the new scheme CYSS was the only form of assistance that the unemployed youth received in those regions. For those people who have not been to Queenstown, the closest area to be found which has any semblance of a Skillshare scheme would be either Launceston or possibly Brighton, which are some 300 kilometres away. This means it is impossible for those unemployed young people to receive any support or assistance.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable senator's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the paper.

Last night in the adjournment debate I raised in passing the way in which the loss by the Trade Union Training Authority (TUTA) last year of $1.5m has been covered up by this Government, and an attempt has now been made in the Authority's annual report to hide this loss from those people who read only the report section rather than the detailed accounts at the end of the report. It is a disgrace that any government institution, any government body, experiencing a loss of $1.5m should put out a report in which that loss is not discussed, revealed or stated in the signed part of the report-which is what one would imagine would be the section of the report which outlines to readers what has happened.

I must say, having outlined that extraordinary and unexplained loss last night, that many other elements of this annual report have come to my notice and have caused me a great deal of concern. I have had a good look at the cost per student training day, which is about $165. It costs $165 a day for every student who attends the Trade Union Training Authority. I know it is difficult to make comparisons but that figure is about four times as much as the average cost to educate someone at a tertiary institution. It is probably three times as much as it costs to teach someone to be a doctor. I am not quite certain how the Authority has managed to reach that level. When one looks at the details of individual increased costs in the annual report one finds that in the four years from 1983-84 to June 1988 salaries have rocketed from only $172,000 to 5 1/2 times that amount-$4m. But the number of student training days has increased by only 56 per cent.

This means that salaries per student training day have more than trebled, from $18.40 to $66.80. Course costs-and I presume that they are the other non-salary costs involved in these courses-have jumped 2 1/2 times over this period, from $739,000 to $1.9m, increasing the course costs per student training day from $19.10 to $30.80.

What on earth is going on in this college? These extraordinary figures seem to coincide with the running down of the Clyde Cameron College at Wodonga. Is the Government deliberately getting rid of that college? Is it winding it down so far as to be non-existent? In view of the fact that this report does not give the answers, I think the people of Australia have a right to ask: What is the real story? We see this report saying that it is a matter of grave concern that cuts in TUTA's allocation have been enforced for 1988-89. That is simply not true. The taxpayer will be paying more next year for TUTA. The taxpayers' contribution will go up from $7.8m in 1987-88 to $8.5m this year-another hefty increase. However, expenditure is going down. Instead of losing $1.5m, TUTA's expenditure is being cut to $8.5m so that income and expenditure will apparently match. But the reality is that there is to be an increased contribution to an organisation which appears incapable of efficiently and effectively managing its own finances. I think the Senate deserves a proper explanation about why TUTA has managed to lose $1 1/2m and why it has managed to put on so many extra people when its expenditure went far beyond the increasing allocations that have been made to the organisation by this Government. I see in the Forward Estimates that TUTA is still intending to increase its staffing level beyond last year's level even though the total expenditure is to fall.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable senator's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bishop Sen B.K. .

TALK.START.PARA: —I also want to comment on the annual report of the Trade Union Training Authority (TUTA) and, in particular, on part of the supplementary information that was provided subsequent to the Estimates Committee A hearings in October. During those Estimates Committee hearings, when we were looking at TUTA, I asked several questions relating to the matter just raised by Senator Michael Baume-that is, the question of student training day costs and how they compared with those of other institutions. It was said in evidence that it was almost impossible to compare TUTA with any other form of educative institution. It is interesting that in subsequent information I was told:

SPEECH.PARA: The ratio of gross expenditure per student training day referred to by Senator Bishop is calculated to provide only one imperfect measurement of the improving efficiency of TUTA's performance. Over recent years, this ratio has fallen substantially and in 1987/88 showed an 11.5% improvement over the previous year. However, it is based on TUTA's gross expenditure for administration, State centre, city and country training, College residential training and national training, liaison and co-ordination and therefore has little relevance other than as an internal indicator.

I find that less than convincing, particularly when TUTA is claiming in that paragraph an improvement in efficiency. Yet, as Senator Baume has just pointed out, TUTA managed to sustain a $1.5m deficit which it made up by selling off assets. In addition, we find on page 27 of this report under the heading `Contracts Exceeding $100,000' dealing with TUTA's need to comply with section 47 (a) of the Trade Union Training Authority Act:
. . . the Authority has been advised that the provisions of paragraph 47 (a) were breached during 1987/88 on a number of occasions.

That matter refers to the investment of amounts of $100,000 or more at any one time when it is necessary to obtain approval. On page 18 of the report under the heading `Current Assets' and the subheading `Cash on Hand and at Bank' we see a deficit of $154,545. We see subsequently in the report that TUTA did not go into deficit at all because, although the cheques were drawn, presumably they were not paid, posted or banked.

All in all, I find the management of TUTA far from satisfactory. It has traded at a loss; it has been in breach of required provisions; and it has managed to finish with a deficit in its cash on hand although, as I have said, it subsequently managed not to go into overdraft because the cheques were dealt with in some fashion that allowed that not to occur. I just wanted to register my feeling, as a member of Senate Estimates Committee A, that TUTA has a lot to answer for, and we will be most interested to look at it again in six months time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Burns Sen B.R

TALK.START.PARA: —It rather disgusts me to hear people on the opposite side of the chamber at every occasion attacking an organisation which, over recent years since its inception, has provided an opportunity for trade unionists to be trained in a proper fashion-an area which is so important in Australia. Time and again we hear people from the Liberal and National parties saying that there is a need to increase productivity, that there is a need for better relations between employers and employees, and that if this is not done our future will be in dire peril. These people also talk about the need to have negotiations at plant level.

SPEECH.PARA: One of the things that the Trade Union Training Authority (TUTA) has done very well over time has been to bring together trade union officers and trade union leaders from around this country; to indicate to them the way in which our industrial relations authorities operate; to advise them of the best ways in which to negotiate; and also to encourage them to be forward thinkers and to be creative in looking at new ways in which they can operate on behalf of the people they represent and in a way which will bring benefits to this country. I think it has done that very well.

We have heard talk about additional amounts that have been spent. No-one has said for one minute that that money was not spent properly and was not accounted for. I notice in the report this statement from the Australian Audit Office:
the statements are based on proper accounts and records
the statements show fairly the financial transactions . . .

So there is no problem there. People feel that it is all right to spend a lot of money to train people in management, as has occurred over many years in universities and other company situations, to get the best deal for shareholders and those people who own the means of production and have had power in this country, but as soon as a Labor government establishes an organisation that, in fairness, provides training for workers to represent the people and provides the opportunity for trade union officials to become more effective and efficient on their behalf, all of a sudden that is a terrible thing.

If there has been an increase in the amount of money spent I would want to look at a number of things. One of the things I would want to ask would be: What has TUTA done with the money? I notice that the report talks about training performance. In 1983-84 there were 601 courses and in 1987-88 there were 1,069 courses. I will not suggest that, because we have more courses, it will necessarily result in an improvement in the courses. But I am suggesting that a lot more work has been done. There is more understanding and cooperation in the community and there has been more forward thinking on the part of trade unions. They have initiated propositions to change awards by restructuring them. They have looked at new career paths. They have looked at opportunities which can be given to people, whatever their age and whatever industry they are in, to gradually improve their ability by learning new skills, by accepting more responsibility. Provided that management has the ability to take the advantage of it, higher productivity and benefits will flow to the community. It would be better if people such as Senator Bishop were to look at the positive aspects of TUTA and recognise that it does an excellent and constructive job for this country and that it needs to do it in a bigger and better way in the future. If the organisations that have been established by this Government to help various sections of the community had all achieved the same level of excellence and were all as productive and as useful to the community as TUTA, Australia would be doing very well. I commend the report.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Coulter Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the paper.

I draw attention to the opening policy content in the report of the Department of Aboriginal Affairs. In view of the debates that we have had in the last few days, it is important to note that it draws attention to the way in which the Aboriginal people were disregarded by the white settlers who came to this country, to the fact that many of the original inhabitants were dispossessed and dispersed, and that their culture was disrupted-which is a point that needs to be stressed over and over again-and threatened. Today their descendants are the most disadvantaged people in the Australian society. The report details a number of ways in which Aboriginal people are dealt with as second class citizens in a predominantly white society in which their individual cultural contribution to the society is under-recognised or totally ignored.

The report mentions among other things that the average Aboriginal life expectancy at birth is 15 to 20 years less than that of other Australians. It mentions that Aboriginal infant mortality, while improving, is still three times that of non-Aboriginal Australians. It says that there is a higher incidence of communicable diseases, such as hepatitis B, and that there are lifestyle diseases such as diabetes and heart disease which are more prevalent among Aboriginal people.

If one reflects upon the culture in which Aboriginal people lived in this country for 40,000 years, it is clear that those diseases were not prevalent before white settlement. The quality of nutrition for Aboriginal people under tribal conditions was extremely good, except in times of extreme drought. A number of the native foods were extremely rich in protein and in essential amino acids. With the lower intake of refined carbohydrates Aborigines did not suffer from diseases such as diabetes or heart disease to the extent they do today. Those diseases have been imposed on Aboriginal people by white society.

The list goes on. It says that Aboriginal unemployment is six times the national average, that Aboriginals earn only half the income of other Australians, that they live in substandard housing, and that the imprisonment rates for Aboriginal people are 14 times those of other Australians.

I draw attention to a couple of figures which are shown early in the report. I do so because of statements which Opposition members have been hammering very hard in recent days, in which they have been stressing the way in which money that has been spent by this Department and also by the Aboriginal Development Commission has been wasted. The Opposition has been talking about how, with the wave of a hand, millions of dollars have been going down the drain. The Department has an average staffing level of 721, representing 0.43 per cent of the Commonwealth Public Service. The Aboriginal population is 1.43 per cent of the total population of Australia. So on a per capita basis they have approximately one-third the number of public servants employed in Aboriginal Affairs. Of the total Commonwealth Budget outlays, 0.83 per cent goes to the Aboriginal area. Again, that is approximately half what is spent on other Australians. Those figures need to be kept very clearly in mind when the Opposition lays into those departments which deal with Aboriginal affairs and claims that they are wasting money.
