DEBATE.TITLE: TAXATION LAWS AMENDMENT BILL (No. 5) 1988INCOME TAX RATES AMENDMENT BILL 1988SALES TAX (EXEMPTIONS AND CLASSIFICATIONS) AMENDMENT BILL (No. 2) 1988

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crichton-Browne Sen N.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —As I have but nine or 10 minutes left in which to speak, regrettably I have to rush through my speech at a much more superficial level than I would have wished. Prior to the disruption of my speech, I was making the point that the proponents of the tax on gold companies base their arguments around the obsessive quest for equity in taxation. They argue that the non-gold producing companies in the mineral sector are in an underprivileged position when compared with goldmining companies. A couple of points need to be made in that regard. First, gold exploration is a high risk enterprise and, therefore, is dependent on equity and retained earnings to finance the venture. It is unable to raise capital on the basis of using as security long term contracts because gold sales are all on spot markets. In this regard, the comments of Dr Alan Reynolds, the chief economist of Polyconomics in the United States, should be noted. He correctly stated:

SPEECH.PARA: The whole point of exempting gold from Australia's corporate tax has been to lower that industry's cost of equity capital. Taxing both corporate profits and capital gains at 49 per cent-
as it then was-
which no successful economy does-is a ``double tax'' on retained profits. That biases the tax system against high risk enterprises.

It should also be realised that the gold industry must take the price for which it can sell its gold as set by world commodity prices. In a 1975 study the United States economist and the now Senator Phil Gramm said:
If the policy is to reduce output, employment and investment as little as possible, the worst type of industry to tax is one that must take a world commodity price as given.

That is exactly what the goldmining industry is. That makes a mockery of Senator Cook's answer to a question without notice in October that if Australia's miners accelerate their development they will run the risk of bringing down the market price by putting more gold on the market. Given that Australia produces only 6 per cent of the world's supply of gold, it is equally clear that a tax-induced reduction of investment which reduces supply will not raise the price of gold, just as a tax-induced increase of supply will not lower prices. I find it devastating that Senator Cook, the Minister for Resources, could come in here and put that absurd proposition to us.

It is claimed that the tax free status of goldmining companies diverts some investment away from other mining companies into gold. However, this is not to say that other mining industries are disadvantaged by the level of investment in goldmining. The strength of the goldmining industry has historically been an important factor in facilitating exploration for other minerals. The goldmining centre of Kalgoorlie is a classic example of that. As a result of the gold boom of the late 1800s came possibly the largest and certainly the most daring engineering project of its kind in the world at that time: the pumping of water from Perth to the goldfields of Kalgoorlie through a pipeline over a distance of 600 kilometres. It was the supply of that water which allowed Kalgoorlie to exist as a town in its own right after the gold boom died. Since then it has become a very significant centre for the exploration and development of a wide range of other minerals. Therefore, it cannot be realistically asserted that the other mining industries are significantly disadvantaged by a prospering gold industry.

This Government, faced with a tax system which has become an irrefutable example of a successful economic policy in industry, chooses not to adopt the system as a model. Instead, it feels morally obliged to cripple all industries evenly. It is widely recognised-at least on the non-Labor side of politics-that Australia's low savings and investment rates, combined with high levels of private and public consumption, are the prime factors behind our high current account and foreign deficits. Of course, it is not surprising that Australia's savings rate is a mere 23 per cent of gross domestic product compared with 31 and 32 per cent in Korea and Japan respectively. In this regard I refer the Senate to an article in last weekend's Sydney Morning Herald which reported the Economic Planning Advisory Council (EPAC) as recognising that savings could be increased by lowering the tax on interest earned on savings-a logically compelling proposition. In other words, what EPAC is saying is that the double taxation of income impacts adversely on savings and investment.

It is therefore clear that, if we are to level the playing field of taxation in pursuit of equity, we should not be raising gold to the high levels of taxation which currently apply to the rest of the economy. Rather, as Professor Michael Porter said in a speech in October this year:
We should be generating a playing field in which all savings and investment is largely exempt from taxation, thereby removing the double taxation of savings.

In other words, the taxation arrangements currently applying to the gold industry should be used as a model on which to base taxation generally-that is, an environment in which there are no incentives to invest in gold over other forms of investment: in other words, simply reduce the level of taxation and have the same sort of taxation system that now exists essentially in the gold industry for all industries, with different write-off provisions in terms of investment cost. To create this environment, Porter and the Centre of Policy Studies use an adjusted income tax which nets out investment expenditure from the income tax base. In comparison, however, the Hawke Government would abolish the taxation regime applying to gold in an attempt to create a level playing field by raising taxation.

The Government seems not to have fully understood the extent to which the loss to revenue will be recovered by the imputation and capital gains clawback. What the Government has clearly failed to consider is the fact that the reduction in exploration and goldmining development which, by necessity, will result from the removal of the exemption will obviously reduce the activity being taxed. Accordingly, there will be less revenue from the proposed company tax than is estimated and, further, less revenue will be collected from payroll tax, employees' income tax and, of course, shareholders' tax from the capital gains tax and dividends.

It is clear that the Hawke Government has underestimated the extent to which the tax will cripple the industry. Senator Cook, as I mentioned this morning, has clearly demonstrated the Government's ignorance of the nature of the goldmining industry. In providing answers to questions without notice in this chamber, the Minister claimed that 20 new goldmines were commissioned in 1987-88, 10 of them after the May economic statement announcement of the gold tax. The Minister has also said that a further 30 mines were expected to come on stream by the end of the year. I merely refer Senator Cook and the Senate to an article by Malcolm Hollingsworth in the November edition of Australia's Mining Monthly, which is a very interesting monthly magazine. Notwithstanding that Mr Hollingsworth is a friend of Senator Cook, he said he could not understand how a Minister of this Government could be so incompetent in terms of his announcement. He said:
Your list of the 30 mines starting up this year. . . justifying the impost, names two mines that are in the wrong States, one that has finished mining and another that has its name misspelt.

He gave a long list of the failings of the proposition which has been put by Senator Cook. I would be interested to know whether the Minister thinks that companies have indulged in a sudden rush of highly successful exploration since the May economic statement. He certainly must find it convenient to ignore the fact that these mines are the result of long term exploration projects. Large investments have already been sunk not only into exploration but also into processing plants. Of equal importance is the fact that high risk factors have already been accepted-risks that were taken under assurances from the Hawke Government that a tax on gold would not be introduced. Nobody believed it, but people were compelled to proceed and now they are reaping the rewards of their belief. Such statements can only serve to reduce the credibility of the Government's revenue estimates.

The termination of the gold industry's tax exempt status will offer no benefits to any other sector of the Australian economy. The tragedy is that this tax will not offer relief to any other sector of the economy. The tax is simply a further impost which will go into this Government's total revenue and there will be no benefits and no cuts for anybody else. I condemn the legislation.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Teague Sen B.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —There has been a long list of Opposition speakers on the three Bills which we are debating cognately because they all represent the tax profile of the Labor Government, which for six years has been more tax and a greater burden on the Australian people-both individuals and companies. This Government has had a six-year pattern of increasing the tax burden on the Australian people in terms of sales tax imposts and every other kind of tax. There is only one glimmer of hope or good news in all the measures before us in the Sales Tax (Exemptions and Classifications) Amendment Bill (No. 2), the Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 5) and the Income Tax Rates Amendment Bill; that is, the implementation of the May 1988 decision to cut company tax in Australia from 49c to 39c in the dollar, a reform which we in the Opposition have urged upon this Government for years and which we announced in our policy as one of the priority measures that we would introduce in government.

SPEECH.PARA: That is only one of the measures that a Liberal-National Party government would introduce. We give even more priority to the need to cut personal income tax so that the burden placed by the Labor Government on Australian families can be lifted-so that they can be restored to the level of available income to spend at their own discretion that they had in 1982, before the momentum developed year by year in increasing tax imposts on Australian families. We have announced in recent years, particularly before the last election, and it was reiterated in our commentary on the May statement and the recent Budget, that a Liberal-National Party government would significantly cut income taxation, taxes on families. I believe that that will be seen by Australian families only after the election of a Liberal-National Party government. Certainly, there is no news of tax cuts for ordinary Australians and for Australian families in any of the measures now before the Senate. There are adjustments to sales tax, to company tax, and to a number of other taxes, such as the gold tax, which my colleague Senator Crichton-Browne was just now addressing in his speech. But there is no news of any income cuts for individuals and for families.

Even now, whilst there is still speculation that there may be such cuts from 1 July next year, by measures yet to be announced, debated, or implemented by legislation, those cuts are in doubt. The Treasurer (Mr Keating), the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke), and the Minister for Finance (Senator Walsh) have made contradictory statements as to whether the country can afford the tax cuts which the Labor Government has begun to promise in its off-the-cuff statements. The Labor Government is being met by the public of Australia saying, `You've given this tax cut to companies from 49c to 39c and we are feeling the increasing burden on us, as a family. When are we going to get tax cuts? When will we be restored to the same income level which we had before the Labor Government was elected?'. In recent weeks the message has been that because the foundation of the present Labor Budget was based on solving Australia's balance of payments problem and that this has blown away from all of the estimates and standards on which this Budget was built, to give tax cuts may lead to yet further imbalance in this country's balance of payments. If the tax cuts were given, would not Australians spend that money increasingly by overseas purchases, and would this not lead to a yet further unsound position for the Australian economy?

Nervous doubts in the minds of the Treasurer and the Prime Minister have created signals in recent weeks that the tax cuts for individuals and for families may not be on. Another reason they are in doubt is that they are being linked by the Labor Government's Ministers to a tax-wage trade-off with the Australian Council of Trade Unions (ACTU). It is still to be seen whether the proposal, particularly from Mr Kelty, about the restructuring of wages will be economically responsible and will allow the tax cuts. If the restructuring which the ACTU and the trade union movement want to put in place is going to create irresponsible increases in wages, then the Government will say, `Bang go the tax cuts'.

At the moment, we all have grave doubts as to whether or not the Labor Government will deliver its promise on tax cuts. In the Opposition our position is firm. If elected to government, a Liberal-National Party government will bring tax cuts to individuals and to families. We are conscious that the Labor Government, when talking about its hope to have a $20 a week tax cut for the average worker, will fall short by more than $30 a week because of the erosion of available income in the hands of the average worker of some $56 a week that has accrued during the six years of the Hawke-Keating Labor Government. Will the tax cuts be $56 a week, to return to the position of 1982 before the election of this Labor Government?

TALK.START.PARA: —My dog will jump over the moon before that.

—Senator Crichton-Browne says that somebody is going to jump over the moon before that will happen. I know that in this chamber Senator Walsh has said that the Australian public should not be expecting $56 a week tax cuts for the average wage earner. Even on the best admission-setting aside the two areas of doubt of which I have spoken with regard to the wage-tax trade-off or with regard to the balance of payments-the Government is wanting to dampen expectations by saying, `No, we will not give the $56 a week in tax cuts. You will be lucky to get $20 a week'.

SPEECH.PARA: I highlighted this important matter in my opening remarks, because it is only on some occasions that we have before us tax Bills such as the package of these three Bills being debated tonight in the Senate. Not only must we denounce this Government for placing more and more burdens upon the Australian people through its increasing tax measures, but we must draw attention in this chamber to the failure of this Government to give any tax relief to the individuals and families of Australia.

It has been remarked on by many commentators that the Hawke-Keating Government is the biggest taxing government in Australian history. That is a record which has been held for six years in a row. The first year, as this chamber will recall, in which the Hawke-Keating Government brought down a Budget was 1983. The Senate will recall the change of government in March 1983. Some months later, in August of that year, the first Labor Government Budget came down and established a tax burden on Australians that broke all previous records. Not only was the burden and the strain of that Budget felt by the Australian people in 1983, but the next year the Hawke-Keating Labor Government broke its own record as the highest taxing government in Australian history.

The pattern has continued in 1985, 1986, 1987, and again this year, 1988. The increase in the tax burden on the Australian people is not only in monetary terms, in that the tax take is more billions of dollars in each of those six years, but also in real terms. Taking account of inflation, coming back to the real purchasing power of the Australian dollar, the tax burden on the Australian people in real terms has increased in each of the six year of the Labor Government. Top priority should be given to tax reforms so that this tax burden can be eased. I can only assure this Senate that, given the track record of the Labor Government, the only way that this situation will be remedied is for a Liberal-National Party government to be elected.

With those introductory remarks which join with my colleagues in their contributions about the Income Tax Rates Amendment Bill and the Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 5), I wish to concentrate my remarks on the third Bill, which is the Sales Tax (Exemptions and Classifications) Amendment Bill (No. 2). This Bill is 2 1/2 pages long. I am sure that the Government did not want any of us to refer to this tiny Bill in the debate on the tax measures that are before the Senate. The few sentences in the second reading speech of the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories (Senator Richardson) contain no reference whatsoever to the retrospective aspects of this sales tax measure, nor to the bumbling mistakes that the Government has made with regard to its comprehensive reform of sales tax. `Reform' is too nice a description; I should say `increased burden', which is what will happen as a result of these sales tax measures.

The Senate would accept the proposition that an elected government with a majority in the House of Representatives is entitled in its Budget or May statement to increase sales tax in a way which is consistent across the spectrum and is fair, one sector to another. The fact is that the Government forgot to include some of those consistent measures in the Sales Tax (Exemptions and Classifications) Amendment Bill 1988 [No. 2] which it introduced this year. In November, only last month, the Minister for Industrial Relations and Minister Assisting the Treasurer (Mr Peter Morris) introduced into the House of Representatives the Sales Tax (Exemptions and Classifications) Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1988 to tidy up the position. The Minister had the gall and the arrogance to say that in effect this Bill will operate from the same day-that is, 8 o'clock on Budget day in August-as do the other sales tax measures. But the Australian public, and particularly the companies which are affected by this sales tax measure, have had no warning. On the contrary, they thought that the sales tax legislation that was introduced into the Parliament in August did implement the full extent of the Government's decisions. The measure that is before us now would create a grave injustice and it must be amended by the Senate. If it is not amended, it will have a retrospective effect which is unfair. We must not allow the Government to slip in this small piece of legislation in the hope that it will not be noticed among the sales tax measures before the Senate.

Let me refer to the history of this matter. Since 1935 there has been, among the exemptions listed in the Sales Tax (Exemptions and Classifications) Act, an exemption under item 92 for bags-plastic and paper bags that contain foods and other items. These paper and other bags have had a longstanding exemption from sales tax. General references were made in the Budget announcements for this year to removing certain exemptions affecting goods used by retailers to wrap or secure goods for marketing or delivery. It is most important to note that specific legislation, not a general announcement, is needed to confirm the exact items which will attract sales tax. It is in this respect that the Government left Australia in confusion.

Madam Acting Deputy President, I believe it is fair for you, me and other members of this chamber to be entitled to think that the Sales Tax (Exemptions and Classifications) Amendment Bill 1988 [No. 2] that was introduced in the House of Representatives on 23 August would cover all of the concrete expressions of the Government's intentions and that the people affected could order their affairs accordingly. We accept the principle that changes in tax announced on Budget night can operate from that date, so long as the legislation is consistent with that announcement. The Bill introduced on 23 August made no change to item 92 in the first schedule of the Act, although changes were made to numerous other items. The legislation duly passed through the Parliament and became law. One might have thought that that was the end of the matter and that the position was clear for the foreseeable future. But this is not the case. Because the Government messed it up and because there was an inconsistency, the Government introduced a further Bill on 3 November-the Bill to amend item 92.

As I have said, unfortunately it has been announced that the amendment will have retrospective effect from Budget night when it should have effect only from 3 November, the day on which the Bill was introduced into the Parliament. This Bill clearly corrects in a concrete and specific way what we in this Parliament and the public would have expected the earlier measure to contain. People were entitled to think that the Government was not planning to amend item 92.

The Opposition has frequently had reason to criticise the Government's practice of legislation by press release-even in regard to tax matters. This practice causes uncertainty among taxpayers who have to organise their affairs on the basis of vague press statements with detailed legislation following months or, as we have seen recently-as Senator Messner would know very well-even years later. I draw an analogy between this Bill and the process of legislation by press release that I am criticising. In this instance, the Government is relying on its words of 23 August which were presented in the most general form. Surely the Senate will insist that the Government cannot get away with this kind of approach.

Taxpayers who have been operating on the basis of the actual legislation of 23 August are now being told that this was wrongly drafted and that they will bear the consequences, the costs, of the Government's own mistake. Clearly, that is not good enough. It is important that there should be certainty about taxation laws, especially in respect of sales tax, which wholesalers pass on to retailers. There needs to be certainty when a transaction occurs so that wholesalers and retailers know that the sales tax has been calculated correctly. That amount of money owing by way of sales tax is then passed on to the Commissioner of Taxation and the Australian Taxation Office. But there should not be any kind of uncertainty or dithering.

Let me cite the specific effect that this Bill will have on Detmold Packaging, a firm in my State of South Australia which manufactures bags. In the 10-week period between 23 August and 3 November this company operated on the basis that the legislation before the Parliament in August expressed the Government's policy and sold bags worth $1.11m. Detmold has been told that it will have to hand over $187,000 in sales tax in respect of the $1 million sale of paper bags. This decision is totally wrong. I see that Senator Foreman, another senator from South Australia, who is sitting on the other side of the chamber, agrees with me in his heart and mind that in this day and age that sort of penalty on a good South Australian firm should not be imposed. Governments ought to be able to get their announcements about legislation sufficiently in order that South Australian companies such as this do not suffer that kind of penalty.
Sitting suspended from 6.30 to 8 p.m.

TALK.START.PARA: —Before the suspension of the sitting for dinner I was joining the many in the Opposition who, with regard to the three tax Bills before us, have decried the present Hawke Labor Government for the tax burden that has been placed upon the Australian people. We saw record taxation in 1983, taxation Australia had never before experienced. In 1984 taxation increased to a new record. In 1985, 1986 and 1987 it increased again. The burden of taxation borne by the Australian people is still unsurpassed in 1988. When we have three taxation Bills before the Senate it is timely to remind this chamber of the record tax burden that has been placed on Australians by the Hawke-Keating Labor Government.

SPEECH.PARA: In the measures before us we see increase after increase in taxation, with the only good news being company tax being lowered from 49c to 39c in the dollar. There is no mention whatsoever of any tax cuts for the ordinary Australian, for individual taxpayers or for families. I mentioned before the suspension of the sitting that the tax cuts we all look for-that we in the Opposition, the Liberal and National parties, firmly promise on coming to government after the next election-are now in jeopardy because the Government has in mind a tax-wage trade-off that appears to be related to the Kelty restructuring of wages. In addition, the balance of payments problem has so undermined the viability of the Government's Budget that again there is uncertainty about tax cuts coming to individuals and families. These measures are not before us in the Senate. They are in jeopardy, even with regard to the hopeful date of 1 July next year.

The only tax cuts that will be worthy of the name are those that may be worth $56 a week to the average taxpayer. If we had tax cuts of that dimension it would at least bring Australian families back to the level of discretionary income that they had in real terms before the present Government was elected in 1983. That is what we are sure will not be achieved by the present Labor Government. It is talking about tax cuts of only $20 a week, not $56 a week, for the average taxpayer. I have my own doubts that there will be tax cuts even of $20 a week for ordinary Australians. To give tax cuts of $20 a week will return only a small portion of the tax hike that we have all suffered as a result of the record breaking taxation burden that the Labor Government has placed on us. It would return only a small part of what has arisen from one measure alone, that is, bracket creep, whereby the incomes of families, through inflation alone, rising through the taxation levels leads to a greater tax take by the Government. Bracket creep has taken scores of dollars a week from the average family. We are not even given the promise that this bracket creep take by the present Government will be returned.

I have particularly addressed the Sales Tax (Exemptions and Classifications) Amendment Bill (No. 2) and shown how this second sales tax Bill to come before the Senate has arisen because the Government messed up its sales tax announcements in the Budget Speech and in the legislation introduced at the time of the Budget. This has led to this additional sales tax measure, which was introduced on 3 November.

I have highlighted how this will affect just one company in my State of South Australia, Detmold Packaging, which manufactures paper bags and other bags. For example, with this legislation taking effect from Budget day, 23 August, instead of the day on which it was introduced into the Parliament, 3 November, this will lead to that one company, Detmold Packaging, having to hand over $187,000 in tax that it did not expect and was not liable for. The effect on this one company that I highlighted prior to the dinner break is a good illustration of why this Bill must be amended by the Senate. I believe it will be amended by the Senate because the Australian Democrats have agreed with the Opposition to remedy the faults of the Government in this proposal so that it should operate only from 3 November. On the initiative of the Liberal and National parties, we will deny the retrospective reach of this sales tax measure. It should not reach back before 3 November. Our amendment, with the support of the majority of this chamber, will ensure that there is not a penalty on taxpayers--

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable senator's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Stone Sen J.O.

TALKER.NAME: Senator STONE
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —We are debating cognately the Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 5) 1988, the Income Tax Rates Amendment Bill 1988 and the Sales Tax (Exemptions and Classifications) Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1988. My remarks will be devoted to the first of these Bills, the Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 5) 1988, and specifically to that part of the Bill which effects, as from 1 January 1991, the removal of the exemption from company tax which is presently enjoyed by the goldmining industry. Having listened to the debate on this matter over the last day or so, you will be aware, Mr Acting Deputy President, that there are numerous things that can be said about this legislation. For example, it can be argued, and has been argued in this place, that the goldmining industry is one of our most thriving industries-as indeed it is. But, for that matter, so would be any other industry that enjoyed the same freedom from company tax as does the goldmining industry.

SPEECH.PARA: It can also be argued, and has been argued here, that the goldmining industry is a major contributor to our export income and that, particularly with our present disastrous balance of payments, this should be a major consideration when thinking about the tax regime to be applied to this industry. Indeed, that industry is a major contributor to our export income. But so would any other export industry be if it enjoyed the same freedom from company tax as does the goldmining industry when no other industries enjoy that freedom. Let us just imagine the contribution to exports that our wool industry, for example, could make. It already makes a very big one. Just imagine how much bigger a one it could make if it were totally free of company income tax. Just imagine what a contribution the engineering manufacturing industry, for example, could make-or dozens of others. It can be argued, and has been here in the last day or so, that the goldmining industry is vital to the lives of many of our remote outback communities, as well as to other centres such as Kalgoorlie, which may not be quite in that category but which nevertheless are thriving centres of population in areas well removed from their respective metropolitan cities-Perth in the case of Kalgoorlie.

By way of digression, I should say that my mother grew up in Kalgoorlie, so I have a certain affection for that city and the industry around which its fortunes revolve. Indeed, my grandfather, the man after whom I am named, John Owen Hunt, as he was called, died and was buried there in 1905, having been employed on one of the great mines. All the things that are argued in favour of the importance of the goldmining industry to the maintenance and survival of these remote outback communities and other centres such as Kalgoorlie are true.

Of course, the same would be true, although no doubt in different specific localities, if an income tax exemption were granted to all other activities undertaken in remote localities, however defined. I am not advocating that. I am simply making the point in passing that in this respect also the argument is not singular to the goldmining industry. Indeed, the only point I want to make in these few opening remarks is that there is nothing special about the goldmining industry as such so far as any of these particular arguments are concerned. The arguments concern the advantages to any industry which accrue to it when it is granted exemption from a tax which every other industry within the economy pays.

There has been a major change in the system of company taxation in Australia in the last year or so through the introduction of the so-called imputation system, the taxation of company dividends. It is worth while spending a little time on the implications of that for the matter I am talking about here tonight. Let us think about the effects of that change in the income tax area. Let us assume that a goldmining company which is paying dividends has some shareholders who are Australian residents and liable to Australian tax and other shareholders who are foreign residents and therefore not liable to Australian tax as such, although dividends payable to them are, of course, subject to dividend withholding tax, which in most cases would be levied at the rate applicable to countries with which Australia has a double taxation agreement, namely, 10 per cent. It is 20 per cent in the case of other countries, but they are insignificant for these purposes.

As things stand today, with no company tax levied on goldmining companies, Australian shareholders who receive dividends from goldmining companies pay the full marginal rate of personal income tax upon those dividends. Let us say it is 50.25 per cent, including the Medicare rebate. As I indicated a moment ago, foreigners are not liable to that tax, although their dividends are subject to dividend withholding tax at, let us say, the rate of 10 per cent applicable to countries with which we have double taxation agreements. When those foreign shareholders submit their taxation returns to their own national governments, let us say, the Government of the United States of America or the Government of Britain, they are entitled to claim credit against the taxation to which they would otherwise be liable in their own countries for the dividend withholding tax that they have paid or that has been paid on their dividends. Otherwise those dividends become fully taxable, subject to that credit, in their hands in the countries concerned.

As the second reading speech of the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories (Senator Richardson) pointed out, quite accurately, in such cases foreign treasuries do pick up the difference between the 10 per cent dividend withholding tax credit and whatever the personal rate of the shareholder concerned is. The result is that the foreign shareholder is levied at precisely the same rate as he would be if he was paying tax on a share of a company in his own country. But what is happening in that case is that the foreign treasuries benefit, naturally enough. Australians who receive dividends from a goldmining company will, because those goldmining companies pay no company tax, be levied at the full marginal rate. They will not be able to claim an imputation credit because of the nature of the system.

The proposal in the Bill is to impose company tax on goldmining companies as from 1 January 1991. If companies then pay dividends to Australians, those Australians will then be entitled to claim the imputation rebate in respect of the company tax which has been paid on their behalf by the company. So they will not be any worse off as a result of the change in the system, or at least not in respect of income tax. I will come in a moment to the question of whether they would be worse off as a result of capital appreciation of their shares; that is a different matter.

In future foreign shareholders will be able to claim a credit in respect of the tax paid by the company. That will mean that the amount of tax they will be liable to pay themselves will be reduced. The only loser will be the treasuries in the United States of America, Britain or wherever the shareholder has his or her residence. We have a situation there where, basically, there is no real detriment to the foreign shareholder or to the Australian shareholder as a result of the action. We have a situation where the companies are paying tax where they did not pay tax before. The Australian Taxation Office will pick up tax from the companies, but foreign treasuries will not pick up tax from the companies. I personally cannot see why one could reasonably object to that situation on those grounds.

There is, however, another area of interest for shareholders, and that is in respect of the capital appreciation of their shareholdings. It is true that where one has, as at present, company income untaxed, then profits which are ploughed back on an untaxed basis, as distinct from being distributed, increase the net worth of a company at a faster rate than such profits would increase it if they were ploughed back on a taxed basis, by definition. That is another way of saying that the capital appreciation of such shares over a period under the present situation is more rapid than it is likely to be after those companies start paying tax. I do not think there is any real argument about that. One should say, for the sake of completeness, that following the introduction of capital gains tax, which I personally did not agree with and which will be removed by the Opposition when it is elected to government, the difference between the effective value in the hands of the shareholders of those differential rates of appreciation of the company shares has been diminished. As I say, that is a qualification to the more general point.

So we have a situation where, in the absence of company tax, our Taxation Office does not get any tax, in effect, from foreign shareholders other than the dividend withholding tax and does get tax from Australian shareholders if dividends are distributable; whereas with taxation at the company level our Taxation Office gets the tax from both Australian and foreign shareholders, but Australian shareholders then receive imputation credit in respect of any dividends payable to them.

Some commentators have suggested, notwithstanding these on the whole rather persuasive arguments in favour of the levelling of the playing field approach, that the goldmining industry is a kind of tax haven within our taxation system-along with the principal private residence, for example. After all, the principal private residence does not attract tax in terms of the imputed rent or imputed income which we derive from our private residences; it does not attract capital gains tax, and it does not count for the purposes of the assets test for the age pension. So the principal private residence is an exceedingly valuable and exceedingly singular asset within our present tax welfare system.

Some people have suggested that goldmining companies are in a somewhat similar position in so far as they represent one other area of the total economic firmament, so to speak, where people have a chance still to earn a decent income from an investment and, hence, where an incentive is provided to save and invest, and all those entirely desirable and worthwhile actions. Such people argue that it is precisely because the principal private residence and, indeed, the goldmining companies, are free of taxes and otherwise favourably considered in the taxation cum welfare system that those areas of our economy are booming, whereas the rest of it is sluggish, to say the least. They argue from that that the freedom from tax in these areas encourages savings and that, if only for that reason, we should not be subjecting the goldmining industry to taxation but rather should be equalising things by removing company tax before anything else. That is the way the argument runs.

In other words, the argument is that we should level the playing field not by removing this lump on it-the goldmining industry-but by building up the rest of the playing field to the same level as the bump. I think that there is a certain attractiveness about that point of view at first sight, although perhaps when one comes to examine it the attraction is less apparent in practice. One minor problem about an approach of that kind is that company tax revenue is estimated in the Budget to yield $10.2 billion this year. If one were to follow the approach advocated by the advocates and abolish company tax entirely, thereby putting every other industry on a par with the goldmining industry, one would have to find, other things being equal, $10.2 billion in revenue from somewhere else, or cut spending by $10.2 billion. I would be in favour of the second option, of course; nevertheless, it does not exactly figure in the views of these advocates. They do not generally put forward a list of $10.2 billion worth of expenditure cuts to finance such a proposal.

TALK.START.PARA: —Give us a list of the $10.2 billion worth.

—I am sorry to disappoint the Minister, but I have not time today to supply them to him. I do not want, however, to rubbish that kind of argument entirely because it can be argued that a so-called fully integrated system of company tax-one whereby tax is payable not at the company level itself but purely at the shareholder level, but whereby the company actually collects the tax-would in some ways be preferable to the system of imputation that we now have.

SPEECH.PARA: Indeed, I have seen some advertisements from the goldmining industry which have pointed out that the Government itself in its own draft White Paper on tax reform back in 1985 argued a case along those lines. It argued for a fully integrated system of company taxation rather than the imputation system. That is perfectly true. That draft White Paper did so argue. But I have noticed that those advertisements, regrettably in terms of their credibility and perhaps the credibility of those sponsoring them, while noting that there were certain practical difficulties referred to in the draft White Paper when considering the possible choice between the two company tax systems, did not go further into the nature of what those practical difficulties might be. As I say, it is perhaps regrettable that these advertisements have simply glossed over the nature of those practical difficulties.

Without going into it in too much detail, as I do not have the time, amongst other reasons, the nature of those practical difficulties leads from the fact that if in an economy which is as heavily penetrated by foreign capital as the Australian economy is-in other words, an economy where the equity in our company structure is as considerably in the hands of foreigners, and I am not being xenophobic about this but simply stating a fact, as Australian equity capital in the corporate sector is-we were to remove all company tax, that would of course relieve foreign shareholders of the tax they are presently paying, implicitly or explicitly. We would then have again on a nationwide scale the problem to which I was pointing earlier, and to which Ministers have pointed previously in relation to the particular example of the goldmining industry. We would be simply generalising the problem that has been pointed to concerning the present basis of taxation of the goldmining industry. Having said all that, one might ask why I am opposing this Bill.

TALK.START.PARA: —Good question.

—As the Minister says, it is a good question. I knew that he would say it was a good question; that is why I asked it for him. At this time of the evening he often needs a bit of help in asking questions. Perhaps I can refine the question a little and ask why I am voting for what will be the Opposition's amendment to the Bill in this area. I stress that I do not disagree with the principle of a level playing field; I only wish the Government would apply that principle a bit more generally. For example, it could apply the principle of a level playing field to the respective positions of export industries on the one hand and import competing industries on the other. In that case our miners and farmers would be benefited, instead of being discriminated against as they are at present because we have a high level of industry protection and all sorts of other elements in our total economic system which discriminate against exporters such as miners and farmers. I will not be diverted further on that particular tack.

SPEECH.PARA: I am opposing this Bill, and more particularly this specific area of the Bill, not for economic reasons or for reasons of taxation principle. I have tried to lay out for the benefit of honourable senators the reasons that the taxation principle in question supports the level playing field concept in this area as in others. I am opposing this Bill for the very simple reason that I believe in politicians keeping their word. I believe it will be very important when we come to the next election that the people of this country remember the importance of electing politicians who will keep their word.

I am aware, as all honourable senators in this place are aware, that prior to the last election the Leader of the Opposition, John Howard, promised that the Opposition would not support imposing a company tax on the goldmining industry within the life of the next Parliament-that is, the life of the current Parliament. As a matter of fact, the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) also made such a promise. The Prime Minister made a promise not in precisely the same words but to the same effect. Of course, the Government is getting around that promise; it is weaselling on that promise by introducing the measure but making it effective as from 1 January 1991, which will not be within the life of the present Parliament because, constitutionally, that would be beyond the last possible time for the next election.

I might say in passing that the post-dating of this provision will have some bad effects on the goldmining industry. There is almost two years to go before that provision will come into effect and there is not the slightest doubt that that hiatus will encourage goldminers to maximise their incomes over the current financial year and in 1989-90 and 1990-91. At least for half of that time they will still be on a non-company tax paying basis. They will maximise their income during that time in order to minimise their tax by mining their richest ore. I do not pretend to be a mining expert but even I know that that is not good mining practice. One does not haul out the richest pockets of ore, because doing it all at once, or more rapidly than would otherwise occur, shortens the life of the mine and results in leaving otherwise minable ore in the ground-ore which could be taken out along with rich ore but which, if left there on its own, is no longer rich enough to mine. It is bad mining practice.

This Government, by this post-dated provision, is condemning the goldmining industry to two years of bad mining practice. The Government may say that it is not condemning the goldmining industry to this because, after all, it does not have to behave in that way; but the Government is certainly applying a very strong and powerful stimulus and incentive to the mining industry to behave in that manner. I have very little doubt that many mines will be operated in that way and that will be a loss to Australia.

As I have said, the attitude I finally bring to the vote, I hope later this evening, is that I believe very strongly in the need for political leaders to keep their promises. We have had too many political leaders in this country-I have to say that it has come from both sides of the political spectrum; I do not want to be unfair in that regard-who have not kept their promises. Given the promise made by the Prime Minister prior to the last election that the Government would not impose a company tax on the goldmining industry during the life of the present Parliament, I believe it profoundly important that that promise should be kept. I shall certainly be voting with my colleagues on this side to see that the Government does so.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to make a contribution to this debate, not least because of Senator Walsh's rather intemperate outburst about those people who have argued against the Government's measure to extend company income tax to those companies which are mining gold. In view of his classification of those who oppose this tax as spivs and bludgers-I think that was the expression used-and in light of the fact that the Western Australian members of the Liberal Party of Australia have been fairly active in pursuing the decision that was arrived at by the Opposition, I should like to make a brief contribution.

SPEECH.PARA: I remind the Minister for Finance, Senator Walsh, who is at the table, that the concerns he has had about anyone who opposes the imposition of corporate tax on goldmining companies and the anger and abuse he has expressed are rather odd, given the recent history of his own Government on this question. I have in front of me that Government's Commonwealth Record which states:
16 December 1986-
in other words, just under two years ago-

The Treasurer, the Hon. P J Keating, and the Minister for Resources and Energy, Senator the Hon. Gareth Evans, announced today that the Government had decided not to remove the income tax exemption available to the goldmining industry.
It is worth noting that this announcement was made just after the Government had received a report from Mr Gutman recommending the imposition of the tax. The statement went on to say:

The Government had concluded that the importance of encouraging active exploration and development, and of maximising production and the consequent export income generated by the gold mining industry, outweighed the arguments in favour of removing the industry's long-standing tax exemption.

I think it would be fair to say that Senator Stone in the speech he has just concluded set out the economic arguments which are in favour of removing the exemption. He followed that with a statement as to why he would vote against this particular measure. I do not wish to comment on or detract from the arguments which he has put. I simply observe that it was not only in December 1986 but also as recently as July 1987 that one of the most senior Ministers, the Leader of the Government in the Senate, Senator Button, advised the Industries Assistance Commission in similar terms in a letter which I think was introduced into the debate by Senator Tony Messner who was leading for the Opposition. Senator Button used exactly the same expressions. He said:

. . . the Government decided not to introduce a gold tax because the importance of encouraging exploration and development, and of maximising production and the consequent export income generated by the gold mining industry, outweighed the arguments in favour of removing the industry's long-standing tax exemption.

We are, of course, talking about an exemption which goes back to the 1920s. In 1986 the Government took the view that the removal of the exemption was not in our national interest because of, among other things, the export significance. In that context, now that we have the benefit of hindsight, it is interesting to see the export record of the gold industry. If we look at what has been produced in terms not of value but of weight, we will see that 91,000 kilograms of gold were produced in Australia in 1986-87 compared with 65,000 kilograms in 1985-86 and 49,000 kilograms in 1984-85. There has been a near doubling of gold production in just two years. Exports of gold have increased just as rapidly. Gold exports in 1985-86 amounted to $774m; in 1986-87, $1,552m; and in 1987-88, $2,562m. In other words, the value of gold exports has more than trebled in just two years. In real terms gold exports increased from $653m in 1985-86 to $1,032m in 1986-87 and $1,560m in 1987-88. So in two years real gold exports have increased 2.3 times. In the September quarter gold exports in real terms jumped to $518m, or more than 6 per cent of total exports.

Were we debating this measure in a situation of comparative comfort with respect to our balance of payments, it might be a little easier to understand the change of mind which has overtaken the Government in the last 12 months. Were we in a situation where the circumstances were markedly different to those which led the Treasurer, Mr Keating, to say that we were headed for a banana republic status, one might have more understanding of the Government's thinking. Just last week we were advised that in gross terms our foreign debt had reached $120 billion with our net debt at $93 billion. The current account deficit for the first four months of 1988-89 was $5.4 billion, which is almost 60 per cent of the $9.5 billion Budget forecast for the year. Those figures are bad enough, but the most worrying thing about them is that they have occurred just after we have been told by the Australian Bureau of Statistics that Australia's terms of trade have recovered to an extent where they are better than they have been for a decade. If we examine the figures which underlie the cash figures which measure our imports and our exports, we get an absolutely terrifying situation. The truth is that the gap between what we buy and what we sell is growing. The apparent improvement since 1986, banana republic year, is not in terms of the physical movement of goods and services but in the terms of trade.

The Minister for Finance was not one who ranted about the terms of trade quite as much as the Treasurer. There was a long period when we could not hear the Treasurer speak without hearing him refer to the terms of trade. They were the father, the mother, the foster parent and the wholesale producer of our economic difficulties. Mr Keating became a bore on the issue of our terms of trade, to the extent that he educated the whole of the Australian public to understand that that was important. He seems to have been surprisingly silent on the subject over the last year and a half.

It is important to remember that the advance of our terms of trade, the improvement-which was not predicted by anybody I met in private enterprise, in the bureaucracy or in politics-is the real reason for the comparative ease of mind that exists at least in big business circles in this country and perhaps in the minds of some senior Ministers. If one examines what is happening to our merchandise trade, one sees that it is a terrifying prospect for this country. I do not believe that the Minister for Finance would deny that we face a significantly difficult situation, which means that if the price of our commodities declines again we will be in an even more difficult situation than we were in 1986.

I make that point because it is part of a pattern of failure on the part of this Government with respect to our economic fundamentals. If one looks at our inflation rate, wages growth, productivity growth and interest rates, one finds a horrifying picture of an uncompetitive country. I will not weary the Senate with the details of the figures which I have before me, but it is fair to say that we are usually half as bad again as anybody else and often twice as bad again. I will not weary the Senate with the lamentable productivity of some of our key service areas such as the waterfront. The fact is that we are a country with very significant difficulties. The reasons which the Treasurer gave in 1986 for believing that it would be unhelpful to tax gold remain true today and, in my view, even more so. The figures speak for themselves. The Government's strategy in that sense of encouraging a rapidly growing export industry has proved to be true. I do not need to labour the point because Senator Stone, at the end of his speech, clearly made the practical points which go to why an imposition of such a tax will have some influence.

One does not like to be classified as a spiv and a bludger because one adopts a position on a matter which has been held by all parties in this place since, I think, 1921. One should not respond to the Minister and his extravagance of expression. However, let me quote a person who, admittedly from a position of interest, has put, in a cool and calm way, the position of the gold industry with respect to gold tax. I refer to Sir Arvi Parbo, who is, I think, widely admired not just on my side of politics but, I suspect, on the Government side of politics.

TALK.START.PARA: —Disgraceful-Western Mining.

—I like the Minister's interjections of how disgraceful everybody is. Everybody is disgraceful who disagrees with this Minister. I will quote from a passage of Sir Arvi Parbo's Chairman's address to Western Mining Corporation Holdings Ltd, which was, of course, an address by a chairman of a major goldminer and, therefore, clearly from that perspective. If the Minister is prepared to classify Sir Arvi Parbo as a spiv and a bludger, I suspect that he will get little comfort from his colleagues. Sir Arvi Parbo said:

SPEECH.PARA: We are from time to time asked why gold companies think they should be exempt from paying tax when everyone else has to pay it. This question is based on a wide misunderstanding of the issue.

Gold companies pay all the usual taxes except corporation tax and shareholders pay full income tax on dividends arising out of gold mining profits. Other companies pay corporation tax, but are then able to pass on an imputation credit to shareholders who receive a corresponding credit against their income tax liability.

It is therefore not that the gold mining industry does not pay tax. Gold companies and their shareholders taken together pay income tax through a system which is very close to the so-called integration method of corporate taxation, as compared with the alternative imputation method which is presently applied to all other industry. The only departure from the integration method is that shareholders of gold mining companies pay tax on retained earnings only when those earnings are distributed as dividends.

In the 1985 White Paper on taxation prepared by the Federal Government both methods were discussed. The conclusion was that while the full integration method was the only ideal approach to corporate taxation, there were practical difficulties in implementing it. The imputation system would provide an appropriate basis for extension to a full integration system when the practical difficulties were eventually adequately resolved.

The integration method as now applied to gold mining has the advantage that undistributed company profits are not taxed in the first instance. Such profits are invariably applied towards further development and investment, and more funds are therefore available from internal company resources for these vital purposes. Encouragement of more investment in productive activities is, as we all know, absolutely essential for the future of Australia. The undistributed profits will not go untaxed, because additional dividends and capital gains resulting from reinvestment are taxed in shareholders' hands when received.
The final two paragraphs I wish to quote are these:

The dramatic expansion of the Australian gold mining industry during the 1980's would not have occurred if this positive taxation regime had not applied. Continuation of this regime is essential if gold mining is to make an ongoing and increasing contribution to the Australian economy.

The gold mining industry is not asking to be privileged through not paying tax. It argues that the present system applied to gold mining, which encourages and facilitates re-investment of a part of the profits in the industry, is in Australia's interests. It argues that it is in Australia's interests to extend this system, and therefore the same encouragement of investment to all Australian industries.

That ends the quotation from Sir Arvi Parbo. The truth of the matter is that Australia faces a most difficult future with respect to its export situation. I think we face a most difficult situation with respect to our balance of payments. We maintain a taxation system which is biased against investment in favour of consumption. I think that this measure which is proposed by the Government will further shift the bias of the system in that direction. I do not believe that that is the direction in which we should move.

I remind the Minister for Finance that when he introduced dividend imputation one might, if one had the same approach to politics as he, have engaged in all sorts of mud slinging about the Government's operating with respect to the help it was giving its big business mates. I would remind the Minister that we supported that dividend imputation as a means of reducing the double taxation of earnings, which has been a feature of the Australian company tax system.

The truth of the matter is that the goldmining industry is closer to the ideal that we would seek for Australian industry. It is a pity that we should wish to move in the other direction. I commend the Opposition's amendments to the Senate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —Tonight we are debating three Bills: the Income Tax Rates Amendment Bill, which incorporates various amendments to the Income Tax Assessment Act; the Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 5), which is an annual Bill about taxation rates; and the Sales Tax (Exemptions and Classifications) Amendment Bill (No. 2), which changes various sales tax rates and classifications. This is a cognate debate for those three Bills. There are two Government amendments which I will be moving in the committee stages to two of the Bills. There is an Opposition amendment to the second reading motion, which, of course, the Government will be opposing, and an Opposition amendment to the commencement date of one of the particular changes in the Sales Tax Bill. The Australian Democrats will also wheel up on the Sales Tax Bill a couple of the same amendments that they have wheeled up for every Sales Tax Bill since 1984. Of course, there is the big amendment, which is identified as 492 and is to be moved by the Opposition. The effect of it would be to continue an uneven playing field to the mining industry; that is, to continue the exemption from corporate taxation which the goldmining industry has had since 1924.

SPEECH.PARA: It is worth noting the real reason why that exemption was granted. It is probably one of the many things which Winston Churchill has to answer for. He took England back onto the gold standard in 1924 at the pre-war rate, which meant that sterling was grossly overvalued. Australia, which was pegged to sterling at that time, followed suit. The goldmining industry in Australia was placed in extreme difficulties and the reaction was to exempt goldmining from corporate income tax. It was one of those knee-jerk, foolish reactions which unfortunately has taken 64 years to correct.

In the 14 1/2 years that I have been a member of this place, I cannot remember supporting any piece of legislation with more enthusiasm than I support the ending of the goldmining rort. It has polluted the political process in Australia for as long as I can remember. The workers in the goldmining industry have always paid tax on their wages.

TALK.START.PARA: —Why didn't you take that view in December 1986?
—Is Senator Durack going to declare his shareholding?
—I want you to declare why you--

—It is a disgrace. Since Senator Durack has chosen to interject, I say that I regard it as a travesty of an honest parliamentary system that we have every member of the Opposition opposing this legislation and not one of them has declared his own vested interests-that is, the number of shares that they hold in companies that mine gold. And I challenge them--
—Mr Acting Deputy President, I take a point of order. If the Minister will sit down, I will be very happy to declare mine now-at nil.

—Thank you, Senator Stone. Of course, I have always regarded Senator Stone as being fundamentally an honourable man. I do not expect Senator Crichton-Browne, for example, to follow Senator Stone's example and declare how many shares he has in goldmining companies. I do not expect Senator Crichton-Browne to follow Senator Stone's honourable example.
—We have one precedent now. Why can't they all do it.
—Exactly-why cannot they all do it?
—Mr Acting Deputy President, I take a point of order. I think the process that the Minister is going through is quite unparliamentary. I ask that you call him to order.
—The Minister will get back to the second reading debate.
—I certainly will, Mr Acting Deputy President.
—Tell us why you took that different view in December 1986?

—I am about to come to that. I ask Senator Durack just to show the same patience that he showed while he allowed that file to stay in the bottom drawer gathering dust for five years. The workers who work in the goldmining industry have always paid tax on their wages-as they should do. But those who have held shares in goldmining companies have-for 64 years-not paid corporate taxation. Of course, in the main they are not people who actually work-people who actually get calluses on their hands and dust on their faces. They lounge around principally in Perth but also in other cities and have never had a callous on their hands in their lives.
—You don't like people to invest in anything. Is that what you are saying?
—Get out of the gutter.
—Order! There are too many interjections on my left.
—Would the honourable senator like to declare his shareholdings?
—You are a complete and utter clown!
—Order, Senator Boswell! There are too many interjections on my left.
—As I was saying, Ronnie--
—Mr Acting Deputy President, I take a point of order. I heard the remarks made by Senator Walsh. I was one of those who spoke against the gold tax.
—Do you have a point of order, Senator Parer?
—My point of order is that I have no gold shares.
—That is not a point of order.

—Mr Acting Deputy President, may I say that I have also always regarded Senator Parer as a decent and honourable man. He has come in and declared that he has no goldmining shares. I have no problems with that at all; I absolutely believe him. I have absolutely no reason to doubt his integrity. I just mention that apparently Senator Panizza is nominating himself as not having any goldmining shares either. That leaves, if I remember correctly, 33--
—Thirty-two.
—Thirty-two members of the Opposition have not declared themselves.
—Oh, aren't you smart. Go back into the gutter.
—Well, Senator Knowles can tell us how many goldmining shares she has.
—None.
—Oh well, that leaves 31.
—Order! Senator Walsh will address his remarks to the Chair and not to his opponents in this chamber.
—I apologise, Mr Acting Deputy President. Senator Boswell was interjecting--
—I do not have to tell him anything.
—Order! If Senator Knowles persists in interjecting, I will turn my attention to her.

—Mr Acting Deputy President, Senator Boswell was interjecting a while ago in a very disorderly fashion. I just repeat to him what I said to him earlier today: the last time I saw a mouth that big it had a brown paper bag stuffed in it.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Stone made quite a worthy contribution to the debate. He presented a mostly rational argument. In particular, he elaborated on matters about which he has a good deal of technical expertise. He spoke about international taxing arrangements under which, he conceded, United States equity holders in Australian goldmining ventures effectively pay the tax in Washington that they do not pay in Australia. It was very hard to tell which side of the debate he was on. In the end he had to put up an elaborate but very unconvincing rationalisation for a fundamentally indefensible position-that is, that he was going to stick with the Opposition on this issue. Senator Maguire suggested that Senator Stone believed that Australia should be running a foreign aid program for the United States. With all due respect to Senator Maguire, I do not believe that is correct. I think Senator Stone knows very well that, even though the Reagan Administration has done enormous damage to the United States economy, the United States has not reached the stage of being a Third World country and therefore a worthy recipient of Australian foreign aid.

Senator Stone also dealt with-and I probably received some of the letters that he has-those people who have argued essentially that there should be no corporate taxation in Australia at all. This is an argument which I believe is not entirely without merit, among other reasons because of the extent to which corporate taxes are passed on to consumers. Most of the serious work that I have read on this subject suggests that probably two-thirds of corporate taxation is passed on to consumers. I make this point because it is of some importance. That sort of conclusion is substantially valid if we are dealing with a manufacturing company or a company engaged in retail trade. It is, however, quite different for those companies which are producing products the price of which is determined by export parity, which by and large are in extractive industries. They are price takers. The prices that are received are set by forces outside Australia. Gold is clearly an extractive industry. Whatever the case may be for abolishing corporate taxation across the board for non-extractive industries or industries which do not have their prices determined by external forces, there is no case for having no taxation at all for companies engaged in the production of commodities, particularly in extractive industries, when the prices for their products are set by external forces.

I remind Senator Boswell that this is a fact which is obviously recognised by the Queensland Government. I recall that in, I believe, 1986 at the Northern Australian Development Forum one of Senator Boswell's friends, Mr Katter Jr, delivered a passionate tirade about the stupidity of taxing income derived from goldmining. He said that there were dozens of projects throughout Queensland involving the investment of billions of dollars and that the only thing that was holding them up was the fear that the stupid socialist Government in Canberra would impose a tax on gold. I spoke immediately after Mr Katter. I said I was very interested in his remarks. If it was such a stupid idea to impose a tax on goldmining, I wondered why the Queensland Government was doing it-which it was, which it always has done and which it continues to do.

TALK.START.PARA: —Do you really want your legislation tonight? You are not behaving as though you do.
—I have had put to me the spurious argument, which has been repeated by some of the speakers in this debate, that with the imputation system the exemption of goldmining from--
—You had better control him, Whip. Don't look so insignificant. You can do it if you try.

—Mr Acting Deputy President, I suggest that Senator Walters is in contempt of the Senate. She has threatened that if I reply to the spurious and specious arguments that have been raised by the Opposition in this debate then the Opposition will not allow legislation to be passed.
—Oh no. You are one of the greatest experts on making threats there has been.
—We can sit here on Christmas Eve or Christmas Day.
—Expedite legislation.

—Senator Chaney suggests expediting legislation when we had 30-odd speakers, almost all of them from the Opposition, on the Appropriation Bills and 17 on this package of Bills. With the exception of a very good two-minute contribution from Senator McKiernan and my summary, all the speakers have been from the Opposition.

SPEECH.PARA: The spurious argument has been put to me in correspondence and again tonight that, with the imputation system in operation, the fact that goldmining companies are exempt from corporate taxation really does not matter. This was put by Mr Tuckey on 9 November on an Australian Broadcasting Corporation program in Canberra in response to a question about `goldmining being a tax avoiding industry'. He said:

I mean the other factor that of course has arisen which keeps getting ignored is that the circumstances for the gold industry have changed substantially with imputation. I mean the reality of imputation is that tax on company profits is now only paid once. It is either paid by the company and the credit is passed on to the dividend earner or it is paid by the person receiving the dividend if the company is unable to give evidence to the Tax Commissioner.

Of course, the same line has been run by a gaggle of spivs and bludgers who wrote to me about this, putting the same argument. That shows that they are stupid as well. They are particularly stupid if they think that I would fall for such a phoney argument. Of course, the first and obvious response to that argument is, if what they are saying is true, that the tax is paid anyway, why are they squealing? They are squealing because they believe, probably correctly, that they can take the retained profits as a capital gain through selling their shares and thereby get a concessional rate of tax. They also believe that the Opposition, should it be elected to government, would let them off paying any capital gains tax provided that they hold the shares for five years. Of course, it is declared Opposition policy to let them off in that way; the people who are punting on that are correct about that leg of the proposition. What they are not correct about is the assumption that the Opposition will be in government to implement its policy.

The greed of these people who hold shares in goldmining companies that employ people who have always paid tax on their wages is not surprising. But I do find it an affront that they also indulge in what is really economic treachery, for the reasons that Senator Stone set out-that is, that foreigners who own equity in Australian goldmining companies pay overseas, particularly in the United States, the tax that they are exempted from paying in Australia. As much as $70m a year in taxation is being paid overwhelmingly in Washington rather than in Australia because this absurd taxation law has persisted for 64 years.

TALK.START.PARA: —Absolute nonsense. More is being reinvested than is taken out.

—I am very glad that Senator Messner has raised the question of investment because about 36 per cent of the equity in Australian goldmining enterprises is held by foreigners. Those foreigners have put their money into these projects, knowing that they will pay corporate tax on the profits, except that they pay it in their own countries instead of in Australia. They have put their money in in the past and they will continue to do so in the future, provided the price of gold is attractive enough.
—What about the joint ventures?

—Joint ventures are precisely what I am talking about. The major equity in the Telfer joint venture is, I think, held by an American mining company which puts up its money, pays its tax in Washington but pays nothing in Australia. The argument can be developed that we should have gone to the United States and said, `What about renegotiating the double taxation agreement?' The first problem with that is that it would take about two years at the very least just to get through the negotiating process. More importantly, what would happen if we were to go to the United States and say, `Look, we have this crazy taxation system in Australia which taxes corporate income derived from everything other than gold and we want you to fix it up for us by agreeing to a very much larger dividend withholding tax on profits repatriated to the United States companies which have equity'? Do those opposite know what I would do if I were an American? I would say, `Clear out, do not come pulling my leg. Do not ask me to bend over backwards to fix up Australia's idiotic taxation laws'. That is what the Americans would say. They might say it a bit more politely, but essentially that is what they would say.

SPEECH.PARA: The truth about investment is, of course, that there has been no major goldmining project in Australia for many years which has not factored into its economic viability assessment corporate tax at a 49c rate, not the 39c rate the companies now face. I am very glad that Senator Chaney mentioned Western Mining Corporation, because I had a conversation with Hugh Morgan in 1985 about the subject of tax exemption of the goldmining industry. Hugh Morgan said, `We realise that there will be a tax on goldmining profits and, of course, there has to be a tax on goldmining profits'. I know that Western Mining is singing a different tune now, but that is what Hugh Morgan said in 1985 and that is what every rational goldminer in Australia has known and factored into its economic viability assessments for at least the last 10 years.

TALK.START.PARA: —They did it for Roxby Downs.
—As Senator Maguire says, they did it for Roxby Downs, which of course involved Western Mining very heavily as one of the joint venturers.

It knows it will be defeated because the Australian Democrats have indicated they are going to vote with the Government. This raises the question of what the Opposition does in the unlikely event of its being elected to government. I cannot get an answer from Mr Howard or Dr Hewson or Mr Peacock or anybody about that. The ultimate piece of political chicanery is that they will wheel up a piece of legislation saying--
