SPEECH.PARA: Finally, I support this part of the Bills with particular enthusiasm. This is an issue which has polluted the Australian political processes for as long as I can remember and probably before I was born. Once this legislation is passed, as I understand it will be, those people who are involved in managing goldmining companies should devote their talents and energies to mining gold and stop playing negative sum games; that is, wasting effort and resources on lobbying or blackmailing politicians to get a free ride on the taxpayers' back, especially on the backs of the people who work for them, who actually mine the gold, who have always paid tax on their wages and salaries.
Question put:
That the amendment (Senator Messner's) be agreed to.

DIVISION.RESULT.PARA: Question so resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.PARA: Original question, as amended, resolved in the affirmative.
Bills read a second time.

PROCTEXT.PARA: TAXATION LAWS AMENDMENT BILL (No. 5) 1988
Clause 1 agreed to.
Clause 2 (Commencement).

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: Page 1, clause 2, lines 7 to 9, leave out the clause, insert the following clause:
Commencement
``2. (1) Subject to this section, this Act commences on the day on which it receives the Royal Assent.
``(2) Division 6 of Part III commences, or shall be taken to have commenced, as the case requires, on 1 January 1989.''.

It had been assumed that the Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 5) 1988 would be proclaimed by 1 January. It is now possible that the Bill will not be proclaimed by 1 January. Should that occur, under the imputation arrangements and because of the difference in the 39c and 49c tax rates applying, companies could gain an unintended advantage from the fact that the Bill may not be proclaimed on 1 January. That is the essentiality of the amendment.

The date of effect for these provisions will be 1 January 1989 rather than the date on which the amending Act receives royal assent. That is the critical clause. The amendment is necessary because there is now no certainty that the Bill containing the transitional provisions will receive royal assent prior to 1 January 1989. The transitional imputation provisions will prevent franked dividends paid by early balancing companies with imputation credits that are calculated on the basis of the 39 per cent company tax rate from being channelled through later balancing companies to be subsequently credited at the 49 per cent company tax rate.

This amendment will ensure that franked dividends paid by early balancing companies during the period between 1 January 1989 and the day on which the amending Act receives royal assent will be subject to the same requirements as those paid on and after the day of royal assent. This amendment will prevent any revenue loss that might arise if royal assent does not occur before 1 January 1989. It will also, of course, ensure equality of treatment for companies within the financial year regardless of the date upon which they are paid.
Amendment agreed to.
Clause, as amended, agreed to.
Clauses 3 to 8-by leave-taken together, and agreed to.
Clause 9 (Exemptions).

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Messner Sen The Hon A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (1) Page 3, paragraphs 9 (b) and (c), lines 26 to 29, leave out the paragraphs.

In effect, this amendment is in opposition to subclauses 9 (b) and 9 (c) of the Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 5). The amendment of these two subclauses reflects the opposition which the Liberal and National parties will be expressing, in voting against clause 9, to the gold tax which we have been discussing during the second reading debate. Votes will be taken on other clauses a little later as they are considered in the committee stage. This amendment is merely the commencement of that exercise as these two subclauses are mentioned very early in the amending Bill.

We canvassed at great length during the second reading debate the arguments against the introduction of a gold tax in Australia. As the Minister for Finance (Senator Walsh) pointed out during the second reading debate, the goldmining industry has been exempted from paying corporate tax for many years. Taxation is paid by shareholders on dividends that they receive from companies that mine gold. A capital gains tax is payable in respect of any profits that are earned from buying and selling shares in goldmining companies. In fact, that contributes very significantly to the coffers of the Commonwealth by virtue of those taxes alone. There are, of course, other State taxes, other royalties and so on, payable to State governments. Most States are in some way touched by this proposal, but it is particularly Western Australia which has such a heavy investment in goldmining that is mostly concerned about the non-exemption of the goldmining industry that will apply from now on if this Bill is accepted by the Parliament.

Our reasons for opposing this tax, in summary form, are very simply expressed. Firstly, we believe that the industry is in a very strong growth phase which is of significant benefit to Australia. In the last four or five years the total operating revenue of the goldmining industry has quadrupled from around $600m a year to around $2,500m a year. Also there has been a very significant change in the export of gold, which has quadrupled. The sale of gold on the overseas markets has helped us significantly with the balance of payments problem we have at present. Without that we would be perhaps in a greater pickle than we are at the moment with a huge overseas debt of some $120,000m.

The gold industry is a vital industry. It is growing fast. As I said, its revenue has quadrupled in the last four or five years. Employment in the industry has skyrocketed from about 2,000 in 1984 to about 7,500 in the current year, so it is a significant employer of Australians, all over the continent. This development is not only occurring in the big towns and cities; it is occurring in the outback and in the remoter parts of Australia. This development is generating future growth and opportunities for Australia. Those are the significant economic facts of life.

There is a significant improvement in our balance of payments being brought about by this development. This is no more clearly demonstrated than by considering the following statistic which shows what is happening with this industry. We have all been used to the fact that industries such as wheat, wool, coal and iron ore have been significant contributors to the export income of this country over many years. They have been the backbone of the development of our export industries. Going back some four or five years, gold featured on the list of Australian exports in about tenth position. Today it has reached No. 3 on the list of this country's exports. In fact, it runs just behind coal and wool. It has become our third biggest export. It is a vitally significant industry at a time when there is a demand for the product, when there is a capacity to produce in this country and when investment is flowing into it. And now we find that the Government wants to chop it off at the knees by imposing a higher tax regime on it. It plainly does not make economic sense.

That has not just been demonstrated by arguments put by members of the Liberal and National parties during the debate over the last day or so, but has also been brought to the Government's attention through various studies that have been undertaken by significant consultants such as Ernst and Whinney and J. B. Were and Son. Those studies have demonstrated that the Government will lose taxation revenue as a result of the introduction of a gold tax. It will happen because the gold industry, if taxed, will stop growing in this country. It will not employ people at the rate that it has been employing them over the last several years. It will not grow in terms of overall revenue. It will not, therefore, be generating and multiplying its way through the economy to create jobs in other industries. We will not see growth in export income as a result. We will not see a contribution to our balance of payments problems as a result. We are facing today no greater crisis than our balance of payments, yet this stupid Hawke-Keating Government wants to chop off the industry at the knees to try to bring some kind of abstract taxation theory into force. It is just plain nonsense. It defeats all commonsense-all plain thinking-and consequently it does not deserve the Committee's support.

We will be opposing all clauses in the Bill that seek to institute the goldmining tax. We believe that it is wrong in principle and in practice. The Government has not put forward, either in the second reading speech or at any time in the course of the argument of the last two days, any debating point of significance in support of the tax. Not one argument has been advanced. All arguments that have been put forward by the Minister-he is the only one from the other side who has spoken-have been in rebuttal of arguments put forward by this side. No point in positive support of this tax has emanated from the Government side.

TALK.START.PARA: —Goldmining shares went up 18 points today.

—Well, that is a great thing. What that means is that the Government will have further capital gains tax flowing into the coffers. That supports my point. That demonstrates growth in this industry. It means more investment, more jobs, more production and a better balance of payments result. That is precisely what we ought to be encouraging. Senator Maguire wants to stop it. That is his whole approach to life.

SPEECH.PARA: Some 19 honourable senators have spoken to the Bill dealing with the gold tax. I can inform honourable senators of the breakdown: 16 Liberal and National Party senators have spoken; two members of the Australian Democrats have spoken; and only one senator would stand up on behalf of the Government to defend this nonsense. One senator from the Government side has been prepared to support it, out of 19 speakers. Where are the Western Australian senators from the Labor side? Why are they not pouring through the doors to speak to the Bill? We have not seen them. Where are those honourable senators who are interested in pure economics? We have not even seen Senator Maguire on his feet on this issue. As Senator Puplick said the other day, Senator Maguire is the kind of person who would come in and defend the Massacre of the Innocents: but he did not defend the gold tax, nor would he, because he knows that it is economic stupidity. He will admit that. He had to do a deal with Mr Bannon, the South Australian Premier, to get the Roxby Downs operation under way. We know what that was all about. He went cold on the idea until 1991. Now he has to pay the piper and give him a gold tax. That is what it is all about. There has been a deal about Roxby Downs and other operations throughout Australia for the last several years. Let us not have any hypocrisy from Senator Maguire about that.

The point about all this is quite simple. The economic rationale for this tax does not stand up. No Government senator, bar the Minister, will stand up and defend the issue. He has not put forward one positive reason at all for the tax. In the House of Representatives Mr Keating was not able to advance one reason whatsoever for the tax. If one looks at the statement he brought down last May when he introduced the tax, one sees that there was no argument in support of it. It is purely a figment of some Government person's mentality and, quite clearly, it deserves to be defeated. We, in the Liberal and National parties, will be vigorously opposing all clauses relating to the gold tax. We invite the Democrats to join with us so that we can defeat this Bill, get rid of this nonsense, and get on with governing Australia properly.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Parer Sen W.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to support the remarks made by Senator Messner. I will not go over all the points raised by him, but there are a few matters I would like to raise at some time in the committee stage to which I would like Senator Walsh to reply. They are an overview of what this gold tax is all about. The first question is: why bring in legislation for a tax now which will be applicable in 1991? The effect of that action is no different from Senator Walsh telling financial institutions what the exchange rate will be, or what the interest rate will be, in 1991. Senator Maguire kept interjecting before about the gold tax going up 18 points today.
—The stock market. The goldmining shares went up 18 points today.

—The net result of flagging a tax that is not going to apply between now and 1991 is that the miners who can will high grade. It is no good criticising them for this, but it is simply because the Government is flagging now something that will happen in 1991. I can see Senator Maguire nodding because I think he knows this will happen. This high grading means that those people who purchased and owned shares before September 1985-I think that is when capital gains tax came in-will be holding onto those shares because of the high grading process. This means, simply on the demand and supply for shares, that there are fewer shares on the market than there normally would be because of this legislation. That is the distortion it causes and I wonder, when Senator Walsh replies, whether he will give me the reasons as to why at this stage the Government would do a silly thing like this.

SPEECH.PARA: The other comment I wish to make is that Senator Walsh, in his speech on the second reading, referred to the fact that he did not have any objection in principle to a tax system which encouraged savings investment rather than consumption. I think a lot of people would agree with him on that. But he made some differentiation between goldminers, whom he called price takers--

TALK.START.PARA: —I did not say that in this debate.

—The Minister did say that. He made the point that goldminers were price takers and not price makers. One can understand this tax system applying to price makers rather than price takers. I had great difficulty coming to grips with that because, in the absence of a monopoly, I would imagine that all producers of whatever is being produced are price takers and not price makers.

SPEECH.PARA: The other comment I wished to make was this: Senator Walsh has mentioned, on a number of occasions, the concern he has, and one of the major reasons for the introduction of this gold tax is that moneys end up in foreign treasuries, for example, in the United States instead of the Australian Treasury. I think this is a retrograde step and we will find out in a year or two just how retrograde it is in regard to future mines, not existing mines that might continue until costs exceed revenue. What I could not understand with any degree of wit was why the Government could not have just introduced a simple amendment, if that is what the problem was. A simple amendment would have meant that dividends paid overseas to foreign companies which are not taxable here would attract a withholding tax equal to the tax they would pay if dividends were distributed in Australia, bearing in mind that we do have an offset. We have Australians who invest in the United States who do not pay the full tax, because in the United States there are two very hefty taxes; one is a Federal tax and the other is State taxes. By having investments in the United States they avoid paying the State taxes. Therefore, when the money comes back here, presumably they get the benefit that would also flow from the other direction.

They are the major points I wished to raise. As I said in my opening remarks, I would not go over the ground covered both in the second reading speech and in the comments made by Senator Messner. I think they are very important points to which I would like to hear the answers.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —Of course, the amendment which Senator Messner has just moved, as he made very clear, seeks to perpetuate the unlevel playing field-that is, the exemption from corporate taxation of one industry alone. Of course, the Government will not accept the amendment.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Parer asked a couple of questions which deserve an answer and they will get one. He asked why the commencement date is 1991. I thought I had covered that in my second reading reply. Senator Parer might not have been here when I made those comments. The Prime Minister (Mr Hawke), as did the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Howard) in almost identical terms, gave an undertaking that there would be no tax on corporate profits derived from goldmining during the life of this Parliament. That is the reason for the 1991 commencement date. I think it is a fair argument if the honourable senator wants to be critical about the date being 1991. In fact, I would probably agree with him. But I have made the point that this issue has polluted the Australian political process for 64 years and that is just one of the products of that pollution.

In regard to the taxation of up to $70m being paid in Washington instead of Australia, Senator Parer asked what superficially seems to be a very reasonable question; that is, why do we not just have a withholding tax on dividends repatriated from the United States equal to the Australian corporate tax rate? I also dealt with this matter in my second reading reply. That would require a change to the double taxation agreement with the US and, therefore, a renegotiation of that agreement which, under any circumstances, would take a considerable amount of time but to which in this case, I suggest, the US would be unlikely to agree. Why should the United States bend over backwards to put an extraordinary sort of clause into a double taxation agreement in order to compensate for the distortions caused by a tax law in Australia? I would be extremely surprised if there were the same sort of tax law for any industry in the United States.

Senator Panizza held up his hand when I was speaking in the second reading debate and I misunderstood what he was signifying. I thought when he held up his hand he was signifying that he did not have shares in goldmining companies. He has since told me privately that he was signifying that he does have shares in goldmining companies. I pass no moral judgment about that but I misunderstood his signal and I want to set the record straight.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to ask the Minister for Resources (Senator Cook), who is now in the chamber, a couple of simple questions. Can he tell me exactly the difference to revenue by the end of next year if the gold tax had been introduced on 1 July, allowing for a foreign dividend withholding tax of 15 per cent if I am correct, which, would apply under the double taxation agreement between Australia and the United States that Senator Walsh just mentioned? Can the Minister guess the amount that Australian goldmining companies lost between, I believe, 1938 and 1974-I am sure about 1974 but not quite so sure about 1938-as a result of the price of gold being fixed?
—It was 1972.
—No, it was taken off in 1974. However, the price of gold was fixed over that period. As a result, companies had to forgo a vast amount of money that they could have secured on the world market.
—Senator Panizza asked me to give him a figure of what goldmining companies may have lost by having the price of gold fixed.
—That was the last question.

—Senator Panizza will have to tell me what the earlier questions were because I was taking over from Senator Walsh and I did not hear them. If he can repeat them, I will do my best to answer them. However, I do not know the answer to the last question.
—You are a good Minister, Cookie.

—That is the factual case. Does Senator Walters know the answer to that question? I do not think anyone knows the answer to that question. It depends on a number of variables which would take a considerable computation to actually calculate and which one could not make any serious judgment about. One would only be guessing. I am not quite sure what relevance that question has to the measure that is before the chamber. If Senator Panizza wants to talk about profits of goldmining companies-if that is the purpose of his question-let me say that that last time I looked at the figures, which was two weeks ago now, gold was selling on the London Metals Exchange for about $A520. We know from departmental research that the cost on average of producing an ounce of gold in Australia was $300. We are looking at a cool $250-odd profit for each ounce of gold produced in Australia on average. By any stretch of the imagination, that is not a bad cop.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Panizza Sen J.H.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will repeat those questions that the Minister for Resources (Senator Cook) did not hear. Can the Minister give me an approximation of the extra collections if corporate tax on gold came in on, say, 1 July, allowing for the fact that tax is already collected on unfranked dividends in Australia and that all dividends on goldmining companies are untaxed because they do not pay corporate tax? Allowing for that, and also allowing for the two-way agreement with foreign dividends which we have between Australia and the United States and between Australia and other countries-there is a 15 per cent withholding tax, contrary to what Senator Walsh said; they are not completely free-can the Minister give me such an approximation? To change a system that has lasted since 1924 is a big turnaround and a big disincentive to further exploration. That has already been shown in the downturn in exploration in Kalgoorlie, as the Minister knows. Exploration is about 20 per cent lower than it was this time last year. All of those things are affected, and I would like to know the figure. That is the end of those questions.

SPEECH.PARA: By way of explanation, the reason I asked whether the Minister knew how much goldmining companies lost between 1938 and 1974 was to show that they need this preferential treatment that they have been getting since gold has not been taxed because they have had preferential punishment between 1938 and 1984. Can the Minister tell me of any other export products whose prices were fixed between 1938 and 1974?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Parer Sen W.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —It might help if I follow on from Senator Panizza's questions and then the Minister can answer both at once.
—I am quite happy to take the questions in their entirety or one at a time, whichever way honourable senators wish to deal them up. I am quite relaxed.

—I will just follow on from my colleague Senator Panizza. Under the gold tax system as it now exists, there is a great incentive for equity rather than debt. I notice with interest that Senator Haines is here; this is something that she feels strongly about. I wonder whether any calculations have been done. If so, what are the results of those calculations to show just what the change in tax will be? My reason for asking this and showing my hand is that I have seen calculations. If I have seen them, I hope the Government has done calculations to get the same sorts of results, because once this system comes in-bearing in mind that between now and 1991 we are going to get a massive high grading where possible, and bearing in mind that under the current system where tax is payable in the hands of the shareholders, because they are unfranked dividends, and for shares bought after September 1985 there is a capital gains tax on shares sold-there is going to be a tremendous move to go from equity into debt. I hope the Government has done its homework on this.

SPEECH.PARA: If we went from zero debt, which would be the norm today in most companies, because there has been no reason for them to have deductions, to, say, 60 per cent debt, and then add to that all the other deductions for depreciation and so on, what would be the net effect in revenue to the Government by moving to this system? I believe that the chance is that over a period there will be a negative return to the Government.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —It seems that I can go back on the interchange bench because the main player, the Minister for Finance (Senator Walsh), is due to come back on the field. However, before I move to the interchange bench--
—You were always nineteenth man.

—I do not mind being the nineteenth man. We are in government and as long was we are, I am happy to be the nineteenth man, and I guess that is for a long time yet. Senator Panizza and I sometimes share the same seat on that long flight back to Perth.
—The same seat?

—The same bench. I am constantly amazed that some of Senator Panizza's colleagues mispronounce his name. I have always correctly pronounced his name with a definite `z'-and indeed acknowledged that one of his cousins or nephews was one of the all-time great South Australian league footballers, a top ruckman for South Adelaide. It has irritated me for some time that his colleagues mispronounce his name, and I just thought I would set that straight.
—What about South Adelaide?
—It was a good team. It won the Grand Final in 1960, but it has not done well since.
—It won in 1964, that is right.
—You cannot even get the funny bits right.
—It is not a funny bit; it is a factual bit.
—Right. You cannot even get the factual bits right.
—I stood correcting.
—Could you return to the Bill, Senator Cook?
—I think I could return to the point. This is very diverting. I just wanted to sort out a minor matter of pronunciation.
—Get back to the point in issue.

—I have already been pulled into line by the Temporary Chairman. I cannot engage in badinage across the chamber any more. I must direct my attention to the question. We calculate that the yield from extending normal company tax to the goldmining industry, closing off the gold loophole, will be about $300m per annum. Senator Panizza's question was: if we were then to deduct what might be obtained by tax imputation being reduced as a consequence, the balance would be. I cannot give him that figure. I would again be entering into the realms of speculation if I were to do so, and he might quite rightly upbraid me for venturing thus.

SPEECH.PARA: Let me say though, in respect of the allegations that he-or was it Senator Parer?-made about high grading, and in Senator Parer's case, the question on exploration, that the Commonwealth may well have made a grievous miscalculation and be dudding our revenue by introducing this measure. That was the import of the question. We do not believe that will be so. If the honourable senator is right, then his arguments about it being a brake on incentive and a brake on development would be wrong. If he is right, then the goldmining industry in Australia is going to have an enhanced incentive to further develop, and all the foredoomings and forebodings made in contributions to the second reading debate would be right past the point and would be providing an incentive to the industry. This is a logical extension from the premises inherent in the questions of Senator Parer. The honourable senator may find it uncomfortable, but that is a logical extension. Therefore, perhaps it is not in his best interests to pursue the argument. That is all I am saying.

Nonetheless, the point is that I do not think we are dudding our base. Even if we were to accept the Opposition's view that in the short term we were, in the long term, by giving equal treatment to the mining and sale of this metal that is enjoyed by the miners and sellers of all other metals, we would at least be establishing the equity considerations that are inherent in our position.

I make one other observation. If Senator Panizza's forecasts are true about high grading, then I am sure that he will use his influence in the conservative coalition to address that concern to the governments of the Northern Territory, Queensland, New South Wales and Tasmania. We have to exempt South Australia from this, because that is the only other State in which there is an explicit gold tax. Those States apply a production or a profits based tax. If members of the Opposition are concerned about a gold tax, then their fire should be directed to those who apply it and not to the Commonwealth, which extends company tax to the gold industry.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Durack Sen The Hon P.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —I was following the answer given by Senator Cook. As Senator Walsh is now here, maybe he will address his mind to the question. Senator Cook was asked by one of my colleagues about the actual net amount that the Government expected to recover from the imposition of this tax. Senator Cook's answer was $300m per annum.
—Gross.
—That is very interesting-$300m gross.
—No, it is a net figure.

—Senator Cook has given the answer that it was $300m gross. I would not be surprised if that was wrong. Senator Cook did not seem to know much about the subject. The fact is that is the figure that has been given to the Committee. I am asking the Minister for Finance (Senator Walsh), who is hopefully better at arithmetic, what the net figure is. I do not know whether Senator Walsh was listening, but Senator Cook seemed to have a very simplistic way of estimating the profits from the gold tax. He said, `Well, gold now is selling for $A500 and something and the cost of producing it is $300 and something, so one can see what a great profit there is'. He does not seem to have regard to the fact that in the first place under this legislation companies will be able to carry forward from the date of the May statement this year the various deductions that would be available to them. They will be carrying forward from May 1988 to January 1991-a period of 2 1/2 years-a very solid amount of deductions. I would like to know, firstly, when those deductions work themselves out because clearly there will no profit at all in the 1990-91 tax year. When will the Government expect to start recovering any sort of gain from this tax? Secondly, has the Government made estimates of what will be, on a continuing basis, the various deductions that will be available annually, such as interest payments, depreciation payments and exploration costs, all of which will be deductable once a tax has been imposed? Thirdly, I ask the Minister: What will be the set-off against whatever the net result of that is from the loss of tax on dividends? As companies will be paying franked dividends, presumably in most cases, there will be a loss of tax on dividends and there will also be a loss on capital gains.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Messner has indicated that some calculations have been made on this score by Ernst and Whinney and J. B. Were and Son. Whatever the Minister thinks of their calculations, the reality is that there will be a considerable loss in capital gains tax because of the depressed value of the market capitalisation of gold shares. Has the Government taken all these matters into consideration in its calculation of the gain, whether it be net or gross? Senator Cook has departed the chamber. He talked about gross gains. I think he probably did not understand what he was talking about. Has the Government taken into account all the matters that I have indicated? If it has, what is its figure of long term profit from this tax? When will that profit start to come on stream?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Parer Sen W.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to correct one point made by Senator Cook. He said that if he extrapolated my view through to there being a lower return to the Government this would be to the benefit of the companies. What he did not understand, and what apparently the Government does not understand, is that I am talking about new developments, not existing projects which, as I said earlier, will go on until costs exceed revenue. One of the pluses of the existing gold tax as it applies before this legislation comes into place is that the system of forward selling used by the gold industry has been such that in the early stages of a project it has been able to finance the first three to five years of the project. After that it can be off and running, and, I point out to Senator Haines, without going into debt, interestingly enough. This legislation will do away with that.

SPEECH.PARA: To follow up what Senator Durack said, and also to get clarification on the response from Senator Cook, the remark was made that the Government expected the net revenue to be in the order of $300m a year. Has that figure been arrived at on the assumption that the structure of the goldmining companies is unchanged; in other words, that equity will remain almost 100 per cent of the source of funding? If the companies go into 60 or 70 per cent debt, what figure would that be? As Senator Durack has mentioned, to that we must add deductions for depreciation and exploration and all the other deductions that apply under the normal company tax system.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —There are two concepts of gross and net here. The first one, which is the one Senator Cook was addressing, is that of corporate tax revenue after making allowance for the carry forward of exploration expenditure prior to calendar year 1991 and for some undeducted other investments. That has been taken into account in the estimate of $300m in a full year. The estimate for the first financial year, which is only half a financial year in reality, is $70m. Because of those carry forwards it will take some time for it to build up to the full figure. The fact that those carry forwards are there and that undeducted other investment which would under general taxation rules have been deductable from taxable income would also be taken into account is, as I acknowledged a while ago, a distortion-and perhaps an unfortunate distortion. But the nettle had to be grasped on this issue at some time or other. It should have been grasped many years ago.

SPEECH.PARA: On the question of the payout of dividends and tax that would have been collected on that, let me say first that that has no relevance to the dividends that are payable overseas. Around 36 per cent of the equity in Australian goldmines is held by foreigners, and overwhelmingly by the United States. No attempt has been made to estimate those dividends and for a variety of reasons they are unlikely to be very great. Under the old regime there was a very strong incentive to retain profits within goldmining companies for an indefinite period and for people from time to time to sell their shares and pick up a capital gain, instead of taking income, which would have been taxed at a concessional rate.

Another important point highly relevant to that is that should the Opposition get into government and implement the policies to which it committed itself some time ago, I do not remember exactly when-that is, to abolish the capital gains tax if an asset has been held for more than five years-of course almost everybody would hold goldmining shares for more than five years and then cash them in, receiving in the price of the shares they sold the accumulated untaxed profits of the company and escaping capital gains tax altogether. So it depends largely on what assumptions one makes about what might happen, but if one were to assume that the Opposition's policy on capital gains taxation was implemented, there would be almost no tax levied on dividends anyway because there would be hardly any dividends taken. Earnings would all be taken as capital gains after a five-year period, untaxed.

The argument is being put forward-and I have not heard anyone explicitly say this, but it is implicit in a number of comments that have been made-that the effect of this measure will actually be to reduce the amount of tax paid to the Commonwealth. If that were true I would repeat the question I asked in reply to the second reading debate: Why are the people who are affected by it complaining about it?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crichton-Browne Sen N.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to make some comments in response to the abusive outburst we heard from the Minister some time ago. For my part, I have just about had enough of Ministers coming into this chamber clearly affected by alcohol and ordinary senators who are trying to do a job have to put up with their drunken abuse.
—Senator Crichton-Browne, you cannot impute motives like that to any Minister. Would you withdraw that statement.

—I rise on a point of order, Mr Temporary Chairman. I wish Senator Crichton-Browne could be affected by an outburst of honesty, like seven of his colleagues were, and declare his shareholdings in goldmining companies.
—Senator Walsh, I have asked Senator Crichton-Browne to withdraw his imputation against you and I ask you to withdraw your imputation against Senator Crichton-Browne.
—Very well, Mr Temporary Chairman.
—I withdraw my remark. While I am on my feet, might I inquire by way of a point of order whether a senator being drunk in the chamber can be considered to be disorderly?
—That is a hypothetical question and is therefore out of order.
—Would you like to go outside?
—Senator Walsh has asked me whether I would like to go outside. Is he challenging me to a run around the lake or is this another drinkathon?
—No, a punch-up.

—Just a punch-up? Senator Walsh would see two of me, and run. Mr Temporary Chairman, the abuse, when it was not being directed at me and my colleagues, was being directed at those who were audacious enough and intrepid enough to disagree with the tax on gold. I will start from the top. I remind the Committee of an exchange that took place in the Western Australian Legislative Assembly. Dr Gallop from the Western Australian Labor Party asked this question of the Premier:

SPEECH.PARA: Can the Premier restate the Government's position on gold tax? Can he say what support he might expect for the Government's stand on this matter?
Mr Dowding stated:

This Government is and has been at all material times opposed to the removal of the tax-exempt status of gold. In order to advance the situation in a constructive way I have asked the Minister for Agriculture to reform the gold policy committee and to ask it to report to the Deputy Premier and myself as soon as practicable on what steps can be taken in the face of the Federal Government's decision.

That was not somebody who, presumably, had a direct interest in a mining tenement, a mining claim or a mining company; that was the Premier of Western Australia. The Premier of Western Australia went on at a later date--

TALK.START.PARA: —The temporary Premier.
—That is right; he is inexorably heading towards disaster. Later the Premier chided the Western Australian Liberal Party for not being more aggressive in its attitude towards tax. He went on to say:

SPEECH.PARA: I am disappointed that the Liberal Party was not more supportive of the State Government and the goldmining industry's attack over the last five years on the attempt by the Federal Government to remove the exemption.
The Premier said at another time:
The Federal Government has enough revenue without seeking to raise a further $100 million to $600 million through a gold tax . . .

Federal revenues are up dramatically and I do not think there is a need to increase Federal revenue now . . . The gold industry was already paying a de facto income tax in the form of dividend imputation where shareholders in gold companies paid tax on their dividends.
The Premier is reported in the Daily News of 13 May as saying:
. . . the WA Government maintained its opposition to any form of gold tax.
He said in the Australian Financial Review of 26 May:
I believe it is a clear breach of faith with the WA Government and the community and as far as I am concerned the fight is far from over.

If Senator Walsh wants to call his mates spivs and layabouts who lounge about in Perth that is his judgment upon them; it is certainly not mine. An article on 19 May in the West Australian newspaper states:
The Deputy Premier, Mr Parker, and the Minister for Agriculture, Mr Grill, are in Canberra lobbying against the Federal Government's threat of a gold tax.
The Premier, Mr Dowding, told State Parliament yesterday that both had gone to Canberra because of the WA Government's concern over persistent speculation that a gold tax would be introduced.
The Premier said on 26 May in the State Parliament:
We are appalled at the Federal Government's decision about the gold tax; we are disappointed that the Liberal Party of this State did not give more support . . .
The State Liberal Party in Western Australia has been most aggressive, to say the least, in its attitude in support of its opposition to a tax on gold. If that is not enough for Mr Dowding--

TALK.START.PARA: —What about John Hyde?
—I do not know whether he is a member of the Liberal Party. Mr Dowding went on in the Legislative Assembly to say:

SPEECH.PARA: I have made my position clear on the gold tax exemption. I have been vigorous and condemnatory of the Federal Government-

What did the honourable member for Kalgoorlie, Mr Graeme Campbell, one of Senator Walsh's drinking mates, have to say? Did he support the tax on gold? He crossed the floor. There was nothing altruistic about that. He said: `Either I will lose my seat or I will lose my endorsement. I will take a chance on my endorsement and make sure I retain my seat'. What did Mr Grill, a senior Cabinet Minister and another of Senator Walsh's mates, say? Mr Grill, who is Chairman of the joint State Government gold industry policy committee, said he endorsed Mr Campbell's stand. A newspaper article reports him as saying:
It was a courageous decision that reflected the feelings of the vast majority of the people in his electorate . . .

Mr Campbell is a true representative of the Goldfields people and a staunch supporter of the State Government's anti-gold tax stand. I would have done exactly the same thing had I been in his position.

That was said by one of the senior Ministers in the Western Australian State Government. Yet Senator Walsh talks about spivs and loungeabouts. We heard him some weeks ago talking about a man and claiming that he had been, to use the Minister's vulgar expression, `in the slammer'. And, of course, he had not. But that does not worry Senator Walsh. He sprays names around as it suits him; he could not care less who it touches or condemns. Let us ask ourselves what has happened in a material sense since December 1986, when the Treasurer (Mr Keating) said--

TALK.START.PARA: —I told you that. If you hadn't been having a bottle of whisky in your office, you would have heard it.

—Come on, Senator Walsh! What a pathetic retort! When the argument fails, when the logic fails, what does he do? Get into the abuse or get into the bottle-that is his formula. Let us hear what the Treasurer had to say. He said:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . the importance of encouraging active exploration and development, and of maximising production and the consequent export income generated by the gold mining industry, outweighed the arguments in favour of removing the industry's long-standing tax exemption.

Tell us what has happened to the balance of payments since then. What has happened since the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) said that there would be no tax on gold in the life of this Parliament? What is the difference between the life of this Parliament, the life of the last Parliament, or the life of the next Parliament? It is absolutely nothing. It is politically expedient. This is not an attempt to straighten out a tax distortion; it is simply a tax grab. Let us look at what the enlightened Senator Cook had to say in the Senate. He is another of Senator Walsh's soul mates. He said:
If Australian miners accelerate their development they will run the risk of bringing down the market price by putting more gold on the market.

How do honourable senators like that for an economic argument? Australia produces 6 per cent of the world's gold. Senator Cook suggests that a tax induced reduction in investment which reduces supply will raise the price of gold. Senator Cook is suggesting to us that the Australian tax laws will affect the world price of gold. I find that absolutely remarkable, but no doubt Senator Walsh, when he gets to his feet in due course, will explain the logic of that.

TALK.START.PARA: —No, he won't.

—Perhaps he will not. That is the sort of argument we are getting from the Government. Senator Walsh and Senator Cook will no doubt tell us that the levels of production in Australia are due to distortions in the tax regime. It is perhaps worth looking at what has been happening around the world. Over the last eight years Australian gold production has increased tenfold-that is, 1,000 per cent-from 17 tonnes in 1980 to a projected 189 tonnes in 1989. If we look at the rest of the world we will see that the world supply of mined gold grew by just 13 per cent between 1985 and 1988. That compares with Australia's increase of 1,000 per cent. South Africa has had a decrease of 11 per cent. I accept that South Africa has problems because of the depth of its mines but, with the world prices of gold, its production has decreased by 11 per cent. Canada will increase its production by only 50 per cent and production in the United States will grow by only 33 per cent. Is Senator Walsh going to tell me when he gets to his feet-if that is possible-that the increase in production of gold in Australia is due to the distortion of the tax system? Is it because we have a tax system that induces investment and, therefore, increases production to the level that it has? Of course that is not the case and Senator Walsh knows it.

SPEECH.PARA: This legislation is not about a level playing field; it is about increasing the tax grab. I am sure that Senator Walsh says it himself: one of the fundamental problems with Australia is our poor levels of investment and saving. Whilst there are distortions in consumption-there are problems with the levels of public sector and private sector consumption-anybody looking objectively at the goldmining industry will accept that the tax system has provided and ensured that there has been a significant increase in capital investment, which is what I would have imagined the Government would have encouraged.

I conclude by saying that if Senator Walsh is suggesting that those who oppose him have their own agenda or are being politically expedient, I can only assume that he knows his colleagues better than I do; that he is suggesting that Mr Dowding, the Western Australian Premier, and the Labor Cabinet, support a tax on gold. If they do, I can only assume that they would have no objection to a royalty on gold. If they are half sensible, looking at revenue they would say to themselves, `Once this tax is introduced why should the Federal Government get the benefits of it and not a State government?' So why would they not automatically put a royalty on it? I have no doubt that they will do so. This legislation has no merit, no intrinsic justification and no economic rationale. It is simply a further grab by this Government for increased revenue.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Watson Sen J.O.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —There must have been a statistical calculation to support the claim that $300m per annum will be raised in subsequent years, as page 4 of the explanatory memorandum states. My concern arises from an answer given by Senator Cook when the suggestion was made that that $300m per annum was a gross figure. I ask Senator Walsh to confirm that and to refer to his statistical background support figures to enable us to get an appreciation of the impact that, for example, the payment of franked dividends would have on that calculation. I ask for the financial impact of the change as a result of the payment of franked dividends. How much would that be? I ask for the financial figure of the impact of the effect that capital gains tax would have. I ask what adjustment was made in respect of the changing of the capital base of a company. I ask for the figures that would relate to the carrying forward of exploration and other expenditures peculiar to the running of the mining industry. Perhaps, at the end of the day, the Minister can give us the net figure. That would be appreciated.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Tasmania: Tourism-Australian Film Finance Corporation-Current Account Deficit

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Calvert Sen P.H.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to speak briefly in the adjournment debate tonight on the subject of tourism in Tasmania and the remarkable success which the present Tasmanian Liberal Government has achieved in attracting visitors to the State. I am sure that all honourable senators present who have had the opportunity to visit Tasmania would agree that it is a most attractive holiday destination. It is a destination which has suffered somewhat in the past because people may have felt that it was a little laid back and perhaps not as exciting as some of the mainland destinations. However, this has changed as people now know and appreciate that the beautiful scenery, the idyllic lifestyle, and the warm hospitality which Tasmania offers so generously, can certainly be appreciated in its own right.

SPEECH.PARA: The Tasmanian Government, through a number of highly successful initiatives, has promoted tourism to the point where it has become one of the State's major revenue earners. With the recent retirement of the former Minister for Tourism and Deputy Premier, Mr Geoff Pearsall, the State has lost not only a skilful and well-respected politician, but also a wonderful ambassador. I would like therefore to place on record the appreciation of the people of Tasmania for Geoff Pearsall's untiring efforts.

I wish also, when speaking on tourism in Tasmania, to refer the Senate to the Wrest Point Casino in Hobart which was Australia's first legalised casino. In that regard, Tasmania has led the way. It is a multimillion dollar investment, which has attracted many tourists to the island and with the recent addition of its magnificent convention facilities surely ranks as one of the best of these types of facilities in the world. Honourable senators present would be well aware that it was not so long ago that Wrest Point Casino was chosen twice by the Labor Party as a venue for its national conference. Having spoken to some of its members I know they speak very highly of the facility. Perhaps they might not speak so highly of some of the results of those conferences, but be that as it may, it certainly has proved to be a very wonderful and well-recognised convention facility for Australia.

Unfortunately, it is particularly disappointing when one who is chosen to represent Tasmania chooses to pursue the path of political opportunism by knocking one's own State. There is the tall poppy syndrome in which successful individuals often find that their success is criticised by others who are all too ready to knock them down. Unfortunately, this type of criticism, which has become part of the Australian phenomenon, was recently levelled by Senator Sanders in this place at the Wrest Point Casino. There is no doubt that much of what Senator Sanders had to say was blatantly untrue. I believe that when one understands that Senator Sanders, although he represents the people of Tasmania, has chosen no longer to make that State his home, one perhaps can understand why he may have got out of touch with what is going on in Tasmania.

I particularly wish to refer the Senate to comments made in this place on 3 November, 1988, when Senator Sanders described the Wrest Point Casino as `that giant white phallic symbol on the shoreline'. He went on to say, `It is besmirching the river view of local residents'. As a proud Tasmanian, and one who has noted the promotion of tourism in Tasmania for many years, I would say that to most people, including the promoters of tourism in Tasmania, the casino is certainly not a great white phallic symbol. It is a symbol of tourism.

Every video which promotes Tasmania features it significantly. I believe that what he has said is certainly not the majority view of all Tasmanians and is quite untrue. He also claimed that when one entered the Casino all one saw were the Moonah mums and the women from the working class suburbs of Moonah and Glenorchy, mindlessly pulling away at levers on poker machines. There are no poker machines in the casino, as such, and if there are, they certainly do not have handles on them. It is another example of the honourable senator's ignorance of the facts. He also went on to say that the Wrest Point Casino was disturbing the fabric of the Tasmanian community. I believe that this is also untrue. Senator Sanders's comments have not gone unnoticed.

As I have pointed out previously, they have caused considerable disquiet in Tasmania's tourist industry, which is probably one of Tasmania's major employers. If Senator Sanders has been successful in convincing people that they should not visit Tasmania or the Wrest Point casino, he has really only been successful in costing ordinary Tasmanians their jobs. If that is an achievement of which he is proud, I am particularly disappointed. I believe that all senators in this place should use their time actively to support their own State and to portray their State in a positive and not a negative light.

Senator Sanders's comments have also drawn widespread criticism from professionals in the hospitality industry. I recently received a letter from Mr John Haddad, AM, Managing Director of Federal Pacific Hotels Ltd, who has taken particular exception to Senator Sanders's view of Wrest Point and his inference that Tasmanian casinos were run by organised crime. The letter, from Mr Haddad to Senator Sanders, states:
Dear Sir,

Upon my return recently from overseas I read the report in Hansard which contains the remarks you made in the Senate in the course of the debate on the Australian Capital Territory Casino Control Ordinance 1988.

One expects from ones representatives in Parliament a respect for the truth. This was a quality demonstrably absent from statements made by you on the above occasion and I am bound to record my protest.

It is very regrettable that you chose to describe Wrest Point so contemptuously and inaccurately. The Wrest Point hotel casino and convention centre is one of the best and most favourably known landmarks in the Commonwealth and is featured consistently in tourism literature.
My company added the convention facilities on its own initiative some few years ago at a cost of $20 million because it recognised the need to strengthen the tourism infrastructure of Tasmania.
The Wrest Point complex has made a contribution to the tourist industry of this State and of Australia which is incalculable in dollar terms.

It has attracted international and national conferences of consequence to Tasmania, the State you purport to represent, and my company is proud of its contribution, so much more worthy of note than your disparaging description.

I join issue with you also when you claim, allegedly from your own observations, that what one sees at Wrest Point ``is the Moonah mums, the women from the working class suburbs of Moonah and Glenorchy, just mindlessly pulling away at levers on poker machines. It has disrupted the fabric of the community''.

That statement is patently and demonstrably untrue. There are no poker machines at Wrest Point. There are video gaming machines programmed to play a game strictly in accordance with the rules for the table games approved by the Tasmanian Government. None of them have handles.

Finally, I refer to the most disgraceful statement you made. Asking the rhetorical question ``Does anyone really sincerely think that the present casinos are not run by organised crime'' you went on to claim ``They (people in organised crime) run the casinos in Australia''.
Speaking for my own company which controls two casinos in Australia, I state unequivocally that your claim is without a vestige of truth. It is thoroughly false.

Federal Hotels is proud of the integrity of its directors, of its staff, and of its casino operations. I remind you that the Australian Federal Police conducted a full investigation into my company, as the operators of the casino proposed for Christmas Island, and gave it a complete clearance.
I find it a matter of profound regret that a member of the Australian Parliament should so demean himself and his position as you did on the occasion about which I have written.
Yours faithfully,
John M. Haddad
Managing Director
The Federal Hotels Limited

The letter is self-explanatory. I believe that what has happened is an abuse of parliamentary privilege. In the future when someone who represents Tasmania wishes to criticise aspects of that State, he should think about what he is going to say before he puts his mouth into gear.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Dunn Sen I.P.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to make some brief remarks in relation to comments that were made yesterday by Senator Puplick in this chamber about the newly established Australian Film Finance Corporation (AFFC) and its Chairman, Kim Williams. Senator Puplick was right when he said I was editor of the film industry trade magazine Encore, which I was for two years. Earlier in the year I was in the old Parliament House interviewing Gary Punch on the day when he announced the new scheme for the future of film funding in Australia. The old scheme was clearly not working. It was introduced in 1980-81 by the Fraser Government with a tax concession rate of 150 per cent for investment in film production, with a 50 per cent concession on the returns from films. In subsequent years the Labor Government reduced the film concessions to 133:33 and then to 120:20.

SPEECH.PARA: It was clear that the tax concessions were costing the Government an increasing amount of money. There was an increasing dissatisfaction from within the industry that the right sort of product was not being made, that there were rorts within the industry, that the quality of films was not good, that the films that were being made were not commercial, and that there was a gradual decline in production which accompanied the decline in the tax concession rates. However, one good thing about the tax concession rates, in my opinion, was that at least they provided experience to many people in the Australian film industry, experience that would not otherwise have been gained had the tax concessions not been introduced.

The new scheme which was introduced this year was welcomed by the various industry groups-the Screen Production Association of Australia, the Australian Screen Directors Association, Actors Equity of Australia and the Australian Theatrical and Amusement Employees Association. Kim Williams, who was then chief executive of the Australian Film Commission, played a critical role in promoting open public discussion on the new model for future assistance to the Australian film industry. He conducted numerous seminars around the country with all film bodies, including the State film bodies. He received a multitude of submissions on the new proposal. A paper was produced from within the Australian Film Commission on the future of film funding and it was circulated widely throughout the industry. When comments were returned from industry groups they were incorporated into the new model.

The point I am making is that there was widespread industry agreement on the new model. The industry itself played a leading role-and a very large role-in fashioning the new scheme. It seems that Senator Puplick forgets this. In fact, I find it quite difficult to pinpoint exactly what Senator Puplick is criticising in relation to the new scheme. He conveniently forgets to mention the cost of the tax concessions to the taxpayer and the loss to government revenue of the 10ba scheme which reached about $150m in its most expensive year. I wonder whether he is saying that any government in which he might be the arts Minister would be prepared to support the loss of $100m annually to government revenue for the sake of Australian film culture. I really doubt that.

Of course production went down as the tax incentives decreased. A year ago the future of film production in this country looked very gloomy. There was great concern that there would be widespread unemployment in the industry if something were not done. Certainly, there has been a delay in establishing the new film funding body but I ask Senator Puplick what is new. The Australian Film Finance Corporation is now operational; it is up and running. I believe that what Senator Puplick said yesterday was clutching at straws. He is critical of the new Film Corporation before it has had a chance to prove itself. He picks on one phrase-that is, `30 per cent private sector participation'. I think he deliberately misunderstands it to find a point of criticism. Thirty per cent private sector participation in the new scheme reflects an attempt by the new Film Corporation to involve the private sector in film funding in this country. The new Film Corporation will obviously have a certain amount of flexibility in deciding how much private sector involvement will go into any individual production deal. It must have that sort of flexibility. That is the nature of the film industry. If Senator Puplick is not prepared to acknowledge that that is the nature of the film industry I do not think he knows very much about it.

In the overall allocation of its funding the AFFC must be allowed a certain amount of discretion in deciding the allocation of its funds and the proportion of its funds. Certainly a proportion will go to feature film production, which in recent years has not been as successful as we might have hoped under the tax incentive scheme. It is also very clear that a certain amount will go to television and to children's productions on television, which have been extremely successful.

Senator Puplick also referred to a film that may or may not be funded by the new Australian Film Finance Corporation. It is a film called Till the End of the World and it is going to be made by Wim Wenders, who is an internationally renowned film maker. Senator Puplick on the one hand commends Wim Wenders for his reputation and on the other hand suggests that the Film Corporation is worthy of criticism for investing money in a film to be made by an internationally renowned film maker. I do not understand the reasoning behind this. In any case, the Film Corporation has not yet made any decision on this project, so it seems to me quite early to make any kind of pronouncement on it.

Senator Puplick also complained about the cost of the new Australian Film Finance Corporation office. As I pointed out earlier, he forgot to mention the cost to the taxpayer of the tax concession scheme over the years. By comparison with that, the cost of the office, which would have to fund quite a large staff, pales. He said that the board of the new Australian Film Finance Corporation is `overloaded with people whose responsibilities are considerable and whose qualifications appear to be just as much directed towards their active support, membership or participation in the activities of the Australian Labor Party as those of the film industry'. I believe that is incorrect, and I will give honourable senators some of the details of the board members.

William Gurry is a barrister and solicitor and is Managing Director of the National Mutual Royal Bank Ltd. He has been a director of the merchant bank Hill Samuel Australia and Executive Director of the Australian Bank Ltd. Anthony Hartnell is a corporate lawyer and a member of the legal committee of the Business Council of Australia, a director of various companies and a member of the Commercial Law Association of Australia Ltd. There is also Dr Patricia Edgar, who has proven herself to be a most professional and competent director of the Australian Children's Television Foundation. She has a position on the Victorian Post-Secondary Education Commission and was visiting professor at the Department of Communications at the University of Iowa in the United States of America. Patricia Edgar is very well known for the work she has done for children's television in this country, including the degree to which she has actually made it a commercial proposition. I defy Senator Puplick to talk about the Labor Party's connections of these people. He certainly has not proved it in what he said yesterday. In any case, these people all have distinguished records in their own careers. I think their careers speak for themselves.

Senator Puplick also says that the board `is singularly defective in terms of people who actually produce and make films', and `there are no producers of films on the board'. He is quite incorrect about that. One of the board members is Gabrielle Kelly, who is a documentary maker. Dr Patricia Edgar is an executive producer in the Australian Children's Television Foundation, and of course Jack Thompson, who is also a board member, has been involved in films for many years now as an actor and soon to be a producer. I doubt very much that these people on the board will actually be deciding which projects are to be funded by the new Film Corporation. I am sure that, like most board members, they are there to decide on policy and on the overall direction of the Corporation.

The best that Senator Puplick could say was that he believes the Film Finance Corporation model will fail and that it will be a betrayal of the Australian film industry. But he put nothing in his remarks to support his claim. It is therefore not surprising that Senator Puplick should mourn the passing of the tax incentives for the film industry and their replacement, in effect, by what is a government organisation which is able to control how many and what sorts of films and major television projects are to be made in Australia. It is not surprising because the major grouping of individuals who benefited more than any other from the tax incentives, known as division 10BA, were Senator Puplick's friends, among the sharp lawyers and money men around town. It was these people who gradually destroyed the integrity of what had been a very worthwhile and largely bipartisan government endeavour to assist film production in Australia.

TALK.START.PARA: —You are reading your speech again.

—If the honourable senator would just be quiet he might learn something. The lawyers, the accountants, and the stockbrokers who participated in the film industry by recommending film investment to their clients, charging brokerage of up to 10 per cent and inflating the budgets of the films in question by up to 200 per cent in some cases, are the people who will suffer because of the establishment of the new Australian Film Finance Corporation. Under the tax incentives that Senator Puplick seems so fond of, the actual owners of the films which were made-the investors-did not care what sort of film was being made. Most of the time, they did not even know. The rorts which were going on under these incentives were well known to most of the professionals working in the film industry, and it was those professionals who wanted to call a stop to it. It was Prime Minister Fraser, I believe, who established the scheme.

SPEECH.PARA: Under this new scheme of assistance, the Government now has a far greater say in the type of films which may be made, the costs associated with those films and whether the people who make them have the right track record. In other words, the Government is able to control much more closely an industry which has cost the Australian taxpayers several hundred million dollars since 1980. Is it wrong to want to have a greater say in the expenditure of such large amounts of money, or should we leave it up to Senator Puplick's friends in North Shore legal practices and Bond Street broking houses?

The AFFC Board has just announced the granting of assistance to its first project. It is a television series which is a sequel to the very successful mini-series All The Rivers Run to be produced by Crawfords in Australia. Other projects are soon to be announced.

The AFFC Board consists of a blend of people from the film industry, from the law and from banking. Its Chairman, Kim Williams, who may or may not be a follower of the Australian Labor Party, happens to have led the Australian Film Commission (AFC), as its Chief Executive for four years, through the period of greatest change and productivity that the Australian film industry has ever seen. I remind honourable senators that in 1984 he was appointed by a Board which consisted largely of appointees of the previous Liberal Government.

Mr Williams also happens to be one of the most highly regarded individuals in the film industry. In a sense, he was born into it. His father, Mr David Williams, was Managing Director of the Greater Union organisation until a few years ago. Mr Williams had already established his own credentials in the arts industry before he came to the Film Commission. He was previously the Managing Director of Musica Viva, which is the largest chamber music organisation in the world. He also showed his analytical skills through a report he wrote for the Government on the Australian Opera. However, Senator Puplick continues to use this chamber to carry out what can only be perceived as a personal vendetta against Mr Williams. The only reason for his consistent attacks that I can think of is that Mr Williams does not have as many close personal friends who are lawyers, accountants and stockbrokers as Senator Puplick has. If he does, he does not let that get in the way of his better judgment for the future of the film industry.

In closing, I commend the AFC which this year established Film Australia, its production arm, as a wholly-owned government film making body. Under the highly competent and professional leadership of Robin Hughes, it is also working to develop a more commercial basis for its operations. The AFC, in a spirit of fostering international cooperation in film making, has also established a number of international film; making treaties with other countries. One of its co-productions with New Zealand, The Navigator, took out the best feature award at this year's Australian Film Institute festival. The AFC will continue to support low budget and experimental film making with its special production fund which assures the future of the industry by fostering the work of young talent.

The AFC and Kim Williams are to be commended not only for the leading role they have played in the establishment of the AFFC, but also generally for their invaluable work in fostering film culture in Australia. There have been few Australian films made in the last few years in which the AFC has not played a leading role. Many of those films have been acclaimed internationally.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —When I first came to this place, Senator Don Willesee, a Labor senator, took me aside one day and told me that if I wanted to get on in this place it was a good idea to play the ball and not the man. I commend that advice to Senator Dunn.

SPEECH.PARA: A former distinguished Liberal member of parliament, the Hon. Bill Wentworth, now aged 81, continues to have an active interest in matters economic. Bill Wentworth got his initial training through the Treasury in New South Wales in the 1930s. As honourable senators will recall, he was a Minister for Aboriginal Affairs; and he has taken a keen interest in questions of the current account deficit, on which he has written extensively. I am impressed by one of the papers he has written recently.

Mr Wentworth argues that the trends of the first two months of this year, which he was able to observe when he wrote the paper, are ominous in relation to what is likely to happen to the current account deficit. He then analyses the elements that go into making up this figure; namely, the goods and services element and the property and income and miscellaneous elements of the current account deficit. He draws attention to several trends which are developing and which affect each of these figures. He doubts that we have any chance of achieving the benchmark of the Treasurer (Mr Keating) of a $7.4 billion current account deficit. He doubts also that we can achieve the Treasury officials' estimate which appeared in the Budget Papers of $9,500m for the current account deficit. He advises to watch the figures coming in over succeeding months. I have to say to the Senate that the figures have come in and would tend to confirm the points made by Mr Wentworth. I seek leave to incorporate in Hansard the brief 2 1/2 page document that he has written.
Leave granted.
The document read as follows-
THE CURRENT ACCOUNT DEFICIT-UP OR DOWN?
By the Hon W C Wentworth

The Government's whole financial strategy is based on the premise that its policies are bringing Australia's Deficit on Current Account under control. If the trend of that Deficit should be upward, not downward, then its policies will have failed.

The results for the first two months of this financial year carry ominous overtones. In July and August 1988 the Deficit has been nearly $3,000 million, as against only about $2,100 million for the same two months of 1987. Too much weight, of course, should not be placed on the result for so short a period, but there are basic reasons which suggest that it represents a real trend.

The grant reduction in the 1987-88 Goods and Services deficit, as compared with the previous year, was due entirely to changes in overseas prices. For that period as a whole our export prices rose by about 8 per cent, while our import prices scarcely rose at all, so our ``terms of trade'' substantially improved. With 1987-88 Exports at $40544 million and Imports at $40410 million, it is evident that, without those overseas price changes, the total 1987-88 Current Account result would have been about even with 1985-86 peak, and somewhat worse than the result for 1986-87.

Can we expect a similar improvement in our terms of trade for 1988-89 as compared with 1987-88? Nobody should be too dogmatic about future world prices (our agricultural exports have already received an unpredicted bonus from Northern Hemisphere droughts) but the consensus of economic opinion is that, on the whole, our 1988-89 terms of trade will be a little worse than for last year.

The real volume of exports can be expected to rise next year, but not by much more than the 42.5 per cent which the ABS reports for last year. Meanwhile, the real volume of imports continues to surge upwards. The ABS reports an increase of 9 per cent for last year, and this year's increase will be fueled by the Government policy of tariff reduction.

On the services side, receipts from tourism will increase (the travel credit last year was $2959 million, an increase of $741 million over the previous year) but as against this the travel debit for Australians overseas at $3572 million increased last year by $366 million, so that the net improvement was only $275 million. The net improvement for 1988-89 is not likely to be very much different.

Subject therefore to uncertainties about the future course of world prices, there is reason to expect that the downward trend in the ``Goods and Services'' deficit, which has been running for the last two years, will be replaced by an upward trend, starting this year.

The deficit for ``Property Income etc.'' has been going up over the last four years by about $1,000 million per year, and this is likely to continue. The main engine driving it upwards is the income earned by the net annual foreign investment which is needed to finance the annual Current Account shortfall.

It would seem, therefore, that the bad figures for this July and August should not be lightly brushed aside. It is all too likely that they represent a real trend. With both the ``Goods and Services'' deficit rising and the ``Property Income etc'' deficit doing the same, the trend for the Current Account Deficit seems set to be upward also. The implications of this for the Government's financial policies are all too clear.

In his Budget Speech on 23 August, Mr Keating correctly described the balance of payments deficit as ``Australia's number one economic problem.'' If this strategy has failed to deal with it, then his strategy has failed overall.

It is somewhat ironic that while Mr Keating, over in Berlin was telling US and West Germany how they should reform their economies on the Australian pattern, he seems oblivious of what is happening here at home. Perhaps someone will remind him of the well-worn phrase about notes and beams.

And what about this year's Current Account Deficit. How will it measure up to the Treasurer's benchmark of $7,400 million, set in his own Budget Speech? There he forecast that ``This year our balance of payments deficit will be halved from its peak of just on three years ago.'' (The 1985-86 peak was, in fact, $14,807 million).

It is true that, in the Treasury papers attached to the Budget, the estimated deficit was set at $9,500 million, but the Treasurer himself adopted the lesser figure quite unequivocally. So far no explanation of the discrepancy has been forthcoming.

It is somewhat curious that so little attention has so far been paid to this crucial discrepancy of $2,100 million between the Treasurer's figures and those of his Department. At the last election, when there was a discrepancy of a quarter of this size in the Opposition's Budget Estimates, Mr Keating himself was quite scathing.

But it is more important that even the Treasury officials' estimate of $9500 million for the Current Account Deficit now seems to have been far too low. The absolute proof of this will have to wait the monthly figures as they come in, but the probability is already more than sufficient to occasion proper concern.
