QUESTION.SPEAKER: Vallentine Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Defence, upon notice, on 31 August 1988:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) When was the study on the risks and consequences of nuclear attack referred to in the Minister's answer to Question on Notice No. 15 (see Weekly Senate Hansard, 16 February 1988, page 73) made available to the emergency service in each State and Territory.
(2) What specific actions have been undertaken by: (a) Territory emergency services, especially Northern Territory services with respect to Pine Gap; and (b) State emergency services.
(3) Did the study referred to contain, in each case below:
(a) estimates of 6500 deaths (1500 blast and heat, 5000 fallout) from a worst-case attack on North West Cape;
(b) estimates of 15,120 deaths (120 blast and heat, 15,000 fallout) from a similar attack on Pine Gap;
(c) estimates of 24,620 deaths (2620 blast and heat, 22,000 fallout) from a similar attack on Nurrungar;
(d) estimates of 50,000 deaths (40,000 blast and heat, 10,000 fallout) from a worst case attack on Darwin;
(e) estimates of 27,000 deaths (2000 blast heat, 25,000 fallout) from a similar attack on Cockburn Sound; and

(f) estimates of 960,000 deaths from blast and heat plus 2.6 million deaths from fallout in the event of worst-case attacks on all of Sydney (Port Jackson), Sydney (Port Botany), Newcastle, Wollongong, Melbourne, Geelong, Port Adelaide and Fremantle.
(4) With respect to each section of part (3) above:
(a) are the figures given (i) contained in the study referred to, (ii) figures developed by the Minister's Department, and (iii) accurate estimates;
(b) if the estimates are not accurate, will the Minister provide accurate estimates; if not, why not.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Defence has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The study was made available in April 1987 to the authorities responsible for emergency services in the Northern Territory, Western Australia and South Australia. It is now being updated to examine the implications of the more accurate and lower yield systems being developed for the Soviet strategic arsenal.
(2) Questions about specific actions undertaken by Territory and State emergency services would be best asked of the responsible Territory or State Minister.
(3) (a) No. (b) No. (c) No. (d) No. (e) No. (f) No.
(4) (a) See the answer to part 3 of the question.

(b) The update referred to in the answer to part 1 of the question will encompass a review of the casualty estimates for communities adjacent to the joint defence facilities. The number of those casualties would of course be heavily dependent on what protective measures had been taken by and for the local populations; casualties would be minimised if arrangements were made for evacuation of the communities. The Government is working with State emergency organisations to this end.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Australian and New Zealand Dairy Industries

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Archer Sen B.R.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy, upon notice, on 30 August 1988:

QUESTION.PARA: In view of the need to discuss and determine outstanding issues of Closer Economic Relations, have Australian and New Zealand officers established the relative degree of assistance to the dairy industries of both countries; if not, can arrangements be put in hand forthwith to produce those figures and achieve an acceptable resolution for all parties in both countries.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Primary Industries and Energy has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: Analyses have been conducted over recent years at government and industry level and by international agencies to review aspects of Australian and New Zealand assistance to the dairy industry. Major changes have been made recently to policies affecting assistance levels for dairying in each country and some of these policies continue to affect assistance levels.

From the Australian perspective, key concerns in the recent negotiations on dairy matters in the Review of the Closer Economic Relations Trade Agreement centred on the monopoly export and pricing powers of the New Zealand Dairy Board and the implications for unrestricted access by New Zealand to the Australian market from 1 July 1990 when the current Memorandum of Understanding on Dairy Products between the Australian and New Zealand dairy industries ceases.

Against this background the Government has negotiated arrangements, which are of treaty status, to apply to trans-Tasman trade in dairy products from 1 July 1990 to ensure that trade is fair as well as free. The agreed arrangements are consistent with the principles and objectives of ANZCERTA and include understandings contained in an exchange of letters between the Australian and New Zealand Governments which guarantee fair trading tactics.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Jones Sen G.N.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade, upon notice, on 29 September 1988:

QUESTION.PARA: Noting the announcement on 2 September 1988 by the Minister for Trade Negotiations, Mr Duffy, that Australia would provide $350,000 for emergency assistance to flood-damaged Bangladesh:
(a) In view of deteriorating conditions in Bangladesh, is this level of aid adequate;
(b) How many people are now homeless in that country, and how many are dead or injured;
(c) What is the projected level of infectious disease in the eventual wake of the floods;
(d) What is the level of damage to infrastructure such as roads and bridges;
(e) How permanent is the overall damage to the future survival of Bangladesh as a nation; and

(f) What monitoring measures are being taken by the Australian Government to make sure the level of aid is adequate to ensure a rich country such as Australia can assist a poorer world partner, such as Bangladesh.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (a) The $350,000 contribution of 2 September 1988 was an initial response for-
(i) Emergency medical and relief supplies disbursed through the Australian High Commission in Dhaka and local non-government organisations (NGOs); and
(ii) urgent survey work on damage to roads and bridges to be carried out by the Snowy Mountains Engineering Corporation (SMEC).
On 9 September, a further $1 million was approved for emergency food aid in the form of 5000 tonnes of wheat.
On 13 September, $20,000 was provided towards the promotion costs for an appeal by the International Disaster Emergencies Committee (IDEC) for their Bangladesh Flood Appeal.
On 20 September the Government provided $115,000 for the charter of an aircraft to fly urgently needed food, medicines and water purifying tablets provided by several Australian NGOs.
On 15 November the government announced the following package of assistance
$2.5 million for supply and shipment of approximately 10,000 tonnes of wheat for emergency relief
$550,000 for emergency relief through four Australian NGOs-CARE, World Vision Australia, Australian Freedom from Hunger Campaign and the Salvation Army
$200,000 for UNICEF's health and nutrition recovery activities
a commitment to provide $22 million in developmental food aid to Bangladesh over the next two years to better enable the Government of Bangladesh to plan its development activities.

(b) and (c) The 1988 floods displaced and affected an estimated 45 million people, 40 per cent of the population of 110 million. The official death toll as a direct result of the floods is 1644. More than 735 deaths were caused subsequently by diarrhoeal disease. The indirect death toll is likely to have been much higher.

(d) The full extent of damage to roads and bridges will be known when the SMEC and Asian Development Bank (ADB) teams complete their reports, but it is expected to be very extensive. The preliminary estimate of damage to roads, bridges and railroads is US$246 million.

(e) The impact of the floods on the Bangladesh economy is obviously devastating and a joint government of Bangladesh/UN assessment team has just completed its report. Fifteen per cent of the food crop has been lost, an estimated 2.5 million tonnes. The extent of damage to other crops is similarly grave. The UN held a special meeting in mid-November which provided a detailed analysis of damage, along with rehabilitation needs.
(f) The Government is closely monitoring developments in Bangladesh from reports by the Australian High Commission in Dhaka, international organisations and voluntary aid agencies.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Sanders Sen N.K.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Defence, upon notice, on 20 October 1988:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) When does the Minister plan to release the draft of the Environmental Impact Statement (EIS) for the proposed shift of naval facilities from Sydney to Jervis Bay?
(2) When will the Jervis Bay marine ecological studies announced by the Minister in his news release No. 130/88 be completed?

(3) Will the draft EIS be released before or after the completion of the marine studies; if before, how does the Minister justify the expenditure of $5.5m on a study which will be only partially relevant to the EIS?
(4) Is there an apparent 7 to 9 year cycle in the scallop population in Jervis Bay?
(5) Will the marine studies, and hence the EIS, be too short in duration to evaluate adequately the impact on the scallop population of the shift of naval facilities to Jervis Bay?

(6) Are there other ecological cycles in the Jervis Bay marine ecosystem which are longer than 3 years; if so, what are the species and cycle lengths involved. Will the marine studies, and hence the EIS, be too short in duration to evaluate adequately the impact on those species of the shift to naval facilities to Jervis Bay?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Defence has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The Draft EIS is planned for release in April 1989.
(2) The Jervis Bay marine ecological studies are planned to be completed by 30 November 1991.

(3) The draft EIS will be released well before the completion of the marine studies. The marine studies will address the overall need for ongoing management of the Jervis Bay marine environment having regard to the Navy's current, and continuing, activities there. Should a decision be made to go ahead with development of an Armament Depot or Fleet Base at Jervis Bay, then this data will also provide a basis for the development of appropriate environmental management plans.
(4) There is insufficient scientific evidence to conclude that the two known periods of intensive scallop fishing form a cycle of the scallop population.

(5) Any Naval relocation to Jervis Bay will not occur prior to the development of a management plan based substantially on the marine studies presently being conducted. If the 7 to 9 year cycle exists, as suggested in the previous question, then it should occur during the currency of the planned marine ecology studies.

(6) The marine studies conducted over 3 years will provide highly credible research information that will address the principal components of the ecosystems and their cycles. Cycles which occur within the study period will be observed, the most significant being the yearly cycle. In the longer term, planned monitoring programmes should provide further knowledge of systems which have longer cycles. The duration and extent of the studies go further than any normally undertaken in association with development proposals.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Archer Sen B.R.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy, upon notice, on 2 November 1988:

QUESTION.PARA: Can the Minister provide further details to that provided in his reply to my Question on Notice No. 417 of 2 June 1988, about the recall action which may be instituted in case contamination is found in a consignment of cheese, in particular: (a) to what extent is such recall enforceable; and (b) if not fully enforceable, how effective is it.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Primary Industries and Energy has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (a) The recall action which is instituted in any case where contamination is found in a consignment of imported cheese is administered by the Federal Bureau of Consumer Affairs of the Attorney-General's Department in cooperation with the state/territory health departments. Such recall action is effected on a voluntary basis by distributors of goods which are considered to pose a risk to public health. However, the Trade Practices Act empowers the Minister for Consumer Affairs to effect a mandatory recall of such product if voluntary action is not satisfactory. The Australian Quarantine and Inspection Service considers that such action is effective provided that recall is initiated expeditiously. To supplement these formal recall procedures, additional measures involving advising importers to withhold distribution of product as soon as generic tests show the likelihood of failure, have been implemented. Importers have responded well to this voluntary scheme of product control. Additionally, the Service has the authority under the Quarantine Act to apply mandatory controls and recall product into quarantine bond should co-operation not be forthcoming.

(b) Only two positive confirmed detections of Listeria monocytogenes, both from the Category 1 group of cheeses, i.e. cheeses with a previous history of failure in Australia or overseas, have been made since the routine import monitoring regimen for cheese was finalised in January 1988. No recall was necessary to prevent the distribution of these products as they were being held in quarantine bond pending clearance by testing. All affected product was destroyed under quarantine supervision. Additionally there were three false positives reported and in all these cases the importers involved were advised and voluntarily withheld their product from distribution until confirmatory testing indicated freedom from Listeria monocytogenes.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Macklin Sen M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy, upon notice, on 2 November 1988:

QUESTION.PARA: Does the Australian Government keep records of subsidised wheat sold to major Australian markets by the United States Government under its Export Enhancement Program (EEP), if so, what has been: (a) the tonnage; (b) the value of the total sales; and (c) the value of the subsidy on wheat sales made to both the USSR and the People's Republic of China since EEP's announcement by the US Government in May 1985.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Primary Industries and Energy has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: I can confirm that my Department keeps detailed records of all subsidised US sales under the EEP. Full details of these sales, including subsidies applying to US wheat sold to major Australian markets were provided in my response to Question No. 276 asked by Senator Macklin on 23 March 1988. My response to Question No. 276 also provided information on EEP subsidised sales to the USSR and China including tonnage and subsidy levels. My earlier response is brought up to date, for recent sales, by the following figures:
USSR-(a) 12,804,800 tonnes. (b) not available. (c) US$447,895,778.
China-(a) 9,190,000 tonnes. (b) not available. (c) US$284,616,100.

Finally, a point of clarification on procedures; the US Government does not make any sales under the EEP. Sales are made by private traders with the assistance of EEP subsidies, in the form of certificates redeemable in Government owned program commodities such as wheat, barley, cotton and corn, provided by the US Government.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 25 August 1988 (Hansard page 258), Senator Knowles asked me, as Minister representing the Treasurer, the following question without notice:

ANSWER.PARA: Is the Minister representing the Treasurer, or the Treasurer, aware that some employers, at the suggestion of the Australian Taxation Office, are already requesting employees to furnish tax file numbers in anticipation of the extended use of the tax file numbering system after November? Does the Treasurer or the Minister condone such an invasion of privacy at a time when legislation is yet to appear before the Parliament and has no guarantee of being passed?
The Treasurer has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

The Australian Taxation Office is not suggesting to employers that they seek the tax file numbers of their employees. Such action by employers would be clearly inappropriate prior to the commencement date for the new tax file number arrangements as they apply to employees. That date is to be set by proclamation and a public announcement will be made at the relevant time. Following recent passage of the Taxation Laws Amendment (Tax File Number) Bill 1988 through the Parliament it is likely that the commencement date will be 1 February 1989.
